Why are some observers continuing to undermine the scheme?

âI thank the member for Grey for the question and for the close interest he takes in the Work for the Dole projects in his electorate. Based on encouraging early results, the government expanded Work for the Dole from a 10,000-place pilot scheme to 125,000 places over four years. I am pleased to say that further evaluation has confirmed the wisdom of that decision. Analysis of that initial pilot program shows that 32 per cent of Work for the Dole participants have gone on to unsubsidised work or to further education or training at a cost of $3,900 per success.

answer.para: This compares very favourably with the Working Nation programs under the former government. For instance, the LEAP program had a 26 per cent success rate at the cost of $26,900 per outcome. The Jobskills program had a 30 per cent success rate at the cost of $36,000 per outcome. The New Work Opportunities program, which was really the flagship labour market program under the former government, had a 21 per cent success rate at the cost of $52,000 per outcome. It is clear that, compared with Working Nation programs, Work for the Dole is getting results which are significantly better for job seekers, and far better for taxpayers.

Work for the Dole is not so much a training program as a work experience program, because this government believes that the best training for work is work itself. That is what the government believes, and that is what the member for Melbourne believes because the member for Melbourne said of the former government's Working Nation programs, `They led to perverse outcomes, with some unemployed people forced to undertake inappropriate and even demoralising training.'

I have been asked why some observers are still undermining this scheme. The answer is quite simple: members opposite are slaves to the union movement and quite unrepresentative of the Australian people. Some 14 per cent of Australian adults are members of the trade union movement. The percentage of members opposite who are members of the trade union movement is not 30 per cent, it is not 50 per cent, it is not 70 per centâit is 100 per cent. Every one of them is a trade union member because they are required to be by the Labor Party.

talk.start.para: â I have received a letter from the honourable member for Batman proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

interjection.para: The government's lack of original and positive proposals to respond to the unemployment crisis.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their placesâ

talk.start.para: âI rise this afternoon to speak on the most important issue of jobs, and in addressing that issue, to discuss the lack of original and positive proposals in response to the unemployment crisis that confronts Australia at the moment. I will deal with the agenda of the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business and Leader of the House. We should look at the agenda of the minister as he escapes the House.

speech.para: Born in July 1950, the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Busi ness likes to think of himself as a modern man. He was elected to parliament on 4 December 1982, put out to pasture in 1983 and returned in 1984. I think it is fair to say that the minister is a person who likes to collect titles. We only have to look at the recent election to see how he goes about collecting titles. Since the election in March 1996, he has added workplace relations, employment and small business to his original responsibilities of industrial relations and Leader of the House.

Not only does he like to collect titles but, unfortunately, he is not a person you would describe as a team player or a very loyal person. This is borne out in a document that I want to address this afternoon. The whole thrust of the document is not about trying to create an environment that will lead to sustained jobs growth in Australia but, unfortunately, is an endeavour to engender and encourage class war and division in Australia.

When you read this document, you get the thrust of the real Peter Reith, Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Businessâand, I must add, Leader of the House. He wants to create the feeling that he is urbane and friendly, and from time to time we see a smiling image. He is even trying to teach his apprentice, the Minister for Employment Services, this approach to political life, but we all know from question time that that approach is wearing very thin.

Under the smiles and the friendly, hail-fellow-well-met style, we find an old class warrior, who, unfortunately, is the worst type of class warrior. I would have thought that a minister of the Crown, when elected to that high office, should adopt the approach that his responsibilities are to seek to put aside what he might believe in his heart, to try to develop a sense of decency and to adopt the approach, `I hold this high office because I am here to try to work out what is in the best interests of all Australians.'

The Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business approaches his job on the basis of class war. It is in that context that I draw the attention of the House to a speech that the minister gave at a busi ness lunch in Perth last year. In that speech, he said:
Never forget the history of politics and never forget which side we're on. We're on the side of making profits. We're on the side of people owning private capital.
I want to repeat that quote because it goes to the heart of the series of questions that the opposition put to the minister this afternoon. Again, I quote:
Never forget the history of politics and never forget which side we're on. We're on the side of making profits. We're on the side of people owning private capital.

It is against that backdrop that we are debating a real issue of public importance today. We could debate the issue on the basis of scorn and derision. We could throw up issues of who on the frontbench has trusts, why they have trusts, and why, through their minimisation of tax, they are seeking to make it harder for governments, from a revenue point of view, to deliver services which the Australian public expects.

On 5 February, the shadow Treasurer and Deputy Leader of the Opposition raised, at long last, the need for a bipartisan approach to the most important issue in Australia at the moment, which is jobs growth and, more importantly, an equitable share of those jobs across the length and breadth of Australia. I say that with some strength, not because of our backgroundsâsome of us are trade union officials and proud of itâand not because some of our parents were formerly politicians, but because of the nature of the electorates that we represent. For whatever reason, we tend to represent areas of disadvantage. How easy it would be to represent a seat in the northern suburbs of Sydney, such as that occupied by the Minister for Employment Services. What an easy job it would beâdecent levels of employment, a fair level of prosperity and not a bad quality of life.

I compare that with the types of seats represented on this side of the House. We can go through them: the problems of Western Sydney, such as in the seat of Werriwa; the problems of Fowler; the problems of Throsby on the New South Wales South Coast; the problems of the northern suburbs of Mel bourneâmy own seat of Batmanâwhere we have unemployment far higher than the national average.

So we raise these issues today not on the basis of mere point scoring but on the basis that the time has come for the government and, more importantly, the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, to come clean. That is what it is about: honesty in government. That is what the questions today went to. They went to the heart of why we were elected hereâand this applies to the majority of us on both sides of the House. We were elected not only on the basis that, irrespective of backgrounds, we want to do the best job for the people we represent; we were also elected on the basis that we would seek to bring honesty to government, and that there would be no secret plans based on punishment which, unfortunately, is the thrust of the minister's secret agendaâyou know, the scribblings from the penthouse on St Kilda Road.

I am not worried about people writing books and putting ideas forward. The Minister for Employment Services has been known to write a few books and a few speeches on the way through. The problem with respect to some of those people is that we are now operating in the real world, the tough world of decision makingâwe have left universityâunlike the petty point scoring of the Minister for Employment Services.

We live in a dynamic world. We learn from our mistakes and we seek to improve our performance in government. I therefore suggest that, yes, we do need a bipartisan approach to government. We are vitally concerned about looking after the unemployed in Australia at the moment, not just the young people but also the mature age people, many from a blue collar background with family responsibilities who are doing it awful tough at the moment.

The Minister for Employment Services has not read the document that I will make available this afternoon. I am offended by suggestions in this document from his senior minister that there is no real major problem in Australia when it comes to mature age unemployment. He goes on to suggestâand this is driven by their mate Mr Textorâthat `for appearances sake we might badge a few programs and make it look as if we are trying to do something.' That is just not good enough. Australia's unemployed and their families deserve better, and I will tell you what they also deserve better. If we are to get a sense of bipartisanship on the issue of unemployment, we deserve better than a third-term agenda that is based on bombs, grenades, balaclavas, dogs and really bad booby traps. That is the basis of this document: it is a return to the division that we saw last year on the waterfront.

The minister likes to question our trade union background. I simply say that in the history of the trade union movement there were excesses, but this side of the House was part of the modernisation of the Australian trade union movement. We learnt that there was a new world order. We learnt about globalisation and the need for Australia to be able to compete internationally in order to try to advance the standard of living of not only trade unionists but, more importantly, all Australians. That is what the trade union movement is concerned about. It is not concerned about inward looking class statements such as that made by the minister for workplace relations in Perth last year. It is concerned about a program of action that is based on compassion and aggression internationally to create decent jobs in Australia, based on Australia competing on fair wages and conditions of employment for a fair day's work but, more importantly, based on developing in Australia through a relevant training agenda the most skilled work force in the world.

That is why I say it sickens me, as someone who had to be part of those hard decisions. The minister talked about me in 1977. I started with the union movement in November 1975. I went through it allâthe class war of the Fraser years and the sense brought to government by Keating and Hawke, with the support of all Australians, of one Australiaâus all pulling together and facing up to some of the mistakes and excesses of the past. That was not easy. When it comes to populism, I can think of disputes such as one just before I came into parliament. I was standing at a mass meeting of over 2,000 workers at Mt Isa who were screaming for my blood, addressing them on the basis that they had to get back to work, modernise their workplace and look at how they could cooperate with employers. And who did I have running around the picket lines trying to undermine me in my desire to develop a sense of cooperation in Mt Isa? None other than a member of the government, the member for Kennedy. Class war and divisionâwe know on which side of the House it operates.

The deputy leader, with the support of the whole of the Labor Party Australia wide is right: unemployment is at a crisis point. We need a bipartisan approach to this issue. Where are the ideas coming from? They are coming from this side of the House. We understand about workplace relations and cooperation. We also understand about protecting the disadvantaged in the work forceâmany of whom are women and others who, unfortunately, are workers with a disability. We also understand about the poverty traps and tax credits. We understand about training and we understand about regional development.

But we cannot understand a poisoned, narrow-minded approach to Australia as we move into the 21st century that says that the second-form agenda, based on the work of Mr Textor and a poll-driven government is as follows: we completely sideline the award system; we sideline the Industrial Relations Commission; we abolish the living wage case before the commission and we replace it with living wage panels made up of those really friendly people from the Productivity Commission, the Reserve Bank and Treasury.

It gets worse. This is, I suppose, the issue of reciprocal obligation. I believe in it. I was a trade union official when the Labor Party came to talk to the union movement about its responsibilities to the unemployed. Not only did we embrace the reciprocal obligation; we also brought in the training wage in acknowledgment of the fact that some of the long-term unemployed are not necessarily as skilled as those at work with a work history.

I move on to their agenda for reciprocal obligation: people pulling their weight. Two sides to the bargain. The unemployed are good people. They want to work. But they are limiting access to social security allowances to no more than six months. They are limiting access to youth allowances and hiding real unemployment numbers by rapidly expanding compulsory work for the dole. I end on this point: we have exposed the real agenda. Australia deserves better. I say, on behalf of the Labor opposition, that we are part and want to be part of the future direction of Australia. We want a bipartisan approach to unemployment, and we want to put to bed the class war. We have learned. When will you learn?

talk.start.para: âI am perfectly prepared to concede goodwill, enthusiasm and dedication to the member for Batman and other members opposite as long as they will return the compliment to members of the government. I will welcome the statement today by the member for Batman about the dedication of the opposition in tackling the unemployment cancer provided he will also welcome the dedication that we on this side have to doing precisely the same thing. There is no higher cause, there is no more important issue, there is no more urgent national task than bringing unemployment down and keeping it down. I welcome many of the things that were said by the member for Batman today, but I wish that he had been prepared to concede to us the same goodwill, the same generosity of spirit, the same dedication to our country that he takes for himself. We are all Australians in this place. We all want to bring unemployment down.

speech.para: The member for Batman began with some cheap shots at my senior colleague the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. The minister is not nearly as tough on members opposite as is the Labor Party on itself. The member for Werriwa has been responsible for some pungent utterances against his colleagues. The member for Melbourne has made equally sharp criticisms of his colleagues. I seem to recall the former Prime Minister Mr Keating describing the former member for Fraser as a `complete buffoon' in an interview he gave to Gerard Henderson some years ago. Former Senator Jim McClelland was a legendary acid-tongued individual. It was said by one of his former New South Wales Labor colleagues that his greatest fault was that he said the first vicious thing that came into his head. One of the things that he recently said, just before he died, was that the Leader of the Opposition was nothing but an overweight lightweight. The mere fact that there are robust exchanges in this parliament should not be allowed to mask the complete dedication that this government and members of the coalition have to tackling the cancer of unemployment.

As the Treasurer said today in answer to a question during question time, under this government inflation has averaged one per cent. Under the former government it averaged over five per cent. Under this government productivity growth has averaged three per cent. Under the former government it averaged 1.5 per cent. Under this government real wages have on average grown by 2.5 per cent. Under the former government they grew on average by just half a per cent.

This government has a good story to tell. This government has a proud record. Sure, we would like it to be betterâwho would not? But the fact is it is a good record, and certainly it stands comparison with the record of members opposite who had 13 years in which to address this problem. Since this government came into office total employment has risen by nearly 400,000. In 1998 alone nearly 200,000 new jobs were created in Australia. That represents annual growth of 2.1 per cent compared with an average of under one per cent for the whole of the OECD area.

At present unemployment is 7.5 per cent, the lowest since September 1990. It is still too high. Of course we concede that. We would be crazy not to concede that. We would betray the Australian people if we did not concede that. But it is heading in the right direction. I should point out to the member for Denison that the rate was, I think, 8.5 per cent in March 1996, so things are going in the right direction. It peaked at 11 per cent in December 1992. That was the former Prime Minister's worst gift to Australia. Youth unemployment is still far too high, but it is now 24 per cent which is a significant, although not satisfactory, fall from March 1996. I should also point out that youth unemployment as a percentage of the teenage population is just 5.4 per cent. Long-term unemployment is also coming down. It is now about 230,000 which is well down from a peak of 350,000 during the former government's recession that we had to have.

I would hate to give the impression that this government is complacent or triumphant about employment and unemployment issues. We must always be doing more. We are doing a very great deal. The problem with members opposite is that despite the enthusiasm and the sincerity, despite the fact that there were some good ideas and some innovative policies under the Keating governmentâof course we must concede thatâthere is this mighty sacred cow that members opposite have never been prepared to slaughterâthat is, government in the interests of the trade union movement. It has been pointed out by me and by others in this parliament that 50 per cent of the Labor Party's 1996 parliamentary intake are former union officials. There is nothing wrong with trade unions. I was a member of a trade union for some years when I was a journalist. I recall one day at Australian Consolidated Press proposing a motion to go on strike when the employer had, in my view, unfairly dismissed a number of my colleagues. I have a lot of respect for the union movement. I just think that the union movement should not be privileged. The union movement should have no special standing or status beyond that attributed to any other sectional group in our society. That is the problem. Fifty per cent of the new intake are former union officials, and 52 per cent of the frontbench are former union officials. If you listened to the maiden speeches of the new intake you would think that Paul Keating had never been Prime Minister and certainly that he had never had an economic policy. You would think the Berlin Wall had never fallen, reading through their maiden speeches. The problem is that they are slaves to the unions and slaves to the public sector. They totally believe in government of the unions, by the unions and for the unions.

This government has pursued three broad strategies to bring unemployment down. The first strategy is obviously to produce a more buoyant economy. To that end we have, at considerable political cost and not without pain in the general community, substantially reduced federal government spending. We have shaved about $10 billion off federal government outlays since we came into office. We have not done it because we enjoy being Uncle Scrooge. We have not done it because we like the screams of pain and suffering, some real and some confected, that welcome policies of this sort. We have done it because it is the only way to get interest rates down, and low interest rates and a more buoyant private sector economy are the best gift that we can give to the unemployed people of Australia, because that is where the jobs are generated to give them the life, the future and the hope that they need.

The second thing we have done is try to produce a more productive work force. That is why my senior colleague has pursued so tenaciously industrial relations reform, even in the teeth of obstruction from the former Leader of the Australian Democrats and current Labor frontbencher, the member for Dickson. We want those people who are in work to be able to work more efficiently and more productively because that is the way that they can be paid more, that is the way that our company profits can increase and that is the way that the economy can expand.

We have also pursued heroically, in the person of the current Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, a strong reform of the education and training sector. The member for Goldstein is a great and distinguished academic, yet he has taken to heart the interests of those 70 per cent of Australians who never go near a university. Thanks to the reforms that he has implemented, there are now more apprentices and trainees in Australia than at any time in our history. I do not want to blow my own trumpet on this; I simply want to say that one of the other great legacies of the member for Goldstein is the Job Network. The Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs and Senator Vanstone, now Minister for Justice, deserve enormous credit for having the vision and the courage to put in place a Job Network which is working far better than the old CES at the vital task of ensuring that what jobs are available are filled as quickly as possible by the best possible people.

The third broad strand that we have pursued is creating a culture of work in this country. The most important single change that we have made is introducing the principle of mutual obligation. This is a much maligned and much misunderstood principle. Mutual obligation is not about punishing unemployed people, it is about empowering them. If someone cannot read and write, if they cannot count, if they cannot think, they are no good to themselves, they are no good to their community and they are no good to their families. They need the help that this government is giving them through the programs that we have put in place under mutual obligation. There is nothing good in telling people that a life of idleness is acceptable. The only preparation for work is work, and mutual obligation is giving people the work experience that they need if they are going to make the most of the rest of their lives. Telling people that they can sit idly by and lead a good life, telling people that the world owes them a living or telling people that someone else will do it all for them is not doing them any favours. It is condemning them to a life that no member opposite, if he or she was to think clearly about it, would want.

I think there are a great deal of original policies in our program. As I said, the Job Network is a world first. No other country anywhere in the world has taken this step. No other country anywhere in the world has put the provision of employment services completely into the hands of the community sector and the private sector. We have done this because we trust the people, because we trust organisations like the Salvation Army, Mission Australia, Centacare and the Brotherhood of St Laurence. We trust them to do a better job than bureaucracies, however hard-working and however decent. We trust them because we know that they are close to the people and we know that they have the welfare of those they serve at their heart. They are not clock watchers, they are not people who follow pettifogging rules, they are not people who knock off at five o'clock whether or not there is a problem to be solvedâthey are people who will go the extra mile for those they seek to serve. That is why we have given them the prime responsibility for delivering these very important services to their fellow Australians.

I am delighted that our Job Network is attracting international attention and international interest. In fact, we recently had a large delegation of British members of parliament coming to Australia to learn about the Job Network and to see what aspects of that they could implement in Britain. As this parliament can guess, I am myself an Anglophile, but I am delighted to see that these days we have much more to teach them than they have to teach us.

I will concede that mutual obligation is a development of the principle of reciprocal obligation put in place by the former Labor government. We have taken it further. We have said to young people that it is not enough simply to look for work. We have said, `If, having looked for work, none is available, we will empower you by offering to you programs and projects that will enable you to make the most of your lives.' I fail to understand the self-righteousness of members opposite over this. We have taken a good idea from Labor and further developed it. We have done to this principle what the Labor Party should have done if it had had more time in office.

To the extent that our ideas are supposedly not original, it is only because we thought of them before this stint in government. Work for the Dole has recently been attributed in the press to American academics. In fact, the first publicly formulated work for the dole plan that I can find was the policy of the community service scheme that we took to the election in 1987.

Our policies are original and positive. We are not pursuing in respect of unemployment the classic textbook theories. We are not just cutting wages. We are not cutting wages at allâthey are going up by 2.5 per cent. Some wages are going up by much more if productivity increases. We are not just mindlessly boosting spending. We are selectively increasing spending in areas where it will help rather than simply spending first and thinking later, which all too often was the policy of the former government. Our policy is smarter work and more clever spending. The beauty of all of that is that it is working, and members opposite should acknowledge that. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe Howard government is a no-ideas government. It lacks any original thoughts or positive proposals to respond to the unemployment crisis faced by Australia. It has not come up with one new idea, policy or initiative to help the unemployed or to reduce the unemployment problem. To the government, it is business as usual and more luck to those who can survive on their own. This government's agenda is simple: it is about lower wages and higher taxes. That is the only agenda the government has. This is its vision. This is where it wants Australia to be in the future.

speech.para: We on this side of the House have been heavily criticised because we have original ideas. We have been criticised because we write books. We have been criticised because we are prepared to challenge the status quo, unlike the government, which dredges up outdated systems from Europe and America and hopes that no-one will notice. It would be a sad day if we were to give up trying to do better for the people of Australia. We cannot accept that nothing more can be done and, therefore, people should just accept what they are given. We will never be satisfied that all that can be done has been done. I am proud to belong to a party that has this fortitude and courage.

Where are the new ideas from the front bench on the government side? Where are the new ideas from the back bench? Where are any new or positive ideas from this whole government? In fact, there are none: no new ideas and no books, unless of course you want to include the only recent book of note, and that was written by Bob Ellis.

This government is living in the past in a policy vacuum with a back to the future approach to policy. Instead, this government should be investing in people, industry and innovation. We should be investing in education and training. We should be looking to our youth for new ideas and inspiration. We need to value the contribution that can be made by our older citizens and we need to accept that, with adequate training, workers can have long and meaningful employment in ever changing industries.

We need a government that has the courage to commit resources and funding to where it will do the most good. There is a huge role for government to play in achieving all of these goalsâand it can be done. Reciprocal obligation means the government has a responsibility also. The Labor Party is committed to all Australians who want a guarantee for a better future.

No-one has been fooled by the systematic program of attacks on ordinary workers and families. The attacks on workers have been thorough and deeply felt. The government's idea of reform is dogs and balaclavas on Australia's wharves. To them, reform is about punishing those with literacy problems who have been let down by the education system, a system reeling from slashed budgets. To the government, reform is about making it harder for people to qualify for assistance and decreasing the availability of services provided. It is about shifting the goalposts of eligibility.

When the government talks about sound financial management and the budget surplus figures, it is really talking about how many more dollars they have scrooged from the pockets of ordinary workers and families. Literacy programs should be used to assist the unemployed to get jobs, not as a means to reduce welfare numbers. Where is the government's responsibility to mutual obligation when it only hands out the stick and definitely not the carrot?

They have cut funding to Centrelink and want 5,000 more jobs to be cut. The system by which the unemployed are supposed to get help and find work has failed. Up to 80 per cent of people that try to get through to Centrelink are failed by this government's system. So, when the unemployed try to get assistance with literacy programs, the government will fail them before they start because of the lack of resources at Centrelink. This is just another example of the Howard government's push polling approach, a policy devoid of commitments and concern for those in need.

The government needs to explain the theory of economic growth to the six million customers of Centrelink who are increasingly becoming disenfranchised as their calls go unanswered. The only growth they see are the debts of trying to provide for their families. It is not good enough for a government to scapegoat or punish the unemployed for a problem they did not create, while this government eats caviar and drinks champagne. This government has not yet realised that the people they attack may be unemployed, and some may have problems with literacy, but they will not have any problems filling out the ballot paper at the next election.

The government's approach to the Work for the Dole scheme has been based purely on popular opinion and polling than on any new idea or credible approach to assisting the jobless. In 1996 the Howard government slashed $1 billion from training programs and undermined the highly effective Skillshare system. Their solution is to reinvent Work for the Dole by providing no training and no jobs. Again, it is a matter for the government to blame the unemployed but do nothing to help.

The government is devoid of any new ideas or positive approaches to solving the unemployment problem in Australia. The government has persisted with an ideologically driven class division by its attempts to remove unfair dismissal laws. This is another example of the job destroying old ideas of the past coming from this conservative government. The attacks by this government on the unfair dismissal laws are designed to make it easy for unscrupulous employers to sack people at will.

This is a job destroying policy. The very fact that an arbitrary limit of 15 employees has been set is in itself an incentive for small business not to employ more than this number so as to fall within the regulations. This will stunt business growth and it will ensure that some businesses will go to extremes to find loopholes. Small business, when asked what they would like to see most changed, usually respond by saying `less paperwork'. So what does the government do? It proposes to introduce the paperwork nightmare called the GST.

The government justifies its position by saying that the passage of these regulations would create jobs, yet the minister refuses to use his own department's research showing that less than one per cent of businesses see the unfair dismissal laws as any reason not to employ someone. Time and time again this government trots out dodgy figures produced by an even dodgier methodology, figures that are a result of nothing more than push polling. The government's claim that this will create 50,000 jobs is totally baseless and it flies in the face of the reality of the many more jobs destroyed by the government to dateâthe countless jobs from the Public Service, our schools, our universities and government service provision agencies.

The future for many workers is in rapidly changing industries, and that future is in training. It is expected that workers will have to learn new and different skills and will then have to retrain to keep up with changing technology. They will need support through government training programs and assistanceâin particular, those who find themselves out of work. But instead of there being more emphasis on training and the skilling-up of workers, they slash programs and blame the unemployed for their situation. Again, this is a no-ideas government with no positive approach to fixing the problems of the unemployed.

Mr Deputy Speaker, John Howard's government has broken so many promises that it is difficult for me just to pick a few, but indulge me for a moment. The Prime Minister and the government promised that a GST or anything like it was completely off the coalition's agenda. But, in fact, the Prime Minister spoke those now infamous words, `Never, ever.' `Never, ever will we introduce a GST.' Now they tell us that a GST will be good for the country; it will be good for the economy; it will be good for the unemployed; it will be good for absolutely everything.

The government's chosen economic modeller, Chris Murphy, no longer agrees. He has cut his estimated benefit to Australia from $1 billion to $607 million. That represents just 65c per person per week. But wait: this is under the most favourable assumptions by the government's chosen modeller. So the economists have now agreed that it will not create jobs; in fact, it will destroy jobs. It will create more paperwork for small business. It will hurt charitable organisations. In fact, the Royal Lifesavers Association of Australia recently said that it may even cost lives. At the end of the day, there is nothing in it for the rest of us, either. So this is what this government calls reforms. This is what they call new ideas. This is what they call a positive approach.

Minister Reith has made his leadership ambitions very clear. He thinks that the way he can do this is to destroy unions. And if workers get caught up along the way, he does not care. The Prime Minister's support for this is to the detriment of workers, whom he will also hurt with his `never, ever' GST.

The government's attacks on unions and their members have far-reaching implications. Their attacks result in all workers being disadvantaged by the policies and decisions made by this government. This, unfortunately, is the only vehicle that Minister Reith has to bolster his public profile and fuel leadership pretensions. So what the rest of us get is a stage performance of Montague and Capulet in Romeo and Juliet. The only things missing are the swords, and the Australian workers are caught in the middle, with their award conditions being slashed and burned.

The government's consistent ideological attacks on members of the opposition about unions are an absolute joke. We are from diverse and more representative backgrounds than this government's reserve grade frontbench. We are proud of our union history and standing up for the rights of workers. Unlike the government, we represent the interests of ordinary Australians. Our bosses are the people of Australia.

The government have been in power now for about three years, with a dismal record of cutting programs, attacking workers and scapegoating the unemployed or anyone else who gets in their road. They have tried to introduce nursing home fees, persecuting old people and making sure that almost all Australians are far from being comfortable and relaxed.

The policies and attitudes of the government frontbench are like reruns of Gilligan's Island. The story never changes and they never get off the island, but unlike Gilligan's Island, the characters are running around with balaclavas, Rottweilers and a `sack the workers' attitude. They still have no new ideas, they still have no new approach and they still will not do anything to fix the problems of the unemployed. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI thank the member for Batman for delivering me the opportunity to speak on this MPI. Frankly, I was absolutely stunned that the opposition would choose to speak on this issue. It is absolutely unbelievable, with their record on unemployment, that they would choose to attack the government on unemployment.

speech.para: The first speaker, the member for Batman, in delivering an MPI on unemployment, gave us a five-minute dissertation on the biography of the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. He had nothing to say. He went on to talk about bipartisanship. To me, bipartisanship requires something given from both sides. There is nothing coming from the other side. Bipartisanship means two people contributing. As far as I can tell, there are contributions coming from only one side of this parliament.

One of the most amazing things that comes from the other side is the way that they consistently knock. The member for Batman knocked Mr Reith's statement about people making profits and owning private capital. What the hell is wrong with making profits? Where do you get wages from? How do you pay workers if you do not make a profit? If we knock everybody who makes a profit and invests in private capital, what jobs will you have? Zero. It is ludicrous to spend time knocking people who make profits.

In no way am Iâor, I am sure, anyone in the governmentâdenying that more and more creative solutions need to be applied to this difficult problem. I am afraid that I do not have any magic answers. The opposition would lead you to think that they have magic answers. I do not think that they do, either. The reason I was so amazed that the opposition would propose an MPI on this matter is that it shows they have learnt nothing in opposition. They have not learnt that it is simply unsustainable to pour money, without any thought, into welfare and work programs. What happens when you do that? You get a $10 billion deficit. You spend more than you have got. You get record inflation and record high interest rates.

What happens when you have these parameters? You get small businesses closing down, you get larger businesses downsizing and you get record high interest rates. What happens when you need to increase employment? You need small businesses opening up, you need large businesses upsizing and you need people investing in new projects.

I am no economist, but I am amazed at the questions asked by the opposition during question time about the effect of the new tax system on employment. If there is clear evidence that the GDP is going to increase substantially, doesn't this mean that we are producing more? If we are producing more, doesn't that mean that somebody has to produce it? Doesn't this mean that people are working in new jobs?

I make no apology for saying that we have to cost welfare and work programs. I also do not apologise for saying that there are some places where we need to spend money on capital input for some Work for the Dole schemes. But you cannot just spend, spend, spend, for the reasons I have outlined. The Job Network in my electorate is a resounding success in most places. Where there are jobs to be had, they are filling them far better than the CES did. Where there are no jobs and no prospects of jobsâand there are some areas in my electorate that do have that problemâ we must be prepared to invest a little more to achieve better outcomes than just Work for the Dole.

The government recognises that the current situation is not yet quite right. It was a huge culture shift for Australians to embrace the Job Network and I am amazed that it has been accepted so readily. It shows that Australians are prepared to embrace change where there is a long-term gain if perhaps a little short-term pain. Perhaps all Australians embrace this except for the Labor Party. It seems, though, that it is not all of the Labor Party. It seems that there is a fairly high degree of understanding of the real world amongst their ranks. I was heartened to hear the member for Canning last night at least speaking from a small business perspective. I disagree entirely with her logic, but at least there is someone over there who has some concept of what it is like to employ someone. Perhaps she might indicate to the leaders whether her business would employ a 16-year-old school leaver instead of a much more mature, settled and experienced 35-year-old, if she had to pay them the same amount.

It is preposterous to suggest that abolishing youth wage rates will not impact on unemployment. Where do you guys come from? Where do you get your understanding of the real world from? Have you ever employed and trained someone? Paid their wages, their super, their workers comp? I have enjoyed working with my young employees over the years. I have seen them fall asleep at the front counter on a Saturday morning after a late night. I have helped them bend over the sink out the back and I have tried to get them to keep something down when they have had an enormous hangover. They were great days, but I assure you that they were more frequent with the young team than the more mature workers. These were great days, but you cannot afford to pay these guys the same as you pay someone who is more productiveâwho has a stronger grip on life and more responsibility.

When I finished my pharmacy degree I was about 22. Even at that age, and having a degree from university, I started on a wage of $8,000 and progressed from there. I recog nised that I was not as useful to my boss as I would be in the future.

The concept of mutual obligation is one area that will lead to more jobs and more employable young people. The Work for the Dole scheme, as the previous speaker from the government said, has led to 30 per cent or 40 per cent of these people going on to paid work or further education and training. We have allowed successive generations of people to come to expect that they can collect money without making any effort on their part. There is a group of Aboriginals up in the northern part of Queensland who call this `sit down money' and refuse to take it. This attitude itself contributes to the unemployment problem because we have allowed people to become unemployable. Projects such as Green Corps and the literacy and numeracy training prepare these people for the work force.

I hear the argument that their self-esteem has been battered, why subject them to more trauma? This is a valid point. The last thing any of us would want to do is belittle someone who is struggling to read or write. However, aren't we doing them more harm by dooming them to a life of unemployment? Wouldn't giving them the ability to be able to check their change in a shop, read a street sign or fill in a job application form be a better way to try to help them obtain employment?

If we continue down this track, it means we are striving for mediocrity not excellence. Adult life is full of striving and failing and learning what we are good at. Everybody has talents but if we do not challenge ourselves we may never learn what our talents are. Let us recognise that the system has let some Australians down and try to make it up to them. Let's not take the easy way out and say `near enough is good enough'. We owe it to these people to give it a try. We owe it to them to share the feeling of battling through and achieving something worthwhile.
There should not be losers with this literacy and numeracy scheme. There will be many who come out at the other end with a great skill. There will be some who have given it a shot and that is all.

We talk about unfair dismissal. Labor again refuses to admit that the unfair dismissal laws will have no impact on employment. They have no idea of the intrigues facing small business. They assume that all small business owners are ogres and all employees are angels. Most small business owners are people too. Most of them have a cooperative and mutually trusting relationship with their employees. If they cannot employ someone who will not steal, if they cannot employ someone they feel comfortable working with every day, who can they employ and why should they employ them? There is nothing worse, as an employer, than not looking forward to going to work every day because there is someone who is in your place of work with whom you do not get on, who hassles customers, who is obnoxious. Yet the owner of the small business has to go in and front that day after day and is able to do nothing about it.
The Federal union partyâ

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the amendments to the Civil Aviation Regulations, as contained in the Statutory Rules 1998, No. 234, made under the Civil Aviation Act 1988, be disallowed.

These amendments represent the first step in the Howard government's plans to privatise air traffic control services and firefighting services at certain airports. The problem with this is that no-one knows exactly what those plans areânot the air traffic controllers, whose jobs and futures may be at stake; not the aviation industry; not the travelling public; and certainly, and most importantly in matters of public accountability, not this parliament.

When it comes to air safety, in this country at the moment we simply do not have sufficient transparency and openness in decision making. Nevertheless, the government are asking us to sign off today on something for which they give us an assurance that the plans are well under way but the government have not made a decision yet. What we do know is that the government have asked CASA to develop standards for potential private provid ers. We know that the government have carried out a structural review of Airservices Australia, in which they look at how they will go about what they like to call `alternative sources of supply in air traffic control'. We know that they expect more than 1,000 jobs to be lost as part of the process. We also know that the government do not plan to publicly release the report of that structural review. We have no information on how the government plan to guarantee safety, price and standards of privatised air traffic control services. I do not think it is enough for the minister to say, as he did at the National Press Club a couple of hours ago, `Don't worry'; that he can tell you that these things are guaranteed.

I do not think the privatisation debate has been won in this country. I think Australians are still, rightly, very sceptical of all the promises of what privatisation will provide and measure it against the evidence. Consequently, we have a lot of euphemisms flying around. We have `alternative sources of supply for private providers'; we have `introducing competition'; andâI like this oneâwe have `making tower services contestable'. We are probably going to have two airport control towers contesting each other to see who can get the business.

At the Senate estimates hearing last week, Mr Dick Smith told us that he did not call it `privatisation'; he called it `local ownership'. At those same hearings, Mr Bill Pollard, the Chief Executive Officer of Airservices Australia, made a very quaint observation. He said, `Look, when you say "privatised", to a lot of people that means different things.' You can make a survey of what has gone on around the world in different stages of privatisation: usually it means job losses; usually it means higher costs; usually it means lower levels of service, especially in the early years; and usually it means that standards are compromised because governments wanting to sell off public entities are worried that they will scare off potential buyers if they ask them to give too many guarantees, which will cost them money.

There is a very important question here, about why we are being asked to allow these regulations to go through today, when the minister told the National Press Club that a final decision has not been made, and when we do not know the details of what the government is asking us to sign up to. We are being asked, yet again, to give some kind of blank cheque.

We have had the lessons in this country. If you want a lesson in how to privatise by stealth, do what these amendments are doing. Step No. 1, you redefine. These regulations redefine air traffic service as including Airservices Australia or `a person providing air traffic services in cooperation with' Airservices Australia or `a person providing air traffic services under an arrangement with' Airservices Australia. In effect, these little or's, and their additions, ultimately require pilots to take instructions from someone other than Airservices Australia, and that paves the way for air traffic control services in this country to be provided by a private corporation.

We have the government saying to us, `Just sign off on this pretty significant, open-ended proposition, and we'll get around to filling in all the details and telling them to you in our own good time.' You have got the timing the wrong way round, Minister. We have to have the details first and then we will seriously consider them. But please do not ask us to vote on them today, taking in trust the minister's words, `Don't worry, we'll look after all the guarantees'. That is a failure of accountability. It is treating parliament with a certain amount of contempt.

The government has failed to address some serious concerns in a lot of key areas. The most serious is the question of guaranteeing aviation safety. Australians take our reputation for aviation safety very seriously indeed. We are told that CASA is drawing up licensing and operating standards for private providers of air traffic control services. Again, we have no knowledge of the details of those standards. Quite frankly, I find it very hard to believe that anyone in the coalition seriously believes that there is absolutely no safety risk at all in handing over air traffic control services to private operators who, by the very nature of being private, need to be motivated primarily to make money out of their operations. They are not in it through a sense of public responsibility.

The other issue that you have not adequately assured us about is cost. We are told that costs will go down, but we have not seen any evidence to that effect. We do not know if there will be a price cap mechanism. We do not know if there will be a prices surveillance regime. What we have on the record for comparison is that airport owners around this countryâand these are the people who, in some instances, are in line to take over air traffic control servicesâare already coming under fire for attempting to get around existing price cap mechanisms on aeronautical charges. You have put in place a process which you say will deliver some of these guarantees on prices, and already this one example of the process is breaking down. I do not think it is surprising that we say to you, `How can we have any confidence that the same thing will not happen with prices with respect to air traffic control services?'

We also do not know about the effect of these regulations and this step towards privatisation of regional airports where air traffic control services cannot be run at a profit. Mr Pollard admitted last week that Airservices Australia was making a loss at regional and general aviation airports. He said, `The only reason it is not showing up in our bottom line is because of the government subsidy.' That is important, but we do not know whether that subsidy is going to continue if Airservices Australia no longer provides the services. We do not know whether loss-making towers may end up being closed, and we do not know whether or not these changes may exacerbate the pressure that already exists on smaller regional airports and regional operators that are already battling to maintain services.

Finally, there is the very fundamental question of public responsibility and accountability, and the role of government. Labor is saying in no uncertain terms that this issue is not primarily an issue of service provision. This is an issue of public safety and public responsibility. This is a government responsibility. This is a core role-of- government responsibility to protect our reputation in international eyes and in domestic eyes for the very highest level of aviation safety. It is a responsibility of government, and it should remain a responsibility of government because it has to be motivated by the need to protect public safety, not by the need to make a profit.

It is not about competition. It is not about air traffic control towers being duplicated at airports. It should not be about airlines and private pilots choosing to fly to one airport over another because its air traffic control services are cheaper. There might be some competition to provide services in the first place to see who gets the right to do it but, once that is done, we will yet again in this country simply be trading a publicly provided service for a private monopoly. And we will be doing that with no guarantee that safety will not be compromised, no guarantee on costs, no guarantee that the services themselves will be maintained at their current level, and no guarantee about the public's capacity to control, direct and scrutinise these services through their members of parliament.

In conclusion, Labor believes that accountability and safety will be compromised by allowing these regulations changes to go ahead. We are not prepared to give the government the right, albeit a slightly disguised one, to take this very first step down the path to privatisation in this fundamental area of government responsibility.

talk.start.para: âIs the motion seconded?

âI second the motion. Open and accountable government means that government must get close to the people. People are sick and tired of the top-down approach of authorities. They want a bottom-up approach where policy comes from the community and not just from experts or elites. There is a serious question in these regulations guaranteeing aviation safety. I find it hard to believe that anyone in the coalition seriously believes that there is absolutely no safety risk at all in handing over air traffic control services to private operators.

speech.para: We have another example of this elite approach with the approval of the Brisbane airport master plan by the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. The community has been excluded and its views have been ridiculed. Nobody in my community doubts the importance of the airport to Brisbane's economic future, nor do they expect to be excluded or held hostage to a development proposal whose fundamental details have been deliberately hidden from them.

The impact of the current proposal cannot be assessed because the flight paths have not been published. Simultaneously, we have proposals for privatisation of flight control. Not providing the flight paths is like announcing a new freeway without identifying the on and off ramps and the arterial roads that feed the freeway. These flight paths exist and have been deliberately withheld. I believe there must be a comprehensive cost-benefit analysis of all possible options, including a second airport for south-east Queensland, covering the economic, social, environmental and public health impacts.

At the end of that process, we may or may not end up with a parallel runway after a comprehensive analysis, but essential information has been withheld and thus it is not possible to make a sensible and rational judgment now. As it stands, the master plan leaves the community in the dark. In a document of some 240 pages, only three pages superficially examine the options. The whole document was rigged so that only one conclusion could be reached: that is, a new parallel runway located 2.1 kilometres west of the existing runway. In his statement of approval, the transport minister claims that the master plan does not set in concrete a parallel runway. This is wrong. His Airports Act 1996, at section 95(5), says:
. . . if the final master plan is in force for the airport the minister must not approve a draft major development plan unless it is consistent with the final master plan.

Many suburbs in north-east Brisbane, as well as southern suburbs, will be affected by this parallel runway. Late in 1996, Airservices Australia announced new flight paths over the north-eastern suburbs. These changes were supported by the then Liberal member. They concentrated an extra 45 northern departures a day over the suburbs of Gordon Park, Kedron, Wavell Heights and Boondall. This traffic must increase with the new runway, as well as traffic arriving from the north over the suburbs of Aspley, Chermside, Kedron, Gordon Park, Wooloowin, Clayfield, Ascot, Albion, Hamilton and Hendra. The location of a new runway close to Shorncliffe, Deagon, Banyo, Nudgee Beach, Northgate, Nundah and Hamilton continues this policy of noise concentration in the north-eastern suburbs.

Mr Swan interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! The minister and the honourable member for Lilley will cease interjecting across the table. The honourable member for Griffith will continue.
âThank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I quote from the minister's response to a question from the member for Dickson on 12 November 1998 when he said:

speech.para: We have agreed to consider introducing competition into some aspects of Air Service's tower business. This will not occur until the Civil Aviation Safety Authority has developed appropriate operating and licensing standards . . . In terms of the question, the action that we have taken accords with a number of firm expressions of interest that the government has received from new airport lessees seeking to make tower services contestable.

In other words, what we have here is the first step towards de facto privatisation of air traffic control services. Why? Because pressure has been brought to bear on the government from private concerns who are now lessees of various airport properties around the country in order to get a slice of the action. This is deleterious to the public interest; it is deleterious to the national interest.

This comes to a core question addressed by the member for Dickson which relates to what are in fact the fundamental responsibilities of government, responsibilities which go to the heart of police powers, which go to the responsibilities of the armed services, the fire services and the ambulance services. Are we next going to see contracting out of things like the strategic and international policy division of the Department of Defence? Are we going to contract out the Army itself? I understand Sandline are looking for a job. Why do we not get them to take on the responsibilities of the Australian Defence Force because it might be cheaper? The bottom line is that this is an abdication of responsibility.

There are at least four critical reasons why this particular motion is called for and why the privatisation of air traffic control services should be rejected. They relate to the points raised by the member for Dickson concerning safety. They relate to the question concerning provision of service across regional Australia. They relate to the question of the cost of the provision of these services to those who need them in regional centres.

It also relates to the question raised by the member for Lilley about the adequacy of these new air traffic control services concerning the monitoring of noise. Noise goes to the heart of issues right across urban Australia where people are affected by proximate airports. That is what makes this whole issue of airport master plans and their recent considerations so germane to today's debate. That is why, for example, in the Senate today Labor has moved a motion establishing a Senate inquiry which will look into the Brisbane Airport Corporation master plan and the government's handling of that master plan. The inquiry will address whether the Brisbane Airport Corporation has failed to adequately investigate alternative runway options, it will investigate whether the BAC failed to release flight path information to the community and why, and it will also investigate why the minister proceeded to endorse the Brisbane Airport Corporation master plan when he had advice to the contrary from his own department concerning the failure of the Brisbane Airport Corporation to provide indicative flight path information to the community.

That in turn leads to the discussion we had in this place earlier today concerning the matter of the advice provided by the minister's department last yearâwhen he was not the ministerâto the Brisbane Airport Corporation saying, `If you are going to proceed with this master plan, provide the community with indicative flight path information.' Why? Because the ANEF system is inadequate, according to the minister's own officials, to provide local communities with sufficient information about which to make intelligent judgments about how their streets and suburbs are going to be affected by this runway which is under consideration.

This is not in my imagination. I quote from a letter from the First Assistant Secretary, Aviation Operations, of the minister's own department, Mr Paul Merner, where, referring to the 1995 Senate report on aircraft noise in SydneyâFalling on Deaf Earsâhe advised the Chief Executive of the Brisbane Airport Corporation:
. . . the ANEF system may be adequate for land use planning purposes, but it is not adequate for assessing the impact of changes and noise exposure.

He went on to say that when the master plan was released to the community, in the interests of informing the local community, information on such things as indicative flight paths should also be provided.

That was advice provided by the minister's own department to the Brisbane Airport Corporation prior to the release of that master plan. Yet what we had last Friday was the minister in question endorsing that master plan when the Brisbane Airport Corporation has said to the community of Brisbane, and indeed to the entire regulatory framework and structure available to the minister, `We don't give a damn about what your official says.' I think that is a complete dereliction of responsibility on the part of the minister because his own officials had provided contrary advice to the Brisbane Airport Corporation about how they conduct themselves.

A Senate inquiry has now unfortunately become necessary because these matters have not been handled properly either by the Brisbane Airport Corporation or by the minister's handling of this matter when it has been put to him through the Brisbane airport master plan, which he endorsed last Friday.

These are all relevant matters when we consider the whole question of the role of government as a regulator, as a custodian of the public interest and as a body which should have a central and continuing engagement in something as critical as the provision of air traffic control towers across the various airports of the Commonwealth.

talk.start.para: âThe first comment that I would make is that I find it absolutely extraordinary that those opposite can say that this is an example of how to privatise by stealth. This from people who, a matter of just a decade ago, were headed up by a Prime Minister who said, `All privatisation is abhorrent and absolutely frightful,' and then showed us the absolute textbook model of how to introduce something by stealth when they got into a bit of financial trouble with such little exerciseâ
âNot me. I didn't do it.
âOh! Not you, no!

speech.para: Ms Kernot interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âLabor says they are not going to do it anymore! That is exactly what they said about the Commonwealth Bank. That is exactly what they said when they privatised the first part of the Commonwealth Bank, `We're not going to do it anymore. Trust us.' Good grief! The transparency of it! The absolute transparency of it! The shadow minister might also contemplate that, in these mattersâand I will come to it in a momentâtheir own act allowed for the contracting out, which, effectively, is what we are now arguing for.
âWe don't like it!
âYou don't like it? You've shifted position! I see!

speech.para: Ms Kernot interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âBut you have shifted from your own position?

speech.para: Ms Kernot interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSo, on privatisation, you would not do again what you did with the Commonwealth Bank?
âI am speaking about my portfolio.

âYou said a moment ago that you would not privatise that way again. In relation to this matter, you are saying now, as I understand it, that you would again intervene in matters of aviation safety when your own policy and your own act when you were in government made it impossible for you to do soâthat in this instance you would also repeal this part of the act. But really, we may as well carry this right through. If we are saying that the private sector is never able to look after safety, it would be logical that the government should take over the manufacturing and distribution of 747s because we could not have one of these dreadful private sector companies building them.
âI didn't say that. I said governmentsâ
âNo, but you might as well. That is a logical extent of your position, which is that only governments can ever act responsibly in relation to safety.

speech.para: In all seriousness, let me come to the matter before us, which is something that those opposite did not do. The regulation in question amends the current definition of air traffic service, which is limited to Airservices Australia in its capacity as provider of air services. Under this new regulation, this would be expanded to include other organisations in cooperation with or under an arrangement with Airservices Australia.

There seems to be a fundamental misunderstanding about the intention of the amendment of this regulation. Let me state quite categorically that this is not about the privatisation of Airservices Australia or any of its activities. This misunderstanding seems to be, largely, the result of material distributed by Civilair, which is the union representing the air traffic controllers. Nor is this a question of safety. Under the proposed amendments, Airservices will retain control of the service provider and will continueâI stress, continueâto apply current safety standards.
Ms Kernot interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThe question, with all the bleeding heart remarks about services in rural Australia, is one of providing tower services at regional airports at reasonable cost. The amendment would permit organisationsâ
âOh! Affordable safety!

âWe will come to that in a moment. The fact of the matter is that the courts have placed certain obligations on us which will, if they are not handled very carefully, result in more expensive services to country areas when that may not be neces sary. This amendment would permit organisations other than Airservices to provide air traffic services under contract.

speech.para: This means that, while Airservices maintains a regulatory responsibility of providing air traffic control tower services, somebody with better flexibility in their cost structure than Airservices, or with lower overheads or with the ability to operate different hours, would provide air traffic control services at an individual tower. But I repeat that the act will still require that the standard of provision of these services would be that of Airservices itself.

Following a recent full Federal Court judgment, the subsidy provided previously by major capital city airports which went towards covering costs at regional airports and general aviation facilities cannot continue. While an appeal to the High Court is planned, the price restructuring will inevitably need to reflect the costs of each of the locations where the towers operate. It is worth remembering that the previous Labor government explicitly recognised the possibility that Airservices would contract out air traffic services.
Ms Kernot interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âWe have just heard there has been a change of policy.
âI said: I'm running this portfolio.
âSo there is a change of Labor Party policy?
âI am in charge of this portfolio.
âAnd you would change the act in government?

speech.para: Ms Kernot interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSo you would change your own act. Mr Deputy Speaker, it is worth remembering that, when your party was in power, you explicitly recognised the possibility that Airservices would contract out air traffic services. I wonder whether you knew your new star recruit was going to be an overarching regulationist of the sort that once stifled this country. That appears to be what you have got.

speech.para: The act allows Airservices to provide air traffic services itself, in cooperation with another organisation, or by arranging another organisation to provide the services on its behalf. In entering into any arrangements with any other organisation, Airservices would still be bound by the requirement in the act for Airservices to regard the safety of air navigation as the most important consideration in exercising its powers and performing its functions.

In the short term, these regulations will enable owners and operators of airports to use organisations other than Airservices to provide air traffic services. This would allow airports to address the costs of their control towers, which the industry has subsidised for many years and which the government is currently subsidising heavily in an $11 million annual budget contribution.

It is important to understand that the number of organisations with the expertise to provide these services is very limited. They are highly qualified and experienced and are certainly not fly-by-night operators. The main options would be SERCOâan organisation with experience in providing these services in the United Kingdomâand any Airservices air traffic controllers presently providing these services at an airport, who choose to form a corporation for this purpose. Beware, lest your own supporters are amongst those who would like to make alternative arrangements for providing the services they are currently engaged in.
Ms Kernot interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThere are also flow-on benefits if the opportunity for alternative service providers is open. CIRCO intends to use the option available under these regulations to set up an international training centre in Australiaâsomething I would have thought you would have liked to have seen. If these regulations are disallowed, this opportunity for new business in Australia will almost certainly be lost.
âHow many jobs will be lost on the way through? At least 1,000.

âThat's an almost laughable suggestion. We are talking about a very isolated number of towers in the first instance. It may well be that local communities will decide to close the towers anyway if you move this amendment and force on them unacceptable price structures. To fully understand the implications of disallowing this regulation, consideration needs to be given to the current situation at the general aviation and smaller regional airports. It is vital that we understand which airports are most affected by any decision to allow these regulations, but currently subsidised airports are either capital city general aviation centres, which are major centres for small aviation businesses, or the Tasmanian airports or the regional airports in rural New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland.

speech.para: Airservices has introduced charges for its services, including tower services in regional areas, which are based on the costs it incurs at each location. The Federal Court has ruled that Airservices must take this approach. Without the subsidy or changes to the cost structure at the individual towers, there would need to be huge increases in charges to pay for tower services; for example, charges at Tamworth airport would have to increase, horrifyingly, from $6.75 a tonne to $38.22 a tonne.

In contrast, the government's approach offers significant savings for Australia's aviation industry and for rural and regional communities. Already CIRCO has indicated that it can provide as effective a service at a price significantly lower than that presently charged by Airservices at a number of locations, including Launceston in Tasmania. New airport operators have approached the government seeking to open up this option. They know that this is a process that has for many years operated successfully overseas, for example, by the FAA in the United States.
Ms Kernot interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âWe keep hearing from those people who keep implying, the shadow minister at the table, that we do not have as good a safety record as the Americans.
âI never said that.
âWell, you are constantly casting aspersions on our safety record.
âOrder! The honourable member for Dickson will cease interjecting. The minister will direct his remarks through the chair.
âMr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The minister is supposed to be talking about the regulations, not about the member for Dickson.
âThe honourable member for Lilley will resume his seat. The minister will remain relevant to the motion before us.

âMr Deputy Speaker, I will not comment any more, but I really think that that was a frivolous interjection given the absolute irrelevancy of what the member for Lilley had to say in this debate. The contrast serves only to condemn him for his flippant and very opportunistic approach to this debate.

speech.para: In conclusion, these regulations will not affect safety at regional airports. They will ensure that charges can be maintained at affordable levels.

talk.start.para: âHow can you say that?

âI cannot help responding to these interjections. This is the mob that gave the ultimate guarantee on tax cuts for the Australian people, l-a-w law, and did not deliver them. What is a guarantee from the ALP worth?
âThe minister will resume his seat.
âI raise a point of order. Mr Deputy Speaker, will you bring the minister back to the regulations, please?
âThe chair would be assisted if the level of interjections was reduced. That would enable the minister to make his remarks through the chair.
âThe fact of the matter is that Labor's approach will increase the cost of air travel for Australians who live in rural and regional Australia. I commend the regulations to the House.

talker.name: Tuckey, Wilson, MP
Mr TUCKEY

speech.para: Ms Kernot interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âAnd we are running the House.

speech.para: Ms Kernot interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âYou did make a comment about this. In the current operations of air safety, the most significant factor is of course the viability of an aircraft, its mechanical status. talk.start.para: âOn behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the first, second and third reports of the committee for 1999 relating to CSIRO Queensland Centre for Advanced Technologies stage 2 development, Pinjarra Hills, Queensland; CSIRO National Centre for Petroleum and Mineral Resources Research, Bentley, WA; and Lavarack Barracks redevelopment stage 2, Townsville, Queensland.

speech.para: Ordered that the reports be printed.

talk.start.para: âThe reports which I have just tabled deal with proposals referred to the committee in the previous parliament. The previous committee was unable to report on them due to the intervening election. The present committee considered the evidence assembled by the previous committee and resolved, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act, that further public hearings on the proposed works were not necessary.

speech.para: The total cost of the public works covered in the reports is close to $200 million.

The first report involves the proposed construction of the CSIRO Queensland Centre for Advanced Technologies Stage 2 development at Pinjarra Hills in Queensland. The estimated out-turn cost of the proposal when referred to the committee was $22.3 million. The committee has recommended that the works should proceed.

By way of background, the Queensland Centre for Advanced Technologies was established by an agreement between the Queensland government and the CSIRO to expand and diversify research and development in the mining, energy and related manufacturing industries in Queensland and nationally. The centre brings together resources from the state government, universities, CSIRO divisions and Queensland and Australia wide minerals, energy and manufacturing industries in collaborative activities.

The proposal examined by the committee includes the construction of a research building, a technology transfer building, a number of new industrial type buildings, extensions to existing buildings such as the library and canteen, and site works, including new roads, car parking and environmental rehabilitation.

The centre was originally designed to cater for research and development projects involving 130 staff.
