Since the centre was established, research activities have grown at a rapid rate and existing facilities will be inadequate to support planned increases in research personnel and projects. As a consequence, the committee has concluded that there is a need to provide additional facilities at the centre to house and support planned increases in personnel and research projects.

The committee found that master planning studies of the site, undertaken by the CSIRO, have identified areas suitable for further expansion well into the next century. Based on the evidence, the committee also concluded that the extent of the proposed works will provide for the planned expansion of research and development projects and provide capabilities expected to stimulate their further expansion.

The second report which I have tabled involves the construction of another national centre for the CSIRO. This one will be located in the Perth suburb of Bentley and will be known as the CSIRO National Centre for Petroleum and Mineral Resources Research. The Bentley Centre will provide a focal point for research excellence and collaboration between CSIRO, Cooperative Research Centres, university researchers, government agencies, resource companies and associated technology suppliers and providers.

The proposal examined by the committee involves the construction of laboratories and research facilities, process bays, support and stores areas, staff amenities, public facilities, associated site works, roadworks, car parking, engineering and communication services and landscaping.
When referred to the committee, the estimated out-turn cost of the proposed work was $31.8 million. The committee has recommended that the work proceed as proposed.

By way of background I should mention that the CSIRO, or its predecessor organisations, has had a presence in Western Australia spanning more than 80 years. It now employs more than 400 staff at six locations in the state.

The proposed work is a recognition of the fact that the mining, oil and gas industries are the mainstay of the Western Australian economy. For this reason, CSIRO and the Western Australian government have identified the need to increase substantially the state's research capability to support the sustained development of resource industries in an era of heightened international competitiveness. The CSIRO divisions involved in the mining, oil and gas industries have established research teams and formed alliances with other research and development partners to undertake projects in Western Australia and nationally.

Based on the evidence, the committee has concluded thatreturns to the community and resource companies from investment in research and technology transfer can be significant and are highly influential in the creation of new investment and employment. The committee also concluded that the extent of the proposed work can be justified as providing modern facilities designed to enable CSIRO divisions and alliance partners to undertake research into minerals and petroleum research at increased levels and will overcome current unsatisfactory conditions.

Two other significant factors also emerged from the committee's inquiry. Firstly, collocation of two key CSIRO divisions, Exploration and Mining and Petroleum Resources, will deliver cost savings and will maximise research effort in support of both oil and mining industry sectors. Secondly, the proposed site for the centre, adjacent to Curtin University of Technology and within Technology Park, Bentley, will provide the capability to foster collaborative research between the university and private sector research and development organisations. CSIRO has developed a master plan for the site which makes provision for further expansion of facilities and staff.

The third report which I have tabled involves the second stage of the redevelopment of Lavarack Barracks in Townsville. There are nine major components in the proposed works. These comprise accommodation and messing, operational, logistic support and infrastructure development facilities. The main component consists of new living-in accommodation for 1,112 officers, senior non-commissioned officers and other ranks, associated mess complexes and a central food preparation facility.
When referred to the committee, the estimated out-turn cost of the proposed work was $139.3 million. The committee has recommended that the works proceed as proposed.
The committee has concluded that the provision of new airconditioned living-in accommodation should improve living standards for on-base personnel and should lift the morale of personnel.

Similarly, the committee established that there is a need for new messes, on a scale commensurate with requirements identified in Department of Defence planning studies, to be provided at Lavarack Barracks adjacent to the sites proposed for new living-in accommodation. The committee believes there are uncertainties about the appropriateness of the cook-chill method of food preparation, based on its untested nature in the Australian Defence Force. For this reason, the committee recommended that the Department of Defence should report back to the committee on the operation of the cook-chill process after it has been fully tested at Lavarack Barracks, before its wider implementation within the Australian Defence Force.

The report concludes that the remainder of the works, namely, a new communications centre, new transport facilities, the eastern deployment and assembly area, new heavy vehicle roads and waste collection facilities, will all provide substantial improvements to the functionality and environmental management of this, one of the Army's largest bases.

I would like to take the opportunity in conclusion to thank the former chair, the Hon. Wilson Tuckey, and the past committee in the last parliament for the work they did in preparation for the presentation of this report. I commend the reports to the House.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: CSIRO Queensland Centre for Advanced Technologies stage 2 development, Pinjarra Hills, Queensland.

As we have heard, the Queensland Centre for Advanced Technologies, located at Pinjarra Hills, Queensland, was established by an agreement between the Queensland government and the CSIRO with the objective of developing a world centre of excellence to expand and diversify research and development in the mining, energy and related manufacturing industries in the state and the coun try as a whole. The centre aims to bring together resources from the state government, universities, kindred CSIRO divisions and Queensland and Australia wide minerals, energy and manufacturing industries in collaborative activities.

Currently, the occupancy across the whole complex greatly exceeds the original planned complement and has led to an acute shortage of space and a demand for additional facilities. New initiatives and increased interest from commercial collaborators will further exacerbate the accommodation problems in the foreseeable future. In order to redress these accommodation problems, the CSIRO proposes a building development program which will significantly expand the existing facilities and in addition permit rationalisation of some of the existing resources.

The proposed development comprises a research building housing lightly serviced laboratories, offices and open work areas; a technology transfer building providing office style accommodation for a number of independent rental suites; a number of new industrial type buildings; expansion of the existing library and canteen facilities; minor alterations to existing buildings to suit change of function; site works, including new roads, car parking, environmental rehabilitation and extension and modifications to site services; and relocation and modification of the existing sewage treatment plant.

The estimated turnout cost is $22.3 million. It is anticipated that construction will commence in early 1999 and be completed by mid-2000. The Public Works Committee, in its report tabled today, as we have heard, recommended that this project proceed. The CSIRO agrees with the committee's recommendations, and I am very happy to commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: CSIRO National Centre for Petroleum and Mineral Resources Research, Bentley, WA.

The National Centre for Petroleum and Mineral Resources Research is being established by the Western Australian government and the CSIRO to substantially increase Western Australia's technological capacity and its capability to support the sustained development of its resource industries. Located at Technology Park, Bentley, the national centre will provide a focal point for research excellence and collaboration among the CSIRO, cooperative research centres, university researchers, government agencies, resource companies and associated technology suppliers and providers.

The national centre will provide a unique opportunity to bring together world-class scientific and engineering research groups to work closely with the petroleum and minerals industries. Collaborative research will embrace a wide range of activities aimed not only at providing solutions to current industry issues but also at providing the research leadership necessary to redress the key research needs and research issues of these industries now and in the decades ahead. The concentration of capability and expertise at the national centre will also provide a major incentive for leading edge companies and organisations to locate their operations in Western Australia, further enhancing the prospects for research collaboration and technology transfer and the delivery of innovative research solutions, services and products to the petroleum and minerals industries.

The centre represents a marriage of the leading edge research in minerals and petroleum exploration and production within the industry sector. The proposed development will include laboratories and research facilities, process bays, support and stores areas, staff amenities and public facilities, and associated site works, roadworks, car parking, engineering and communications services and landscaping.

The estimated turnout cost is $31.8 million. It is anticipated that construction will commence in early to mid-1999 and will be completed by late 2000. The Public Works Committee, in its report tabled today, recommended that this project proceed. The CSIRO agrees with the committee's recommendations, and I am pleased to commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Lavarack Barracks redevelopment stage 2, Townsville, Queensland.

The Department of Defence proposes to redevelop Lavarack Barracks. The works now proposed are needed to overcome acute accommodation inadequacies, to improve efficiency and operational effectiveness, and to provide a sound infrastructure framework on which further development of the barracks can proceed.

The works are in nine main components, consisting of accommodation and messing, operational and logistical support, and infrastructure development facilities. The main components comprise new living-in accommodation for 1,112 officers, senior non-commissioned officers and other ranks; associated mess complexes and a central food preparation facility. The estimated turn-out cost of the proposal is $139.3 million. Subject to parliamentary approval, construction will commence in September 1999 with the objective of completion by December 2001.

The report of the Public Works Committee, as we have heard a moment ago, has recommended that this project proceed. Defence accepts and will implement the recommendations of the committee. I commend this motion to the House.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI will not detain the House long. I have absolutely no disagreement with the expediency motions, but I am concerned at the process. The chair of the Public works committee commenced speaking in this chamber at about 4.53 this afternoon, in presenting the first report, and finished speaking at almost two minutes past five. To this time these reports were confidential.

speech.para: These are confidential reports and no-one was supposed to have seen them until the chair of the committee presented them to this parliament. Yet, also at two minutes past five, we had the parliamentary secretary standing and moving the first expediency motion and proceeding to move the other two expediency motions and making quite a detailed speech.

I wonder whether the parliamentary secretaryâand I have a great admiration for himâhas powers beyond what most people have, otherwise how could he have known what was in those reports? Perhaps someone could have presented him with a speech to make or he made the speech himself, so I am concerned that due process has not been followed.

The other thing that concerns me is that it was in today's blue that the expediency motions were going to be moved and it was in today's Notice Paper, which I guess was printed last nightâI don't know when it was presented. But I would like to know how those responsible for putting it in the Notice Paper knew what the committee was going to recommend, because with an expediency motion being moved the assumption would be that the committee was going to recommend that the work proceed.

I have no argument whatsoever with the expediency motions and with the works proceeding. These are important works, especially the two CSIRO ones. They are of great significance to Australia. In pre-empting what the member for Herbert is going to say, I have absolutely no criticism of the chair of the committee or indeed of the parliamentary secretary who moved the expediency motions. I assume the member for Herbert is going to follow me. I thought I would perhaps speak after him and I have actually jotted down here, `I share his enthusiasm for the work proceeding at Lavarack Barracks. The redevelopment there is long overdue.'

But I must sayâand I must put it on the public recordâthat someone has been a little bit too clever by half with these expediency motions. We are constantly lectured in this House about the correct forms to follow and about the standards of this House and, quite frankly, the correct forms were not followed. I am amazed that these expediency motions have been moved so quickly and I cannot believe that a prepared speech gave such detail and some of the details that the committee recommended in agreeing with that. As I said, the chair completed the speech at two minutes past five. No-one was supposed to have seen the report by then, yet the parliamentary secretary couldâalso at two minutes past fiveâstand up and make a detailed speech highlighting some of the comments in it.
Mr Nugent interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âPeople might think that this is a joke but we on this side are constantly being lectured about the standards of this House and how they have to be adhered to. I am the last in this place to want to be nigglyâI do not want to delay works at allâbut I do think that, when there are forms, they should be followed. It would have been more appropriate, in my view, if the expediency motions had been moved tomorrow. It would have given the impression, even if it did not necessarily follow, that the reports had been considered over an appropriate time. In 30 seconds you cannot read three detailed reports. I am amazed that the chair can commence a speech at 4.53 p.m. and the parliamentary secretary can have the whole three recommendations through by 10 past five. Surely this would be a record for consideration of parliamentary reportsâhaving them considered and expediency motions movedâwithin the parliament.

âThe member for Throsby quite rightly assumed that I would want to say a few words about the Lavarack Barracks recommendation. The motion refers to Australia's largest army base, and probably its most important army base, because it really is the sharp end of the army in Australia.
âRepresented by one of the best members.

âThanks, Parliamentary Secretary. Lavarack, which houses the 3rd Brigade, is very important to the defence of this country. It contains the Ready Deployment Forceâthe force that responds within 24 hours if there is an emergency anywhere in the world. That force is situated in the electorate of Herbert.

speech.para: Work at Lavarack Barracks is urgently needed. I am pleased to see the recommendation to provide the expenditure to carry out the proposed work. The accommodation provided for the soldiers of the 1st and 2nd battalions is 30 to 35 years old. It is terrible, Mr Deputy Speaker; quite literally, you cannot swing a cat in a soldier's room. The accommodation is tiny and cramped. There are communal facilities and there is no airconditioning, even though it is located in the tropics. It really is bad. I am pleased to see that we are addressing new accommodation arrangements for Lavarack. The officers and men of the 1st and 2nd battalionsâindeed, the whole 3rd Brigadeâwill appreciate this recommendation.

There will also be modern mess facilities and a new internal road transport system. Incidentally, the Lavarack Barracks frontage on University Drive runs for about 4Â½ kilometres. That shows how big it is. So the internal transport arrangements are very important.

This is a $139 million project. It is a massive project for Townsville and for Thuringowa. The flow-on from this investment into the local economy will be most welcome. I certainly hopeâand the army has given me an assuranceâthat where local contractors can be used, the locals will benefit from this investment. I am pleased to see that this is programmed to start as soon as possible this year. I heartily support the motion.

talk.start.para: âAt the outset, I congratulate the member for Herbert on the very strong representations he has made with respect to Lavarack Barracks. He has been an outstanding member. This new facility, which is in the process of construction, is yet another tribute to the excellence of his representation.

speech.para: The honourable member for Throsby was a little precious in his contribution a short while ago. I recall that, last time I spoke in relation to these public works matters, the member for Throsby criticised the government for dragging the chain, for not being expeditious, for, shall we say, not being as prompt as he would have liked. We, of course, rejected the false allegations then made by the member for Throsby. I suppose I should take his few words a moment ago as being a compliment for the very good level of productivity which the Department of Finance and Administration has been able to produce so that we are able to make sure that these very important works and very important expenditures are able to proceed as a matter of great urgency.

We have got the reports; we have accepted the reports. We are proving that we are a government which is absolutely determined to make sure that government spending in these areas happens as soon as it possibly can. I commend this motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Replacement nuclear research reactor, Lucas Heights, NSW.

The Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation intends to construct and operate a replacement research reactor at the Lucas Heights Science and Technology Centre. The new facility will replace the 41-year-old high flux Australian reactor, which is expected to reach the end of its operational life around the year 2005.

ANSTO has engaged in the necessary and appropriate level of public consultation, undertakingâand I stress thisâa full environmental impact statement on this project, which it has submitted pursuant to the provisions of the Commonwealth Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. Consideration by the Public Works Committee is the next step in the acquisition process and is a standard requirement for all significant Commonwealth construction projects.

The replacement research reactor will meet the specific objectives of: maintaining and enhancing health care benefits provided to the Australian community; maintaining Australia's nuclear technical expertise; providing a neutron beam research facility that will meet Australia's scientific and industrial needs and serve as a regional centre of scientific excellence; providing research and research training facilities and programs to enhance the educational opportunities available to Australia's scientists and engineers; providing radioisotopes, for use in industry and environmental applications, and facilities for neutron activation analysis, irradiation of materials, and neutron radiography to service the needs of industry, environmental applications and agriculture; and meeting all health, safety, environmental and quality standards in its construction and operation.
The estimated cost of the facility is $286 million. It is proposed that tenders be called in July 1999 with the objective of completion by the end of the year 2005. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Australian Embassy BerlinâRefurbishment to heritage buildings as a chancery and apartments.

As part of the process of reunification of Germany, the seat of German government is relocating from Bonn to Berlin. Relocation is programmed to be completed in 1999âthis year. The diplomatic corps is also required to move to Berlin as part of that relocation.

In 1995 the government purchased two adjoining heritage buildings in the Mitte district of Berlin following an extensive search for suitable premises and sites. This area is the historic centre of Berlin and is close to public transport, hotels and government departments. The decision to purchase and refurbish these buildings was intended in part to be Australia's contribution towards the rebuilding of East Berlin.

Both buildings are heritage listed and have certain heritage requirements which must be managed in the refurbishment program. These include restoration of the facade to the Wallstrasse building, a number of stairways throughout the buildings and a meeting room used by Wilhelm Piek, who later became president of the former East Germany. The Wallstrasse building will provide six stories of modern office accommodation, representational areas for the embassy and two apartments for Australian staff. The Markisches Ufer building will provide four apartments. Car parking will be provided in the basement to serve both buildings. The estimated turnout cost of refurbishment is $43.57 million. A further $3.83 million is to be spent by occupying agencies for tenant fit-out.

Subject to parliamentary approval, it is expected that demolition works will commence in July 1999 and the project will be completed by December 2000. This project is an important demonstration of Australia's commitment to relations with Germany. It will provide quality accommodation for the Australian embassy in a prominent location. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 3 December, on motion by Mr Williams:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âI rise to make my concluding remarks on this bill. In summary, the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 is very important for our region, the western suburbs of Melbourne. It will be welcomed, I am sure, by the migrant resource centres in the region, the Western Region Disability Network and the many ethnic and other community groups in Gellibrand.

speech.para: Labor supports a system being introduced which ensures enforceable decisions can be made on human rights complaints. But the bill does not go far enough. As I have said, I am concerned about the restrictions and pressure these budget decisions, which were discussed earlier, place on people bringing legitimate complaints and hinder the commission's capacity to do its valuable and much needed work in this fundamental area of discrimination and human rights.
I urge the government to take on board our concerns about the drastic underfunding of HREOC and the cuts to legal aid.

talk.start.para: âIt is a pleasure to speak on the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 . The House would be aware that, as the Chair of the Human Rights Subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I take a great deal of interest in this area. This bill came before the last parliament, but unfortunately before it got all the way through the process we had an election, so it lapsed and therefore has to be presented again.

speech.para: I note that this morning the Attorney-General introduced the new Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1999 , which deals with the renaming of HREOC and other things which we will debate on another occasion.

The Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 is quite a far-reaching bill. It is a very complex bill and very important in terms of what we are proposing to do in respect of HREOC. The bill will amend Commonwealth antidiscrimination legislation to reform the functions and structure of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity CommissionâHREOC as it is known in the trade. The bill also responds to the High Court's decision in the Brandy v. HREOC case in 1995, which found that HREOC, as a non-judicial body, did not have the constitutional power to finally determine disputes. In other words, HREOC had been given some powers to make determinations but when that was challenged in the court it was found that as a non-judicial body it did not have the power to enforce those determinations. To deal with that situation we need to change HREOC's role to one of conciliation and consultation, but the legal process and the enforcement has to be done in the Federal Court.

The bill does a number of things. It confers on the president of HREOC the role and functions of chief executive officer, it centralises the complaint investigation and conciliation procedures in the office of the president, and it simplifies the legislation by implementing, where possible, common definitions and best practice procedural provisions for complaint handling in the one act. It makes substantial changes to the Disability Discrimination Act 1992, the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 and the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 to remove the provisions in those acts which currently deal with complaints.

The bill simplifies dispute resolution procedures in human rights matters by eliminating the second tier of review in HREOC, which was not directly enforceable. It provides that matters that cannot be conciliated will be dealt with in the Federal Court of Australia. It provides that the Federal Court will not be bound by technicalities or legal forms in considering proceedings brought before it under this bill. It enables the judges of the Federal Court to delegate some, but not all, of their functions in this area to judicial registrars, who will be able to assist with additional case loads.

The bill makes provision for transitional arrangements for complaints which have been lodged with HREOC under the old law but which will not have been completed at the commencement of the new lawâthe most significant point being that, where prior to the commencement of the new law a complaint has been referred to HREOC for a substantive hearing which has commenced, the complaint will continue to be dealt with under the old law. All other complaints will be transferred to the scheme established by the new law. The bill also includes consequential amendments to related legislation, including the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976, the Defence Act 1903, the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973, the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Act 1996, and the Workplace Relations Act 1996.

Australia has a long and proud record of achievement in the human rights area. In many ways we have been able to provide an example to the world and we certainly provide, in our structures and in the way we approach human rights, a model for many developing countries. But not all, of course, is perfect. We need to be constantly on the alert to make sure that we are keeping up to date and dealing with new developments and that we do not allow our guard to slip in terms of human rights, because it is a very important basic responsibility of the parliament to its citizens.

The present system, however, is good but it is not carved in stone, and there is from time to time a need to update the legislation. The Brandy case demonstrated that perfectly. This government has done a lot of work in the human rights area both within Australia and overseas. We have, for example, been very active in Indonesia, and the Centre for Democratic Institutions set up by this government has been very active in pursuing human rights in the region.

We have provided, with a secretariat and expertise coming out of HREOC, support to a number of human rights commissions on a regional basis. We have started, for example, regular annual dialogue with China on the subject of human rights. We have produced some outstanding people, such as Sir Ronald Wilsonâwho is a former head of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the deputy chair of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliationâand Chris Sidoti, who is the current commissioner of HREOC. It seems to me that, whilst laws, processes and structures are of course important and necessary, it is the quality of those people and of the country's commitment to human rights that is really of overriding importance.

This legislation effectively does three major things. Firstly, the bill removes the unenforceable commission inquiry stage and provides parties with more direct access to the Federal Court, where they will be able to obtain an enforceable and timely determination of their respective rights. This will address the High Court's decision in the Brandy case, as well as concerns about the cost and time involved in the unenforceable commission inquiry process.

Secondly, the bill consolidates the three complaint handling schemes contained in the race, sex and disability discrimination acts into a single, uniform scheme. The new scheme will simplify the complaint handling process and will incorporate best practice procedural provisions. It will centralise responsibility for complaint handling in the president and will improve the commission's capacity to utilise its resources and deliver services in a more efficient manner. It will also assist in promoting consistent and coordinated practices for all complaints.

Thirdly, the bill clarifies the lines of management responsibility in the commission. The president is to assume responsibilities as the chief executive officer. This is designed to facilitate timely decision making and provide for the better administration of the commission.

Certainly there have been some criticisms of what has been proposed in the bill. The criticism generally is based on such factors as the more formal nature of Federal Court proceedings and exposure to the standard fees and cost regime in the court. The government's response to those criticisms is to say that it should be noted that the existing system, with two unenforceable levels of dispute resolution, is less than satisfactory. Enabling the parties to have direct access to the Federal Court, following reconciliation, has the potential to significantly reduce delays and costs in the current system. In addition, the usual rules for fees currently apply to antidiscrimination complaints in the Federal Court. However, as is currently the case, fees are not payable where a person has a card entitling him or her to Commonwealth health benefits or is receiving legal aid, Austudy or Abstudy, or is a minor or a prisoner or a person who would suffer financial hardship. The bill also contains a number of initiatives designed to reduce formality in Federal Court proceedings, possibly reducing costs and reliance on legal representation.

HREOC has an outstanding record in conciliationâmost complaints do not proceed beyond that particular stageâand it will continue this very effective and successful role. The bill fixes the problems created in the Brandy case concerning enforceability of judgments. Informality in the court proceedings which are in this legislation will ensure that the handling of cases is continued in an effective way.

The restructuring of HREOCâso that the president will assume responsibility for all complaint handling, while the commissioners will have a function to argue the policy imperatives of the legislation before the Federal Courtâmeans a clearer delineation between the conciliation of complaints role of the commission and its advocacy role in promoting the protection of human rights. This is an important piece of legislation. It will move the process along, and I commend it to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Swan) adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 16 February, on motion by Mr Fahey:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âMy comments are in continuation, so anybody listening should excuse the fact that I am starting halfway through the discussion. My office has been inundated with complaints about the Youth Allowance. The social implications of this government policy on young people in my electorate almost outweighs any other issue of importance to young people today. Young people who are currently receiving no youth allowance by virtue of their parents' income are not able to access Jobsearch assistance. Their ability to meaningfully and effectively search for employment is thereby thwarted.

speech.para: The fruitless efforts of many young northern Tasmanians caught up in this situation who receive no support, no encouragement and no practical assistance from the government is resulting in anxiety, distress and, in some cases, is moving young people further and further away from ever gaining employment. These young people are being alienated from the job market based on their inability to access professional job seeking assistance. It costs money to apply for jobs, it costs money to attend interviews, and it takes skills to prepare applications in today's competitive market.

In an increasingly ageing society, the Howard government is, through the Youth Allowance program, attacking the capacity of parents to accrue personal savings to cater for their own retirement needs. The government has an obligation to investigate how incurring additional financial responsibility for their children will impact on and affect parental saving patterns. The intrusive and calculating nature of questions that parents and guardians are required to complete as part of the Youth Allowance application process is disgraceful. The additional form `Family actual means test' needs to be completed when potential applicants have claimed a tax deduction for a business loss. This means that many farming families are therefore required to estimate for the government how much they spend on videos, pet food, birthday gifts and those sorts of things. This is an absolute affront to the privacy rights of Australians.

This mean-spirited move by the Howard government is merely obscuring the real youth unemployment issues in Tasmaniaâwith rates which are already unacceptably high at 39.6 per cent for young people between the ages of 15 and 19. The interesting thing is that complaints are not just coming from young peopleâthey are coming from parents and from families. This government which claims to represent the needs of families has placed unrealistic burdens upon them.
A letter in yesterday's Examiner, my local paper, pretty well sums up the feelings of people in the Tasmanian community. It says:

The 1998 Literacy Survey results reported by the Australian Bureau of Statistics revealed that literacy levels are highest of all among those under 25. Illiteracy is more prevalent among the overs 25s . . .
This means that over the past two decades our schools and their "do-gooder" educators have done a superlative job in producing the most literate generation ever.
Why, therefore, have the young been singled out for compulsory literacy classes?
It is one more example of the vendetta that the Howard Government is pursuing against young adults by imposing discriminatory measures upon them that are not also applied to older Australians.
Exploding tertiary education costs, the forced labour work for the dole scheme and the cruel youth allowance all impact more upon the lives of young adults than older ones, for no justifiable reason.
. . . Our young people did not create this society. A fairer and independent definition might reveal that they are defaulting far less than the . . . government.
This sentiment has been repeated again and again to me in the community.

Young people in Tasmania are doubly disadvantaged, because not only do we have a government that is not interested in young people but we have a government that is not interested in regional development and rural and regional Australia. For all the rhetoric, very little has actually been done, unless you count the removal of about $150 million in regional development funds. The Commonwealth has a vital role to play in regional development. However, that has not been the view of this government. On 17 July 1996, John Sharp said that there was no clear rationale or constitutional basis for Commonwealth involvement in regional development. That is an appalling position for a government to adhere to. We need targeted programs for regional Australiaâparticularly in Tasmania.

Let me focus on a couple of issues for Tasmania at the momentâthe Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme and the Wheat Freight Subsidy Scheme. As Tasmanians knowâand we hope other people realiseâthe most valuable thing we need is for these schemes to be enshrined in legislation so that they do not have to run the gauntlet of the budget process every year. Any changes would then be subject to open debate and not the whim of faceless, nameless Treasury officials.

The Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme goes part of the way to compensate Tasmanian industries for the disadvantages the Bass Strait imposes. By its very nature, the scheme supports thousands of jobs. The situation with the TFES at the moment is one where the minister and senior department officials equivocate about its future funding. We are led to believe that there is a commitment for an additional $15 million in the budget, but we have as yet been unable to secure any guarantees about what is going to come out the other side. This is simply not good enough for Tasmanian businesses.

The situation regarding the Wheat Freight Subsidy Scheme is appalling. This scheme has been in place since 1989 but, as of 30 June this year, it will cease to exist. That will be it. All we have is a yet unconfirmed possibility that there may be some good news in the next budgetâa budget that will be produced only weeks prior to the current scheme concluding. Almost 1,600 jobs in Tasmania are directly and indirectly impacted upon by this subsidyâfrom bread makers to the pork industry, to the stock food industry, to chicken growers, to large companies such as Inghams. Inghams employs 240 people directly and about another 100 indirectly. If this scheme is not continued, we face a very real possibility that we are going to lose those jobs.

The choice will be very simple for business people. They will either choose to ship wheat to Tasmania and process it at the additional cost or produce the final product on the mainland and ship it to Tasmania in containers. Failure to support this scheme will transfer jobs out of Tasmania. The most ludicrous thing about this lack of a decision is that all it will cost is $1.2 millionâthat is, $1.2 million to protect and guarantee employment for up to 1,600 Tasmanians. Tasmania's economic future depends on these subsidies.

Regional Australia has been ill served by this government. Unfortunately, this litany of betrayal of people by the government does not end here. To the despair of the community, it goes on and on. Budget after budget, we get more cuts and more broken promises.

talk.start.para: âThe Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1998-99 and cognate bills are of vital importance to government. It is a shame that the appropriation bill has taken so long to come back for debate in the House. I point out that, if the new member for Bass really cared about issues in regional Australia, as she indicated, then she would urge her opposition colleagues to support our tax package which is currently before the Senate.

speech.para: The tax package which is currently before the Senate benefits regional Australia. I am sure my colleague the honourable member for Corangamite will provide further details on the benefits of the tax package for regional Australia, given that he has always proven himself to be a very dedicated, hard-working representative of the people of Corangamite. On that basis, I urge the members of the Labor Party to continue to support ongoing reform in Australia. They can best do that by supporting the tax package in the Senate.

talk.start.para: âI thank the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation at the table for his assistance and his words of encouragement. Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1998-99âwhich we are debating cognately with two other appropriation billsâtalks about the state of the economy. As the minister at the table has suggested, the Labor Party should support our tax bill in the Senate. That has been the thrust of the government's position during the campaign and obviously during the current debate in this place and in the Senate.

speech.para: I want to bring to the attention of the House, and all Australians, the wonderful state of play that now exists in the Australian economy, and the background reasons as to why Australia is performing so well when other nations around the world, especially in our region, are suffering economic difficulty.

Australia has performed well in my assessment because its policy settings are based on a market economy and, to use that set of words that is sometimes frowned upon, on rational economics. That means the economy is based on a demand driven approach. It is based on an understanding of democratic principles. It is a market economy where supply and demand is handled without too much government interference. People have a choice of the goods and services that they wish to buy and, under this government, there has been an improvement in private sector efficiency.

Free markets distribute goods and services to people in a more efficient way. The world has come to the view that the command economies of the communist countriesâtheir systemâdo not work. We see a situation here in our region where Australia has performed remarkably well. In other nations in the South-East Asian area, such as Japan and Thailand, a dominant position has been taken by the policy makers and the governments that have directed the way in which the policy should go. Also, a few of the ruling elite had a vested interest, particularly in Japan where the banks borrowed against the share market. Their equity has fallen away to negligible levels so much that the banking sector in some of the South-East Asian countries is very much under threat.

We had a situation in Japan where big governments and big trade union movements were setting the wages and conditions and the market was not able to make proper judgments. We now have a position, which should have affected Australia, where Japan, technically, is moving into a depression and its central bank is looking for extra credit to maintain its position in the world.

The situation in Australia is that the government, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have brought about a policy setting to balance the budget. That is not an easy situation, as the minister at the table would understand. Politically it is always difficult because of the people out in the community who receive money, receive pensions, from governments. There are the interest groups who always suggest that a balanced budget is not a good thing. This policy in turn has brought about a lower interest rate regime and low inflation. Those things are taken for granted under a Liberal coalition government, but there has not been too much comment by the electorate or by the commentators that these very important factors have been reached.

The floating exchange rate, which I concede the Hawke-Keating government brought in in 1983, has meant that there has been a genuine movement of the exchange of Australia relative to the rest of the world so that the change in trading conditions was taken into account.

The change in the taxation system that is proposed will ensure that hardworking Australians will receive $13 billion worth of tax cuts, and that 80 per cent of Australian income earners will pay no more than the 30 cents in the dollar tax rate. That is a very clear proposition that has provided incentive and confidence to most hardworking Australians. In my own industry, the rural industry, I constantly see hardworking shearers giving up work on a Friday because their tax rate, in their assessment, is too high. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be aware of that from your own experience. I think that is a very clear example of tax rates penalising incentive.

We have this situation with the exchange rates where a more flexible position has been reached in Australia and where the Reserve Bank did not support the exchange rate by artificial means. The Australian dollar bought US80c in early 1997 and got down to as low as something like US56c. Today it stands at US64.5c. That gives a clear indication of the flexibility by which the government and the Reserve Bank have been able to ensure that, by sensible policy settings, Australia has been able to insulate itself against some of the difficulties of the world slowdown, particularly in Asia.

The floating exchange rate has helped out exporters who have not been enjoying profitable times in recent months. But at least the lower US dollar exchange rate ensured that their competitive position was helped. It is interesting to note the comments of Paul Krugman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology writing in Fortune on 21 December 1998. This quote has been used by other speakers on this side of the House but I think it sets in context the position of Australia in the world economic climate. He said:

Although most of its exports go either to Japan or the stricken Tigers, Australia has weathered the storm . . . instead of raising interest rates to defend the Aussie dollarâwhich would have slowed the Aussie economyâthe central bank allowed the currency to slide from almost 80 cents in early 1997 to the low 60s by mid-1998. The result was that while export prices plunged in US dollars, they held in local currency and strong domestic demand kept the economy humming.

That is a very interesting comment by a respected commentator in the Fortune magazine, which is read by most informed economists in America. Krugman went on to note that financial markets viewed the decline in the dollar as a buying opportunity which led to the stabilisation of the currency.

As I was saying, the floating exchange rate mechanism ensures that there is a better price for our commodities such as the wool industry which is suffering a very low price at the moment. But if the exchange rate was against that industry, the wheat industry or the coal industry, just imagine how difficult our commodity prices might have been.

In the case of the Australian banks, unlike some of the other banking institutions around the world, the Australian banks obviously had difficulties in the early 1980s, partly because they did not follow the usual conservative practices. But Australian banks did not fall over, as some banks throughout the Asian region have. We have just seen that Bob Joss has left Westpac in profit. That particular bank, because of its questionable lending practices and the write-off of a number of bad debts, was in a difficult position. It is fair to say that the Australian banking system was prudentially secure and that the Australian people had confidence in it. Under Treasurer Costello and the Howard government, the Australian banking system is very sound, in good heart and has a very strong prudential protection for investors.

The other important factor of Australia's economy being in good heart and being as strong as it is now is the labour market reforms that have been debated in this House on many occasions. We are now starting to see the effect of a change of attitude to labour market reforms and productivity gains in the mining industry and in the manufacturing sector because the work force now has a greater pride in their operations. They have a responsibility for the job in hand and there has been a change by management towards the way in which the work force is being directed and organised. That in itself has ensured genuine productivity gains in Australia where there have been real increases in wages, control of inflation and workers have had more spending power; unlike the heady days of 11 per cent inflation where workers had illusory gains under award conditions but, in fact, their ability to improve their standard of living was very much reduced.

Turning to the balanced budget again, Treasurer Costello and the Howard government have ensured over a three-year period that the budgets are moving back into balance. Despite the $10 billion black hole, which all Australians are familiar with, by next year the federal budget will be in balance. This compares very favourably with the former position in my home state of Victoria where the Cain-Kirner Labor government managed to get that state in a position of bankruptcy, where the state budget was unable to pay their cash payments on a day by day, week by week basis. That was a very lamentable positionâthat a Labor government in such a short term of office could have turned around a state which basically had a sound financial position to one of total bankruptcyâas was the Labor government in South Australia with the collapse of the State Bank of South Australian.

There has been some debate across the board about balancing the budget both here and in America. Even President Clinton has been moving towards balancing the huge US budget. We now have a position in Australia where the federal budget will be balanced and where state budgets are now moving towards a position of balance. That ensures that the taxpayers' dollars are not servicing debt and that there are improved credit ratings which allow those borrowings to be borrowed at a lesser rate, which has a major impact. I notice the movement in Victoria, hopefully, to a AAA Moody's rating which will ensure that the Kennett government can enjoy better interest rates. The Minister for Financial Services and Regulation at the table is very familiar with this set of financial circumstances. That also helps with interest ratesâthat is fundamentalâand the lowering of inflation rates in Australia.

The challenge for the government and for Australia is the balance of payments. It is a matter of concern that the growing economy, by all factors, has ensured that the three per cent growth rate or whatever it might eventually work out to beâmuch better than people anticipatedâhas put pressure on the balance of payments because Australian consumers wish to import goods. The prices our commodities fetch are obviously lower. So the balance of payments is not as good as it might be. However, there are some very encouraging signs that exporters are looking for new markets.

In my own electorate of Corangamite I have the honour to chair an export group, the Geelong Export Network. That group has encouraged local manufacturers and businessmen to look at export market opportunities outside Australia. It has been remarkable the number of opportunities and success stories that have been identified by people who were just looking at export opportunities to improve their business performance, who were able to achieve a niche market in Asia, India and South Africa and were able to export some of their product, overcome the difficulties of language, currency and ensuring payment, all those difficulties which seem insurmountable for exporters who have never before been in export.

That little group, along with Austrade, has been helpful in ensuring that exports improve. We make a dent in that balance of payments problem, so that in the longer run Australia will trade on the right side of the ledger. Obviously the Howard-Costello monetary and financial policy is to encourage Australia to become a more efficient economy so that Australian products become world competitive and we can sell our products in terms of quality and price to the world. The tariff regimes have been reduced and, while those decisions have been difficult in certain parts of Australia, in the TCF industries and in the car industries I am delighted to say that the downward trend of the tariff barriers has had a major impact on attitudes and on the ability of the car industry and the TCF industries to improve their manufacturing process and their efficiency. Also in the farming area, in wheat cropping and in my own area of Corangamite, changes in technology are now looking at productivity improvements that are really quite remarkable.

Again, I note the change in other countriesâin particular, Germany and in the European Unionâwhere there is a tendency to move the other way. A council of ministers rules those 350 million people by dictate and by direction. The genuine free enterprise ethic that is so evident in this country and in America is starting to be lost in some of the attitudes that are clearly evident in Europe. In particular, in Germany we are seeing a movement away from that powerhouse of free enterprise to the lowering of working hours, abolition of nuclear power and some of those fundamentals that created prosperity in that nationâsome of the arguments that we have had in this nation.

Australia has taken the hard decisions to bring about a better economy in a situation where most commentators would have thought Australia would be in difficulty. We have reduced the deficit and we have made an attack on unemployment, which is now at 7.5 per cent, the lowest for many years. That we are gradually reducing the number of Australians unemployed is a remarkable achievementâthe lowest since 1990 and the lowest youth unemployment since 1989.

Australians are increasingly participating in the share marketâsomething unheard of five, six or seven years ago. Average Australians are participating in the Telstra float and did participate in the sale of the Commonwealth Bank, which the former government sold. That has encouraged average Australians to become small capitalists, to understand the share market and to understand that their wealth and productivity is connected to the outcome of their superannuation and their investment in the share market.

I might sound a note of caution about the exuberance of Wall Street and the position of the Australian share market. I observe that share markets do go up and do come down. The investors of Australia need to be somewhat careful about the good times and be aware that the high value of the share market will not always continue, but I think they can be assured that, over time, the share market will continue a steady rise if it reflects the productivity and the wealth of Australia.

The freer markets that have been introduced by this government, the lower interest rates, the low inflation and tax reform have ensured that Australia is moving in the right direction. These are fundamental reforms that have been put in place against considerable opposition by the conservative, backward looking opposition, who are not prepared to make the change, who proposed in the earlier part of their time in government a GST and yet who sit here in this chamber and in the Senate saying they are against it.

The Australian economy, encouraged by this government, has based its whole operation on choiceâthat consumers, manufacturers and workers have a choice, that we have a free market position and that governments are moving out of people's lives in the way things are regulated. The activities of the National Competition Council under Graeme Samuel have ensured that monopolies are being challenged and that resources are being allocated to those areas that can be more productive and more profitable.

I commend the government's policy position. I commend the outcomes reflected in the current set of figures. They are probably the best for 30 years. They are not artificial. These fundamentals and the way in which the Australian economy is working will ensure that there is a good sound future. Obviously we cannot be sure what international shocks might hit us, such as a change in the oil price and other problems with commodity prices on world stock markets, but at least the sensible, well thought out, rational economic policy settings of the present government have given Australia a very sound future in a turbulent world, especially that of our near neighbours.

talk.start.para: âI want to talk on these appropriation bills about a concern I have as an Australian citizen, as a member of parliament, as the shadow minister for industry and as the Minister for Trade in the previous government. My concern is with the hole in the middle of the current rounds of what is seen as economic good newsâand much of which is economic good news.

speech.para: The hole that I see at the core of Australia's economic progress is the growing problem with the current account deficit. But that is actually the tip. That is not the iceberg; it is what is showing up. I think there is a profound structural problem in the development of the Australian economy, and it is a reflection of Australia's difficulty in coming to grips with its place in the modern global economy.

The economy continues to exude relatively strong growth, and the government continues to look very smug and complacent about that. It shows some significant similarities with the story of the artificially inseminated cow that knows something wonderful has happened but has not got the faintest idea how it came about. That is the circumstance we find in our economy at the moment.

When you look at what is driving the growth that continues to be a littleâor, in some cases, a lotâhigher than the more pessimistic economic forecasters suggest, try to look behind the rhetorical flourishes and ask, `What is it that is driving this economic result? What are the factors that underpin it? And are they likely to suggest that it is sustainable?' The most powerful explanation is the success of the United States economy. I would like to come back to that in a moment. There is no doubt that, within Australia, we are reaping the benefits of 15 years of economic reform. A lot of change has taken place which has made the economy more internationally competitive and more successful. Some of those were driving important structural changes which, I regret to say, seem to me to have been reversed. I will come to that in a moment. I am worried about this structural problem, but there has been the benefit of 15 years of economic reform.

Principally we have the success of the United States economy driven by a number of factors, not all of which are relevant to the points I want to make tonight and, in themselves, more than anybody could cover in a 20-minute speech. But there are some elements of it that are particularly important. One, to which the member for Corangamite made fleeting mention, is the wealth effect of the boom on the United States stock exchange driving perceptions of wealth and therefore consumer demand and that you get out of that continuing growth. We have had a lesser version of that in Australia, where the stock market has not grown at the same rate, but there have been some elements of a wealth effect out of an improving stock market and out of the significant Australian demutualisationsâtake, for example, AMP as the most recentâand that has driven consumer demand. There is an inherent instability in economic growth driven by domestic consumer demand, and it shows up in the current account deficit in exactly the problem that I am concerned about and want to come back to.

But there is another element of our success that is reflected internationallyâwe always tend to think that in Australia these are unique phenomenaâand that is the question of the long period of low inflationary growth that Australia has had. The government would like to claim that it has occurred only since March 1996, but we have actually had five years and more, getting on now towards six and seven years, of low inflationary growth. It is an experience we have not had for a long time. It is an international experience; it is therefore hard to argue that it is driven by domestic Australian policy. If it is driven by domestic Australian policy, why is it happening in all those other countries? But there are some common features, and one that I think is significantly underestimated is the impact of information technology in two ways: directly when the prices of information technology products are falling; and, secondly, because of the way in which information technology and technological change are driving falling costs in other aspects of industry.

So for those reasons we have a continuing period of economic growth and low inflationary growth. But there are some clouds on the horizon, and I wish that people would balance the optimism they exude with a little more responsibility and analysis of the issues that are emerging that give cause for concern and that are behind the backdrop of the structural problems and issues to which I wish to refer.

Let us have a look at what has been a remarkably accurate leading indicator of employment. I refer to what used to be called the DEET leading indicator. I do not know how you pronounce the acronym, but it is now the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business leading indicator. It is the same complicated measure based on a number of issues: vehicle registrations, dwelling approvals, vacancy measures and economic growth measures. It has proved over the 15 or more years of its operation to be a very successful and accurate leading indicator, with about a six-month lag. The leading indicator fell for seven consecutive months, until December 1998. The last peak in the indicator occurred in May 1998, and it has fallen for seven months since then. The Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business indicates that that suggests the growth rate of employment will peak during the early part of this year.

Strangely, the government have not referred to that. They have referred to several other employment surveys, but the one they have not referred to is their own. That gives me some cause for apprehension. At the moment it does not look like it is about to collapse, but it does look like the labour market has peaked and that growth in employment is slowing. This is reinforced by details from the Bureau of Statistics about the housing industry which, as the shadow minister for industry, is part of my area of concern and responsibility. The seasonally adjusted data available from last December show that the construction of dwellings is starting to turn down. There is serious cause for concern there that I think we need to pay more attention to than we are.

Paralleling that is the data from BIS Shrapnel about engineering construction. Its document released at the end of last month forecast a 20 per cent decline in activity in Australia's engineering construction industry towards the end of this year. There is no chance that we are going to achieve what is now a bipartisan five per cent unemployment target without addressing a forecast decline of 20 per cent in engineering construction. The government has a policy vacuum about that.

We had some policies at the last election because we foresaw this, and they were targeted to address this problem. By the time we come back into office, that is not going to be the policy prescription because the world will have moved on, but it is an issue that governments need to address. This problem in the engineering construction industry, which is reflected in the reports of a number of the construction companies. I notice it is in the report on Leighton's in this morning's newspaper.

The last comment I want to make about these straws in the wind that cause me some apprehension about whether the smug complacency about our economic performance is justified relates to the most recent December international trade in goods and services figures which show a decline in importsâwhich on the face of it for me, someone expressing concern about the current account deficit, should be a good thingâand it may in fact suppress the impact of the current account deficit problems that we have driven by the excessive consumption base to our economic growth. But it is a problem nevertheless, because the decline is in the importation of capital goods, particularly machinery and industrial equipment, which was the largest decrease which essentially drove the fall.

That is an indication of a problem we have of a fall-off in investment. Where you have a fall-off in investment and a substantial increase in consumption, you are building up a structural imbalance that has the potential to cause serious medium-term problems. It is that to which I wish to refer in my concluding comments about the structural issues to do with Australia's economy and, to the extent that I can, the response which I think the Australian government should start to take.

Looking at some of the structural issues of the Australian economy over the last 15 years, the data showsâsome of the data refers to the last two years but most of it does not, because the rate at which the data can be analysed means we are mainly getting analysis based on material from around 1996âthat the percentage growth in exports had been highest up to 1996 in some of our important manufacturing and services sectors. The fastest growth was in forestry and fishing, which is a very small industry in export terms compared with some of our great industries. Non-metallic minerals, machinery and equipmentâa very significant growth areaâother manufacturing and printing and recorded media are other areas where we are getting a lot of growth in exports. We are also seeing competition for machinery and equipment, that very significant part of our imports which makes up 50 per cent of our merchandise imports.

We have significant growth in some of our services exports, which are of course driven very much by travel and transportation. They are the biggest but not the fastest growing exports, the fastest growing being insurance and, in that period, construction services. I am seriously worried about the fact that support for the export activity of our construction services industries is being withdrawn, in the face of the infrastructure decline in Asia, at the very time when the support is most needed. The Asia Infrastructure Consortium Program, which gave the capacity for Australian consulting engineers and others to put together consortia to bid for the infrastructure projects in Asia, was withdrawn just when it was most needed. So some of those areas of growth have had the support cut out from under them when they are most needed.

In the manufacturing sector, a significant factor in that period of growth was the strength of export growth by those industries adding value to our resourcesâthe food and beverage and metal products industries. I am concerned about whether we are going to continue the focus that leads to that growth because we need to be increasing our exports in the areas of growing world tradeâwhich is manufactures and services. We have been falling back, since the change of strategy driven by this government, to increased reliance on our exports of the very important agricultural and mineral industries, but we continue to sell into a market where the relative prices are falling. We need to focus on increasing our exports in areas where relative prices are risingâessentially high skill, high technology manufacturing and services.

We always focus a lot on exports, but improving our competition with imports is very important. For example, the biggest fall in that period in import penetration was in printing, publishing and recorded media. We have had some rather colourful confrontations in this place about the government's policies that I think undermine the capacity of those industries, particularly recorded media, to be as effective as they might be in meeting import competition and in exporting.

I do not have time to go on to it, but when you measure the knowledge intensity trends in industry development Australia is down at the bottom in the skill pattern and we need to change that. Our R&D has been concentrated at the low technology end of the market compared with the OECD overall, and we need to change that.

I have briefly putâand it has been a very rough thumbnail sketch because time does not permit any moreâsome serious structural problems about where the Australian economy is going and how it can effectively respond to the challenges of globalisation.

Let me mention some of the issues that cause me concern. The government is giving this problem very low priority. In the Governor-General's address to the parliament, to which we had the address-in-reply debate, there was one paragraphâ29 wordsâabout industry policy, with nothing new to say. We had growing concern expressed just this week by our top researchers, who warn that Australia is failing to capitalise on its edge in the lucrative biotechnology industry. It is an area where our research strength is strong and where government inactivity and, worse than that, government cuts and lack of support to universities and to R&D is putting our potential in that very important growth sector at risk.

In the growth area of knowledge based industriesâwhich is where the jobs are and particularly where the high wage jobs areâthe government is failing to protect and, in some cases, is consciously undermining our intellectual property regimes, at a time when the most important aspect of driving growth is successful intellectual property so that people can have confidence in their ownership. I do not refer just to the arguments we had last year about parallel imports, but we now have the National Competition Council recommending that the Trade Practices Act be changed to threaten the capacity of knowledge based industries to enter into some of the licensing arrangements for development of their intellectual property. It is a misunderstanding of the competitive impact of those changes, because those arrangements bring new and competitive products onto the market. It is a pro-competitive policy. I think the National Competition Council has got it wrong in this matter. It got some of the other parts of that report right, but it got that part wrong, and I think the government should clearly reject that.

The government is making some interesting noises, and Minister Alston runs around letting out little thought bubbles. He was talking about encouraging clusters this week. When you ask, `What is behind this? What is the policy? What is he going to do?' there is nothing. It is simply a word that someone has mentioned to him and he says, `Let me say something about that.' But nothing happens. So we need a new direction in industry policy in Australia.

We face challenges in industry policy, and the industry policy requirements of Australia during the next decade are not the same as those of the past. The central focus of public policy for the next three years must be the role government plays in the emerging industries and in the application of scientific and technological innovation to our traditional industries.

We have a strong record of scientific achievement and a proud record of inventiveness. But in the past we have not been able to commercialise that innovation as effectively as we might. It is very important to notice that OECD analysis suggests that in high wage marketsâwhere I assume Australia wants to beâmanufacturing companies can best survive by focusing on work that has a high technology or science content. If we are not driven by technology and science, we are going down the path of a low wage strategy for our growth instead of a high wage strategy for growth. If we are falling back on the low technology industries we might create low wage jobs, but we will not create the sorts of jobs we are educating and training our young people for.

That requires increased government focus on investment, innovation, research and development. What has the Howard government been doing? Reducing funding for universities and reducing incentives for R&D investment. For the first time since records have been collected, industry R&D spending is starting to fall. We need a greater focus on relevant education and training. What is the Howard government's response? Higher education contributions which are higher for science and engineering courses than for others. They are going in exactly the wrong direction.

Because we have had a long period of economic reform there is a lot of strength in the Australian economy, but there are worrying signs and structural flaws. We need an Australian government responding to those worrying signs, responding to those structural flaws, and I regret to say nothing in the policies we see before us at the moment encourages us to think that we are going to get that coherent response in industry policy or in macro-economic policy.

talk.start.para: âIf the member for Fraser wants to see some opportunities being realised by the coalition government, he should have a look at the recent developments out at the Amberley Air Force Base in the electorate of Blair because there a real revolution is going on in the contracting-out of existing RAAF services. It is providing a doorway to high technology development. School leavers and people of that ilk can look to learning real trades, real technologiesâthe techniques of the future. I compliment Amberley Air Force Base on the work that it is doing. Amberley is leading the country in that field. I do not think that at the moment there are any places in the world other than Amberley where you can rebuild an F111 from the ground up. That is what you can do at RAAF Base Amberley. There is also the development of the new Ipswich campus of the University of Queensland. It will provide the necessary training to compliment the good work that is going on out at Amberley.

speech.para: My agenda in this debate on the appropriation bills is the issue of roads because I think roads are the basic building blocks of our society. I want to look at what is being done to appropriate money to make sure those roads are at the highest possible standard. I want to quote from Refocusing Road Reform, a report provided to the Business Council of Australia not long ago. That report says:

A greater than 50% real reduction in these costs over the last 20 years has contributed to a transfer of transport demand from rail and public transport to roads. Future technological advances will probably focus on reducing the adverse social impacts of road transport.

Another finding of that report was that in urban areas over 40 per cent of our travel is on a stop-start undivided arterial street system. Less than 10 per cent of Australian urban travel is on a controlled access primary road system compared with 40 per cent in US cities. This is of economic significance as freeways have 70 per cent less accidents, 30 per cent less fuel consumption, from 50 to 100 per cent less emissions and 50 per cent less time loss for business than stop-start arterial roads.

Traffic numbers are growing faster on primary roads, as in other countries, and falling on rural local roads as the rural population declinesâthat of itself is another storyâor moves into larger country towns. The extent of Australia's paved rural road network is close to best international practice. The extent of our primary road network is well below best international practice. We have only eight kilometres of freeway per billion vehicle kilometres travelled compared with 25 to 35 kilometres per billion vehicle kilometres travelled in Europe and North America. The percentage of travel in Australia on a good quality primary road system is therefore significantly less than in other countries.

The resources consumed in road transport are close to $81 billion per year and include road user, accident, road agency and environmental costs. Business travel costs constitute 66 per cent of total road user costs, and little emphasis has to date been placed on potential resource cost savings for the business car and light commercial vehicles used in the service sector.

I have rattled off a few of those points, and they are quite significant, but perhaps I should also say that Australia is one of the most motorised countries in the world and leads the world in the amount of road freight carried per capita. There was a substantial growth in road freight relative to GDP in the period between 1976 and 1985. I wanted to lay out that background because when we talk about appropriations we are talking about what the government is spending its money on and the direction in which we are taking our country. In regional and rural parts of Australiaâsuch as the area I representâthe development of the regional road network and the development of our national highway system are things which we have to focus very closely on, particularly in this forum.

Looking back over recent times, the funding for the construction of roads in Australia actually suffered during Labor's time in office.
