The real per capita expenditure on Australian roads in constant 1995-96 dollars fell from $131 million in 1983-84 to $85.9 million dollars in 1995-96. The decline in expenditure on Australian roads links neatly with the decline in revenue governments receive from our ailing taxation system. It is no wonder that even the big spenders of the Labor Party cannot afford more for roads when each year the tax system provides us with less revenue. Each year there is less money coming in to provide important infrastructure such as roads. There is less for basic services and less to support those dependent on welfare. We all suffer because the tax system, which is now conveniently defended by Labor, is unable to provide for our needs, and our needs include things like good quality roads.

Fortunately, the changes proposed by the coalition in our tax package help to correct all that. Thanks to the coalition, we can start to debate the question of what priorities we will set now that the tax package offers a substantial dividend and an annual return that will grow naturally as the economy grows, which is a very different picture from what we have seen in recent times. It is an insult to the intelligence of Australians that members opposite have the hide to speak in a debate about government expenditure. These are the same people who cringe at the thought of a real debate on taxation in this country. They do not want to know where the money is coming from; they just want to know how to spend it.

I have said on many occasions that the government's tax package is the single most important factor that contributed to my election. It sounds crazy, but in my electorate the two per cent easytax proposed by One Nation was more credible than the chook scratchings, I suppose you might say, that were dished up by Labor in that election. I went through that election and I pay credit to the Treasurer and to the Prime Minister, because their work on tax became the focus of attention.

Now that the election debate is over, we can turn to dividing the spoils. While Labor squabbles over its future direction, or lack of it, we can discuss the distribution of hundreds of millions of dollars in tax revenue and generated returns that flow from a system that is built to align itself with the real needs of people in the 1990s. The GST delivers more than tax cuts. It will bring about lower transport prices and a new ability to compete in export markets. It brings money into the system.

With the new system in place, the appropriation debate in this parliament can take on a whole new meaning. Instead of squabbling like seagulls over some of the truly malodorous offerings that we have had in the past, we can get back to the real business of government and start to look ahead with a real idea where the money will actually be coming from. Thanks to the coalition, we can get back to the business of providing building blocks for development. We can build infrastructure. We can use the money we generate to build a better country, one that is more secure and more productive.

I do not want our new inheritance wasted. I want new money for infrastructure projects, for important building blocks in our communities. I want it for roads and dams and for a range of basic infrastructure projects that, frankly, have been driven off the national agenda ever since our taxation system began to deteriorate. As that deterioration accelerated, so we saw the end of discussion about reasonable infrastructure projects that we really need to be pursuing in this country.

In my electorate of Blair, the Warrego Highway is the one national highway funded by the Commonwealth. Like other highways, the Warrego has developed over the years until today it is a much better piece of road than it was back in the 1960s or 1970s. It is in a pretty good state of repair compared to what it was in those days. But there are still problems, and they continue to emerge as the use of the road continues to develop. There are problem areas. There are black spots, places like the Plainlands intersection, where we have had a number of serious and even fatal accidents and where we see the prospect, in the very near future, of further developmentâsuch as a schoolâgoing there. We need to be looking at ways to keep up the road standard as the network develops.

I turn now to some of the comments on the way our road infrastructure has developed alongside the demand that is being placed on it. People have set out to assess how we are keeping up with the development of our roads and the traffic on them. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Communications, Transport and Microeconomic Reform report called Planning, not patching stated:

While the objectives and provision of the national highway system may be broadly seen as adequate, there are linkage problems including sections of some roads, access to ports of and areas of major production. In addition, the linkages in urban centres connecting highways are a significant problem.

The report went on to identify, for example, bridge infrastructure as important. I think we have got to make sure that we proceed effectively and do not drop the ball in keeping up the pace of development of the road network.

I want to move on from talking generally about the development of the road network to one issue that I think is dragging that back and causing us problems. It is the issue of noise. We do have to spend an awful lot of money in dealing with noise barriers these days. In some areas you see noise barriers going in probably faster than the highways themselves. A report titled Australian transport and the environment 1997 quoted figures from an Australian study, undertaken in 1986, that 45 per cent of people were concerned about road traffic noise, compared to the next highest area of concern, aircraft noise, at 24 per cent. I think the member for Griffith might be interested to read that because he has had a lot to say about aircraft noise. I think we should be looking also at road noise.

The highest concern in that study for 30 per cent of residents was about the noise from cars modified to increase their level of performanceâcertainly in terms of noise generation. This was followed by noise from motorbikes and squealing brakes. Of people who lived on main roads, 32 per cent said the noise from heavy trucks caused the greatest concern. Compared to the total survey population, those living on main roads voiced higher concern about noise generated by squealing brakes, delivery vans, car horns, buses and that sort of thing.

I mention that survey because I have just spoken about the Warrego Highway and yet we have people concerned about the noise coming from that highway. It is an important artery. There is no suggestion at all that you would ever want to close down the highway because of the noise, but something has got to be done about it. If we look at the way we have been developing answers to the issue of noise, we have seen barriers going up by new highways where the areas being protected from noise are new housing estates that are being built basically at the same time as the highway. It seems crazy to me that we are providing that level of support there, whereas in areas where homes have already been built we are not providing the noise barriers that should come as the highway grows.

I think that some of the state governments and indeed our good selves should be more careful to make sure that people are allocated noise barriers and those sorts of things in line with their entitlement and the degree of discomfort they are feeling so that it is a proper, transparent process. I am concerned at the moment that it does tend to be rather higgledy-piggledy. If I were to compare, say, the development of noise barriers on the Gateway arterial road in Brisbane with the development of noise barriers on the Warrego Highway, I think that the comparison would draw some very strange conclusions in my mindâfor example, that the Gateway development is proceeding way ahead of its time.

I would like to say something about the cost of noise. The report Australian transport and the environment 1997 cites a report of the National Roads Transport Commission of 1995, which estimated the annual cost of noise to Australia as being between $200 million and $400 million. The report also quotes an estimate made by the Interstate Commission in 1990 of $534 million.

In the United States in 1984, it was estimated that four per cent of the nation's annual fuel consumption was due to traffic congestion. In New South Wales, a government report estimated that, without changes in transport planning directions, the results for Sydney in 20 years time would be a 67 per cent increase in travel demand, a 600 per cent increase in congestion, a 23 per cent increase in fuel consumption and a 36 per cent deterioration in air quality. The cost of traffic congestion in Brisbane alone was $400 million. That compared with an estimated cost in Sydney, for example, of over $2 billion.

I raise that because one of the things that has been suggested recently by residents along the Warrego Highway who are desperate in dealing with this noise issue and the lack of action from the state governmentâwhich, I must admit, is merely setting priorities according to the allocation of Commonwealth dollarsâis that we look at speed reductions. I do not think that is an entirely inopportune suggestion. We should perhaps be considering the fact that, as these highways become congested, they are going to become slower and choked. Perhaps it would be worth whileâwe could free more money to spend on the roadâin built-up areas to be prepared to limit the speed.

In the report that I have here on speed control and transport policy, there are a few comments that I think are relevant. Apparently, if you take heavy vehicles as making up 10 per cent of traffic, a report quoted in the policy document that I referred to found that the difference between traffic moving at 100 kilometres per hour compared with traffic way down at 32 kilometres per hour was about 5.5 decibels. That may not sound like very much, but that is quite a significant amount when you take into account the volume of traffic and occasional bursts of speed by particular speeding vehicles. That report includes a graph which shows quite a notable difference between, for example, the noise generated by vehicles at 90 kilometres per hour and vehicles travelling at 100 kilometres per hour. That is an issue that should be pursued because we definitely have to protect our investment in roads.

I want to turn briefly to the rail network because that is another example of infrastructure development which we should be proceeding carefully with. I am talking not about pie in the sky projectsâand there have been a few of thoseâbut about the normal basic development of the rail network in and around Brisbane. For example, we can look to the north and we have the latest and greatest of rail technologies. We have a tilt train roaring up the coast at huge velocity. Yet, if we look to the west from Brisbane out towards Toowoomba, we have the most ancient and archaic rail system I think you could possibly have.

I will take two towns that are roughly the same distance apart from Brisbane. To Toowoomba by road is a distance of 135 kilometres; to Gympie it is 182 kilometres. Based on the timetable for electric train services, the time it takes to get from Gympie to Brisbane on the new tilt train is two hours 19 minutes. If I want to go on the train to Toowoomba, I have to take a twice-weekly diesel service which takes four hours five minutes to travel a little shorter distance out to Toowoomba.

In 1996 Toowoomba had over 83,000 people compared with Gympie with 10,000 people. Why can we not even this up? We should be having a much more relative and effective rail network and it seems crazy to me that, in the time it takes to travel on a rattling old diesel out to Toowoomba, you can hop on a brand new tilt train and be in Bundaberg, which is way to the north, in the same time. I think that we need to be looking at allocating that money because, if we could link up Toowoomba and Brisbane, the capital of Queensland, we would definitely contribute greatly to the economy of south-east Queensland and to the state as a whole. It would certainly assist the development of the Darling Downs and places along the way between those two centresâI represent, of course, the Lockyer Valleyâand it would be a great boon to residents living in that area and to the development of industry in that area.

In closing, I want to urge the government to look much more closely at infrastructure development. I think the opportunity for planning has been given to us, now that we have this new tax system on the agenda. We can look ahead with great certainty as to where we are going and I would appeal to all members to support the development of a 21st century rail and road network in this country.

talk.start.para: âI intend to use the rather broad opportunity that the appropriation bills provide members in this House to make some careful remarks about drug policy. Drug policy is directly relevant to the shadow portfolio I hold as it is a significant law and justice issue. It is also a very important health and social issue.

speech.para: A starting point for reflection on this issue is to go to the 1996 review of the national drug strategy which concluded, amongst other things, that despite its many accomplishments and international acclaim the national drug strategy is in danger of sliding off the political agenda. The national drug strategy, which evolved in the various incarnations of the Labor administrationsâthe Hawke-Keating governmentsâhad won very significant international support and was recognised as probably the leading model internationally of how to address a difficult law and social justice issue.

If those comments of the national drug strategy reviewâthat there was danger of the strategy sliding off the political agendaâwere true in 1996 they are more than true now. I see some of the reasons that that could be the case flowing from the manner of the administration of the strategy by the current government. I see the problems as having two dimensions. First, the focus has been blurred and confused by an increasing cooption of the strategy by attempts to harness it to short-term political objectives and an increasing emphasis on prohibition and law enforcement. The second problem flows from the first, and it is that emphasis that lacks credibility. No-one, least of all law enforcement professionals, believes that Australia can win a war on drugs if that is taken to mean that the supply of all illicit drugs can be cut off. Indeed, recent massive heroin seizures have had no impact on street prices or the availability of heroin, ecstasy and other illicit drugs.
I refer to a telling comment by Professor David Penington in the Age on Friday, 12 February. He said:

We hear just recently of huge hauls of heroin . . . and we have announcements made by politicians that obviously the system is working, and that will deal with the problem; but the reality of course is that the street price of heroin is probably less than it's ever been and the purity of heroin higher than it has ever been.

The problem of credibility is compounded by two factors. The first factor is that, as the focus of the strategy has moved towards law enforcement, focus has been lost on the need to plan and maintain harm minimisation strategies for licit drugsâalcohol and tobacco. Abuse of those licit pharmaceuticals gives rise to social and health costs which in their total dimensions dwarf those associated with illicit drugsânot withstanding the very legitimate concerns and community anxieties that are associated with the latter.

Second, to the degree that a focus on interdiction and law enforcement is inherent in any overall strategy, under the current government there has been a conspicuous failure to develop benchmarks to evaluate the impact on supply, street availability and the price of illicit drugs.

I sought to obtain from the government answers to relatively simple questions by placing questions on the notice paper. I asked, for example: what is the government's estimate for 1996-97 and 1997-98 of the total street value of illicit drugs sold in Australia? The answer that was provided to me said:
Establishing estimates of total values and volumes of illicit drug markets is a very difficult task given the nature and types of information available.

It refers me to some publications, but the government does not state its own best estimates in relation to research into the total street value of illicit drugs sold in Australia. The government provides no material in response to questions about particular drugsâillicit heroin, cannabis, ecstasy, amphetamines, anabolic steroids and others imported into Australia.

I also sought to obtain information about what the government understood to be the effect on the street price of heroin of recent massive drug seizures. Some while ago, in mid-October 1998, the largest ever seizure of heroin in Australia occurredâ400 kilograms in New South Wales. Had the market been affected by the massive volume that was taken out of circulation, you would have expected there to have been a price impact. The government's response was:

The nature of the illicit drug market means that it is not possible to precisely determine the effect of seizures on the prices of street heroin or ecstasy. The primary purpose of supply reduction is to stem, suppress and disrupt the flow and trafficking of illicit drugs and to send a deterrent message to other traffickers. The impact on the price of the drug is a secondary effect.

The reason I was seeking an answer to that question is that the price of drugs in most markets is the only measurable device to determine availability. In most markets the more available a product the lower the priceâmarket forces at work. When it is less available prices rise. Four hundred kilograms of heroin were seizedâthe largest ever in Australia's history. The apocryphal evidence that I received from law enforcement officers is that there was a minor price decline in Melbourne. At about the same time there were made available even lower priced starter packs for those who were beginning that form of drug use.

If you do not have effective benchmarks and you are unprepared to make public any assessments about how you are evaluating your strategy, or the criteria upon which you are operating, the main exposure to the public is reduced to what are fatuous media opportunities for ministersâand indeed the Prime Ministerâto congratulate themselves on large drug seizures, without them having to deal with the inconvenient facts that Professor Penington raised. It also places considerable pressure on law enforcement officials.

There are concerns within the law enforcement community that the decision to seize that 400 kilograms as it came ashoreârather than to follow the drugs to the distribution points and seek to trace the chain of distribution back to those who masterminded the importation in the first placeâmay have come about because of perceived political pressure to make large seizures and not to risk an enforcement strategy that was designed fundamentally to disrupt those chains of dealers at the highest levels.

Whether that concern is justified or not, one can certainly imagine that when ministers so associate themselves, and so constantly, with alleged successes of seizures, advocated on the basis of the size of that seizure, there would be considerable pressure to move to ensure that those objectives are met. It is legitimate to congratulate law enforcement agencies when they do successfully disrupt the plans of organised criminals involved in the importation of illicit drugs, but law enforcement cannot substitute for a strategy to deal with the inevitability of continuing ready supply in Australia of many illicit drugs.

It would be interesting to do some community analysis of opinion. My judgment is that, were we to do so, two elements would stand out. Firstly, there would still be considerable community support for some policies of retribution. I would expect there to be entrenched antagonism and hostility towards people you might regard as pushers of drugs and organised crime syndicates who profit from drug dealing as a business. The public would expect those people to be dealt with harshly if they are caught. But I would also expect to hear a lot of impatience and anger about out-of-touch leadership.

The community knows that there are a lot of drugs in the streets, schools and dance clubs. They expect their community leaders to deal with this with some realism. They know it is a problem that is just not going to go away. They do not like the fact that many of our young people are dying unnecessarily. They worry that addicts may steal their video and CDs just to get their next fix. They know that there are inadequate resources for rehabilitation, detoxification and treatment programs. They know there is a lot of hypocrisy around, particularly from our baby boom, `sex, drugs and rock-and-roll' generation of leaders, who went through their own drug days at universities. They know that just saying no is not going to do the trick. As an article in the Bulletin put it:
. . . making a choice about drug use is no longer counter-cultural.
It is part of the normal growing up of young Australians.

The Bulletin article referred to the fact that, by the age of 17, a majority of young peopleâ57 per cent of boys and 54 per cent of girlsâhad used cannabis at least once; 13 per cent had used more than one illicit drug; and heroin had been used by four per cent. This widespread use of some of these drugs presents a very problematic environment for law enforcement to be the sole response. Some important thinking has emerged from those who are expert in this area, not the least from Professor Penington but also much from the Australian Institute of Criminology.

The public knows that heroin is cheaper, more readily available and purer now than it was three years ago, when the Howard government took office. Australians are rightly wary of copying the institutional hypocrisy of other governmentsâlike perhaps the United Statesâwhich has seen increasing emphasis on a single strategy of prohibition. They know that prohibition has been associated with an escalation of violence, considerable problems with AIDS and other contagious diseases amongst injecting users, huge increases in prison populations and ever-higher penalties. Yet they know that the drug problem did not go away. That may explain surprising levels of support for the call from the capital city mayors and a large number of others, who have been urging new initiatives in this area.

It is important to deal honestly with these issues. The Australian way is not to put the head in the sand. In government, Labor put harm minimisation at the core of its policy. Just as we did with AIDS policy, where we took the hard options and did not surrender to populist opinions, we did it in illicit drug use: we addressed it principally as a health and community issue, incorporating not only law enforcement but also a larger debate about drug use, including alcohol and tobacco.

We recognised that it is important to provide factual, sound information to those who may be exposed to drugs, so that they are aware of the harm that they may face, and can make rational and intelligent decisions in their self-interest to protect themselves. Labor bluntly acknowledged that laws and law enforcement, whilst part of our response, could not and would not substitute for broader strategies. We knew that public education had to be realistic and not sensationalist.

Going back to the Bulletin statistics, when such a large proportion of the population is exposed to the availability of illicit drugs, sensationalist material which does not coincide with the real-life experience of young people is simply not going to be believed. I believe it is important to again assert the centrality of harm minimisation. We have to admit that we cannot completely cut off drug supply, and therefore we must define the central task as decreasing demand and promoting strategies for avoiding health and social damage.

Law enforcement remains an important task, a task which needs to be properly funded. One of the ironies of the current situation is that the government, over the first two years of its term, actually cut back very substantially the funding of the Australian Federal Police and that only after community anger had surfaced did it backfill some of those funding cuts. But it had damaged the key law enforcement institution responsible for policing.

We know that, even if the police do their job as efficiently and effectively as they can, that will not stop drugs coming. As David Penington said, the production of heroin and cocaine is now at a world all-time high and that they will continue to come into the country despite every effort by police, Customs and the National Crime Authority. That leaves us with a residual responsibility. I believe that we need to look seriously at a range of responses and refresh the idea of harm minimisation.

There are a number of strategies, but most which have been advanced in the public debate have not been given serious consideration by the current government. I regard it as a sad event that the Prime Minister dealt with suggestions from police ministers and his own health minister regarding one particular strategy supported by the ACT government by describing it as a `glib and simplistic' solution. It may not have been a solution which this government was prepared to adopt, but such a characterisationâin a difficult field where solutions are not simple to come by and where we are dealing with an environment where we need to grapple with hard facts and realities and not wish them awayâis a very unfortunate response.

It is not surprising that such people as David Penington, Bernie Geary and others of the drug advisory task forces around this country felt deeply hurt by such a characterisation of an initiative which had had a very long period of complex debateâcontroversial debate, but debate which could not possibly be properly characterised as `glib and simplistic'.

There are initiatives which Labor has proposed. We have proposed the idea of drug courts. I was recently in the United States and saw the operation of a drug court in Washington DC. I think that, as part of an overall strategy focused on harm minimisation and not dominated by the rhetoric of law enforcement and prohibition, drug courts will play an important part. Law enforcement itself plays an important part but, at the core, we have to recognise that we are dealing with a social dynamic in this country which is beyond that limited rhetoric, which does require us to reach out for a range of different solutions to meet particular circumstances, and which has to address the needs of those who become in need of support.

We also need to speak plainly to many young people who will not believe us if we use overinflated language to describe a living experience which they will almost inevitably confront as they move through the school system into their early teens and past that period into their youth. This is not a problem which can be swept under the carpet and overlooked. Harm minimisation should be reasserted as a central tenet of our policy. We must put public health and safety first.

We must make plain that the approach to drugs will not overlook the harms associated with tobacco and alcoholâwhich, in their totality, cause more death, social destruction and harm than do the illicit drugs; and so a total focus has to include those. We must be willing to address issues of this complexity and seriousness without the kind of derogatory language that the Prime Minister used in describing those who advocated a particular solution with which he found no sympathy.

talk.start.para: âTonight I would like to draw to the attention of the House and the wider public the gravity of the situation facing Australia in relation to our current account deficit. It is obviously an issue which should be of great significance and importance to all of us. At a time when, through good management, the Australian domestic economy is strong, we all know that the Asian economy and the world economy in general have stalled. Many countries are in recession and some are, in fact, in depression.

speech.para: The impact for Australia means that our imports continue to flow in as domestic demand is here, but that our exports are shrinking as the demand for our raw materials as well as for our elaborately transformed products starts to fall back. One of the largest exports from Australia is coal, and the coal industry represents 10 per cent of our exports. Unlike many of our other exports, it comes from regional and rural Australia. It has two major impacts: it creates jobs and wealth in the regionsâwhich we in this place all know have been shrinking over many years, as the bush is basically being denuded of its population as people move to the coastal fringes.

Coalmining is predominantly carried out in rural and regional Australia. There are still, I might add, some mines around Ipswich, which comes to mind as being very much the focus of south-east Queensland. The fact is that the jobs that they create and the wealth that they bring into Australia mean that the local focus and the national focus are, for us, paramount. Anything that puts the coal industry in jeopardy is in fact putting the sovereignty of this nation in jeopardy in the long term if it means that we lose contracts to competitors overseas and hence lose important export dollars.

Obviously, right now in Queensland there is a major issue with the coal industry in Emerald, where we have a dispute going on at the Gordonstone mine. I would like to touch on that shortly in some detail. A little of the history of the coalmining industry would indicate that unproductive work practices have been conducted in the industry, and that the very high incomes to be earned and the unproductive work practices conducted were condoned by management. I am not here to knock unions. I am here to talk about the difficulties facing this industry and hence the difficulties that will be forced upon Australia's economy.

Over many years, when coal was receiving good prices and it was relatively cheap to mine in Australia, we found that every time an employee made a demand, those demands were met almost out of hand rather than have industrial action. That has artificially inflated the pay of mine workers, without substantial increases in productivity and, in doing so, we had poor management practices and poor working practices in general, meaning that our mines did not meet world's best practice.

Under its workplace relations reform, this government deliberately put in place a framework for substantial improvements in the viability of the Australian coal industry. Like so many things, government can only put in the framework and it is then up to communities or businesses in partnerships to take up that framework and ensure that it works to their best advantage.

The coal industry is not only of critical importance to the country's wealth, given its huge export markets, but its location in regional Australia cannot be underestimated. Not only the direct jobs, but the indirect jobs of banks, schools and services that come with it into these regions are paramount. Every time a mine closes, devastation is wreaked upon the community. Cobar is an example. When it closed, Emeraldâwhich I mentioned earlierâwas fortunate in that it has many other diverse activities and industries, but it was still impacted on quite a lot.

The industry might be large, but it is also vulnerable to international demand and competitionânever more so today than it has been in the last 20 or 30 years. The Labor governments failed to improve the international competitiveness of this industry by creating a workplace relations environment which was not conducive to international best practice. They were unwilling to take on the entrenched power that the unions had put in place and the overoperation of the industry.

In doing so, Labor not only sold Australia down the drain but in turn sold down the drain many of the workers who had paid their union fees year after year to the CFMEU. They have consequently lost their jobs and been thrown on the scrap heap of unemployment, generally in middle age, with children at high school and with no real career prospects as they need retraining. There is a very human element to what we are putting here because the opposition, when in government, and the union bosses and management con spired together to put off a difficult situation and not deal with it at the time.

The recently released Productivity Commission inquiry into the black coal industry illustrates just how important to the industry the workplace relations reforms actually are. Its report says that the industry in Australia produces one per cent of GDP or 10 per cent of our exports. It said that in general the work practice and productivities fell well short of international performance and international standards. Simply put, that means it is more expensive to produce coal in Australia than it is overseas, making us less productive and less competitive. It said that some of the working arrangements, such as the `last on, first off' practice, have their roots in the early history of coalmining in Australia. How did these inefficient work practices come about? Basically, according to the Productivity Commission, it was because the pressure for higher wages and changed working conditions, backed by the threats of strike and disruption to supply, were usually successful.

That goes back to what I was saying earlier: it meant that at a time when these issues should have been dealt with, management was not willing to consult and deal with unions, and unions were not willing to participate as equal partners. They took the militant role and immediately walked out. Like a naughty child, when the parents no longer want to discipline the child they take the least line of resistance and let the child have its way. In the end, they have spoilt the child. In this case, the industry and Australia have been the losers.

The Productivity Commission states specifically that union inspired rules such as `last on, first off' should go because they detract from enterprise performance in the long term by restricting the criteria on which recruitment can be based. As a direct result, mines will be unlikely to achieve the labour productivity and unit labour cost outcomes that would be possible with greater flexibility. In the long run, retrenchment based solely on seniority can only harm competitiveness in an individual mine.

Under the Workplace Relations Act 1996, the framework sets out a manner in which to deal with this. It is allowing what the Productivity Commission said is essentialâthat is, the creation of a workplace focus where mine operators and employees take primary responsibility for workplace relations with arrangements which are the most productive and efficient and which best secure jobs. That is the key point. This is as much about securing jobs as creating wealth for Australia and maintaining our current account.

On 27 May 1998 and on 22 October 1998, the AIRC, including the deputy president and a full bench, simplified the coal industry awards over the objections of the union, including the removal of inefficient work practice rules and the outdated `last on, first off' rule, and rules which entrenched previous custom and practice. I said that that rule goes back a long way. In fact, it goes back to 1902. It is a provision which has outlived the modern industry and it is a provision that was thought right at the time of Vladimir Leninâand he was not proven to be too correct, and this particular measure has proven to be a disaster for this industry.

On 26 May last year, the AIRC also removed from the coal industry award the rules which gave preference in employment to union members or retrenched union members. On 11 August, the full bench delivered a decision which rejected union claims to reintroduce by arbitration into individual mines restrictive work practices. The AIRC said in black and white:
It is a truism that unless the mine is profitable, its future and the welfare of its employees will be in jeopardy.

I do not think this simple fact has actually dawned on many of the leadership within the unions that controlled the work forces at these mines because, if it had, they would have known that the practices they were undertaking were directly jeopardising the jobs of their own members and working against their best interests.

These were union inspired rules which prevented employers from employing the best person for the job and rewarding the best person for the job with continued employment. The unions and the Labor Party wanted to hold on to many of these restrictive prac ticesâincluding that provision which predates the Russian revolution. There is far more to be done than has already been achieved by the Workplace Relations Act, both within the framework of the act and the implementation of the More Jobs, Better Pay election commitment that the coalition took to the people in 1998.

It is clear that the focus given by the coalition to workplace reform in this industry is helping to secure the jobs of thousands of workers directly and, indirectly, the future of some of the small towns in regional communities throughout Australia. The coal industry in Australia cannot afford to stand still with the inefficient work practices or the union preferences that they have had up to date, no more than we as a government can stand on our record of good economic management and presume that that will continue into the future. We must continue to look for improvements in our work practices, as we must continue look for improvements in our capacity to run the economy. This industry is too important to Australia's future for us to neglect it. Too many workers, too many families of miners and too much of regional Australia rely on this industry for it to be allowed to be run by pre-World War I work practices.

None of these changes would have happened under Labor. Let us reflect upon what that would have meant, given what has occurred in Asia, one of the biggest export receivers. Without those contracts, without those changes to workplace relations, and without improved productivity in these mines we would have seen the closure of many more coalmines throughout Australia, and a further collapse of regional Australia. This would have been supported by the Labor government. They moved not one iota during their time in government to rectify the matter. The Leader of the Opposition stands condemned for his comments since then in referring to the fact that he would not make any changes to the restrictive work practices that they currently support.

I would like to concentrate briefly on two examples of how the mining industry can be improved through the use of the Workplace Relations Act. The example is that of Mount Isa Mines. The general manager of operations, Mr Menzies, last year outlined the dramatic changes which his company had been able to make in the industry as a result of forward thinking management changes, a focus on the workplace, the participation of employees and measures facilitated by the coalition government. He delivered a very good speech in Sydney on 15 or 16 June last year.

As I have been stating throughout this, it is a management myth that the unionâthe CFMEUâalone is to blame for the dilemma of this industry. It has been management as well. But now that management has come to realise that the days of endless dollars and clients queuing up to buy the product have gone they have recognised their responsibility. It is time for the unions to come to the table and negotiate in a constructive manner as well.

We have probably all heard of the problems that Rio Tinto had in Hunter Valley No. 1 mine. It has been the focus of much industrial attention. However, it is clear that the management at the mine and the work force have been able to change their approach to workplace relations and introduce a culture which has provided millions of dollars of valuable efficiency to the mine and hence secured the jobs in that workplace.

Let me turn now to Gordonstone which, unfortunately, has not had a good history. The ALP, on the 16th of this month, decided to weigh into the Gordonstone dispute. The member for Hunter and the member for Capricornia put out a press release saying that Labor expresses its support for the coalminers. For which coalminers do they express their support? Is it the coalminers who are currently running the mine and living in the town? Many of them are past members of the union or current members of the union but past workers in that mine under another ownership. The press release quotes a unanimously supported motion of the Labor caucus. It says:

"This Caucus expresses its support and solidarity with the CFMEU, its members and their families in its ongoing battle for industrial relations justice against the multinational Rio Tinto at its mines at Blair Athol, Hunter Valley and Gordonstone."

At Gordonstone there was no dispute with Rio Tinto. The dispute was with a previous mine owner. There was no ownership and no dispute with Rio Tinto. It was not until after this mine had been bought by Rio Tinto that they started to disrupt the workplace. They are no doubt frightening the workers who have returned to work but, more importantly, they are threatening, by their very actions, the jobs in that mine and the viability of that mine. The ALP blindly does this, irrespective of the national interest or the interest of those individuals.

The CFMEU was calling up its pay money. I believe the reason the Labor party unanimously supported this is that during 1997 and 1998 alone, and before 30 June 1998âso we are talking one financial yearâthe CFMEU donated directly to the ALP the sum of $378,798.45. That was preceding the federal election. Who knows how much more passed into the coffers from 30 June through to the election. So there was certainly a debt to be called in. But did it have to be at the expense of Australia's national interest, and at the expense of those workers who are currently working at the mine under agreements approved by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission?

The objection by the CFMEU and the ALP to what is happening at Gordonstone is a good illustration of their approach to workplace relations and industry policy. Put simply, if the union cannot control the commercial decisions made to close or open a mine then the mine should not be opened or closed. There is an irony here. In Gordonstone the community cannot believe the union's position as it was the union that objected to the closure of the mine by the previous operators because it was not done on terms acceptable to them. Now they object to the reopening of the mine because it is not being done on terms acceptable to them. A picket line remains on the site. Work continues to be done to reopen the mine and the current work force is about 50 employees.

It is not as though the mining industry is underpaid. In fact, the mining industry has some of the highest paid employees in the nation. We are talking in the vicinity of $80,000-odd per employee. It is difficult work, it is dangerous work, and I do not begrudge them one cent of it, but what we have to look at is whether the productivity that has been generated by such high wages should allow such methods to occur where people's lives are often put at risk or they feel threatened by activities conducted by what were in some cases fellow workers.

Picketers have been arrested for preventing employees leaving the site at Gordonstone and going home to their families. Employees were required to stay overnight on site away from their families. I cannot see how that destructive behaviour can actually be supported by the ALP. They could not leave because the police could not guarantee the safety of the employees leaving the site to go home. How un-Australian is that, when you consider that this is a dispute between the unions and a past owner of this mine, not the current mine owners? And one of the arrested picketers was the member for Capricornia's husband, Mr Livermore. I wonder: was this a stunt on his behalf or was this some way of ingratiating himself further to the CFMEU in the hope that a little more of the $370,000-odd that went into the Labor party coffers would come directly to her at the next campaign?

This is not a new work force or a non-union work force being brought in to reopen the mine. I have been told that a very large numberâin fact the overwhelming majorityâof the persons employed by the new operator are the former employees of the Gordonstone mine, not a new work force as claimed. I am also advised that they include union and non-union members with employment based on merit without preference to unionists. Surely, that is what we should be striving for in Australia: equality regardless of your union membership, productivity to ensure the jobs of these people, to ensure the productivity and the viability of country towns throughout Australia and to ensure that the desperately needed export dollars of Australia are not dried up through some people'sâ(Time expired)

talk.start.para: âWe are dealing in a cognate debate with Appro priation Bill (No. 3) 1998-99 , Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1998-99 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1998-99 . Apart from dealing selectively with one area of Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1998-99 , I also wish to address some more general matters in this debate which, as we have heard, is generally broad, but for a very particular reason: 40 minutes of my debating time that I might have had last year were in fact stolen from me by the Leader of the House because he gagged the address-in-reply. He also gagged debate on the GST bills before I was given an opportunity to speak. So I have 20 minutesâif I get a continuanceâin order to speak on these appropriation bills. I would seek to deal with the government's program as a whole, as well as with the GST bills.

speech.para: I want to begin with one particular aspect of Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1998-99. As we know, these appropriation bills are to gather up extra expenditure which the government has undertaken but which was not taken into account in the previous budget. They cross a range of matters. In Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1998-99 , for instance, there is about $1Â½ million worth of new expenditure, and that in part has been paid for by $507,000 worth of savings from the Parliamentary Library and the Joint House Department. However, despite cuts, the Laws and Bills Digest Group in the Parliamentary Library has still been able to do its work and Ross Kilmurray has presented some excellent background material on these appropriations bills. I will refer to his work in relation to that extensively in regard to Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1998-99 .

One of the items in these appropriation bills is from the Department of the Treasury seeking more money to the tune of $19,443,000 for a community education and information program on the introduction of the new tax system. On page 2 it says:
This program relates to the advertising and information campaign undertaken by the Howard Government prior to the 1998 general election in respect of its plan for a new tax system.

These appropriation bills retrospectively seek an endorsement for those payments for the advertising campaign that the Howard government undertook. This is not in the normal course of events how you would expect those advertising campaign amounts to be undertaken. Indeed, it has been argued that the Treasury should have foreseen that it would be necessary to expend funds on this advertising campaign and that they should have been able to predict when that would have happened.

In April 1998, the government sought $10 million for this campaign and they sought it from the Advance to the Minister for Finance and Administration, or AMFA, `a fund from which payments may be made for Commonwealth purposes which are both urgent and unforeseen'. In fact, $250,000, or part thereof, was drawn down by the end of that financial year and I think the actual expenditure was just over $57,000. The Auditor-General, who looked at these matters, in passing indicated that it should have been possible for Treasury to predict that the full $10 million would not be expended in the last financial year and that they should have some notion of the time frame for when that would be expended in the coming financial year and, therefore, that these appropriations should not have been through the Advance to the Minister for Finance and Administration but properly should have been in the last budget bills. So this is a retrospective pick-up. This is an attempt on the part of the government to give an ex post facto legitimation of what was a very unusual approach to the funding of this advertising campaign.

I would argue that it could hardly be unforeseen because the Treasurer and his department and the government had determined that they would put this advertising campaign into place. One could argue, however, that it was urgent for the government to put this to the Advance to the Minister for Finance and Administration because it was effectively to serve the coalition's party political purpose of getting re-elected.

An unusual process was adopted, and that process was widely questioned. The Auditor-General's office, after receiving legal advice, argued in the end that it was within guidelines. I think that the whole of this procedure needs to be looked at very carefully. The opposition, when it was in government, was criticised for spending money on public education campaigns in relation to its programs. The key point of difference is this: there was a cap of $5 million in relation to expenditure.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: âOrder! It being 7.30 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: âMr Speaker, I wish to raise the matter of telecommunications in my electorate of Braddon. In doing so, I wish to highlight what I think is a problem in many parts of isolated and rural Australia. There is no doubt that metropolitan Australia enjoys easy access to telecommunication services of all manner and type, and this is only rightâwe are a nation of communicators.

speech.para: The demographic and geographic make-up of our community highlights the need to communicate via electronic, satellite and microwave means. This is particularly the case in rural and remote Australia. Mass electronic communications are often the predominant means of entertainment available to remote communities and individuals.

In my electorate of Braddon, there are a number of instances of communication black spots ranging from poor to non-existent reception of mobile phone and television services to bureaucratic stonewalling on granting frequencies to community broadcasting organisations. I would like to highlight some of these black spots to demonstrate that funds which are intended to improve regional telecommunications infrastructure have not found their way into my electorate in spite of repeated claims by the former member for Braddon to have presented these problems to this government.

Weren't the people of Australia told that the partial sale of Telstra would specifically assist remote communities to receive telecommunication services? I speak of the numerous mobile phone black spots that exist on the west and north-west coasts. Given the relatively harsh climatic conditions, mountainous terrain and isolated coastal geography of the rugged and beautiful west coast and the relatively large distances faced by drivers between townships, the fact that mobile phone black spots exist seriously diminishes the ability of individuals to access help in the case of accidents and emergencies and impedes their ability to do business.

Not only are road users inconvenienced by the black spots, but bush workers, professional fishermen, traditional and recreational land users, bushwalkers and permanent residents of the numerous hamlets dotting the coast and hinterland are also affected. Several boating accidents have occurred on the west coast with a loss of life. In a number of cases the availability of mobile phone reception would have greatly aided in the rescue bids.

Even in the more populous centres along the north-west coast there are frequent black spots which impede business communicationsâimpediments which I am confident would not be tolerated in metropolitan areas. Still, we must thank ourselves for small mercies. To the north of the north-west coast is King Island, renowned for its cheese, dairy, beef, fishing and tourist industries. The island has no mobile phone service at all. This commercially oriented island is without a mobile phone service and, again, this acts as an impediment to commerce on the island as well as limiting communication support in times of emergencies.

TV aggregation from VHF to UHF frequency has not coped well with Tasmania's mountainous terrain. There are too many valley communities which receive poor TV reception and/or do not receive more than one or two channels out of a possible four. The self-help guidelines related to gaining SBS make it almost impossible for small communities in Tasmania to access this relative alternative TV programming. Because a community like Circular Head does not meet the necessary population size to be placed on the SBS priority list, it will need to raise around $100,000 to bring SBS to the municipality. This should not be the responsibility of municipal authorities. It is a Commonwealth responsibility to ensure equitable access to essential telecommunication services.

A matter that has been of considerable concern to me and radio listeners in my electorate for some time is the delay in allocating additional frequencies to community broadcaster 7DBS Coastal FM, based at Wynyard. Mr Speaker, 7DBS was granted a licence in 1989 with a proviso that translator services would be provided within 18 months to cover the station's total listening area. Since then, it has been waiting on the addition frequency allocations to enable this to proceed. You no doubt would appreciate the station's frustration that almost 10 years have passed and it still does not have the frequencies.

The Australian Broadcasting Authority appears to be unnecessarily delaying the process. The station and its listeners are at a loss to understand why, despite several attempts to discover the reason. On behalf of the station and the north-west community, I have drawn the matter to the attention of the minister and eagerly await his response. Tomorrow will not be soon enough for this very patient community radio station and its loyal listeners to receive the additional frequencies, thus eliminating the transmission black spots in its listening area and allowing it to erect the necessary translators so it can fulfil its charter of 1989. Like so many other services which metropolitan and large population areas take for granted, smaller communities like my own in regional Australia can only hope these services will come their way. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to speak about the Olympics inquiry. Much has been said in the media and, while there has been a lot of international focus and focus within Australia, there is no doubt that the night of the announcement `The winner is Sydney' was the greatest night of my life, and one of which I am very proud. The story goes that the reason why President Samaranch took so long to read out the name `Sydney' was that he had never seen Beijing written that way before.

speech.para: Be that as it may, it was a culmination of great professionalism, skill and hard work. The members of the bid team worked extremely hard for three long years, and it was the commitment of both the Fahey and Greiner governments that got these games. Mr Knight is claiming the credit for them, but we should remind people that it was these premiers who put their necks on the line to deliver the bid and who took the political risk up-front.

I have to emphasise that the games bid was a clean bid. We have heard about some of those grey areas. Certainly from our point of view we are convinced that it was done on a basis of integrity. It has always been my belief that there is one city involved in every bid that one should look at closely. I emphasise that that city is not Sydney. I believe that the people who are interested in sport and in delivering the best environment for the games voted for Sydney.

There has been much speculation on the reasons why Sydney won. I think it was because of the attractions of Sydney, the environmental credentials we have, our involvement in sports and previous games, our infrastructure plans, all the athletes being in one location, and the support of the people of the city and the people of Australia. Also, I would say, the support from the US foreign affairs committee of the US Senate who attacked Beijing over human rights issues certainly helped us at the time.

Of course lobbying was important in the whole process, and we do not apologise for the lobbying process. It was expensive and it cost us $28 million. But it is important to say at this point that of that $28 million, $20 million came from the private sectorâthat is one of the factors that has been lost in this whole exercise. If we had had $2 million sitting in that fund at the end of the games bid and we had missed out by two votes, no-one would have thanked us. We were given much in kind: the whole of the program of hotel accommodation was provided free of chargeâ$1 million worth. There were restaurants like Jordan's that provided free mealsâevery visitor went there. We had Goodman Fielder, Qantas, and carpet manufacturersâa whole range of people who provided things free. They were the people who were looking for us to deliver, and they knew what the cost was.

It is also important to recognise that, at the time we did the bid, we had an agreement from Ken Cowley of News Ltd, from Kerry Packer and from John Alexander of the Sydney Morning Herald that they knew we would be going into a high level of duchessing, and they were satisfied that that would be okay and they would not run the normal stories about it. Six years later, here we go; we have this inquiry on. I believe it is political exercise. Why couldn't Mr Knight wait for another couple of weeks until the election was over? There is no reason to be making this requirement with such urgency. The IOC has known about these people on the take for many years. I was given most of the names of those involved in Salt Lake City by one of the other failed bid committees some nine years ago. They have known about it and they are saying we have to produce it in two weeks, that it has to come out before the next election.

Who were the major players? There are no Labor Party people there because they would not have put their necks on the line. Neville Wran had the opportunity and he simply did not take it. It was the coalition that took the risk and, of course, I am sure Mr Knight would love to name people and what we did. We have nothing to hide. Let them open the books; we are happy with that. But bear in mind that there are other cities who had major programs: Manchester had major charter flights, dinners with Princess Anne and people taken to No. 10 Downing Street. There were yachts in Monte Carlo harbourâIstanbul and Manchester had their own yachts. So if we are talking about duchessing, we were one of the minor players. In fact, Berlin spent some $75 million on their programâabout three times what we did.

I believe it is time to totally reform the bid program. They should have a small technical committee involved in looking at the cities that spends no more than three to four days on one visit. They should have outside auditors to ensure the integrity of the process. Of course, a change of president would help, choosing one with a strong track record of cleaning up the corruption, of making statements of the concerns within the IOC. Mr Speaker, I believe we ran an honest bid. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI want to raise a matter this evening of great importance to me, and I think to a number of Australians. It deals with the situation of some of our returned veterans of the Second World War. There are a number of these people involved, and I have had a few come to my electorate office. In particular, I want to raise the situation of one of my constituents, Mr Harcourt Reeves of 18 Bundock Street, Kyogle. Mr Reeves is looking for a service pension because he believes that he is legitimately entitled to one. In fact, Mr Reeves served during the Second World War, but he is in one of those situations where, because of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, it would seem that he is not entitled to the pensions that are usually given to veterans of the war.

speech.para: It might be of use for me to read into the Hansard a report of a review committee that looked into Mr Reeves's application for a service pension. The report says:

2. The applicant enlisted in the Australian Army on 4 October 1944. He was discharged on 7 January 1947. The applicant served in New South Wales and Queensland from enlistment until 12 March 1946. He then travelled to Rabaul where he disembarked on 26 March 1946.

3. Mr. Reeves told the Tribunal that he served on Rabaul and Bougainville from 26 March 1946 to 11 December 1946. His duties included assisting in the round-up of Japanese soldiers who had refused to surrender. He told the Tribunal that the work was extremely dangerous because the Japanese soldiers were heavily armed and very hostile. He said the he was fired on and that some of his companions were killed by the Japanese during the round-up operation.
I continue to quote:

4. The tribunal accepts that during the operations engaged in by Mr. Reeves on Rabaul and Bougainville he incurred danger from hostile Japanese soldiers who had refused to surrender at the end of World War 2.

5. To qualify for a service pension under the Act, Mr. Reeves has to satisfy the provisions relating to "qualifying service". The provisions relevant to his claim require the following criteria to be met:
(i) Incurred danger from hostile forces of the enemy.
(ii) During a relevant "period of hostilities".
(iii) The relevant period being from 3 September 1939 to and including 29 October 1945.
6. Mr. Reeves incurred danger from hostile forces during 1946, this was well after 29 October 1945.
8. The decision that Mr. Reeves does not have the requisite qualifying service may seem to be unfair to Mr. Reeves but it is a correct reading of the provisions of the Act.

There seems to be an anomaly in this particular situation with our veterans. I know from my own experience that, even though the war finished after the bombs were dropped on Nagasaki and Hiroshima, there were many Japanese soldiers throughout the islandsâin fact throughout New Guineaâwho did not know the war had ended. I think it was some 10 years after the war when a Japanese soldier was found on one of the islands, and he still did not realise that the war had ended. He was holed up in a cave, I think, prepared to fight the enemy.

It seems to me that, in an act this parliament has passed, we have cut out people who are entitled to a service pension. As I said, there are a number of people in this situation. From my conversation with Mr Reeves, I concur with him that this was a very dangerous operation. The Japanese soldiers had been cut offâthere were no communicationsâand they were continuing to fight the war. Just because Japan had surrendered does not mean that these people were not at risk. In fact, they were at grave risk and some of them lost their lives.

I ask the minister and the executive of this government to have a close look at this situation. I do not believe it was the intention of the government of the day, or that it is the intention of this parliament or the people of Australia, to deny these people who obviously served their country in good stead and in fairly hostile conditions because, as far as the Japanese soldiers were concerned, the war had not finished.

talk.start.para: âI rise in this adjournment debate to talk about a particular migrant woman who came from Italy some years ago. She is someone who I think is typical of many hundreds of thousands of migrant women who came to this country and did the dutiful thing of looking after their husbands and their children, and whose story probably never gets told.

speech.para: I want to give you a snapshot of this particular lady. She was born on 27 April 1930, and arrived here in Australia from Sicily in 1951. She was a typical young Italian lady who was born to poor parents and used to work the fields. She was used to hard work, and life in Italy in the 1930s and 1940s was not exactly a bed of roses. In fact, as a young girl this lady used to have to walk for something like two hours every morning and two hours every night just to go to and from work, where she would carry rocks on the sides of mountains in Sicily.

She came to Australia, where her husband went up to the cane fields of north Queensland to cut cane, as many Italians at that time did. Naturally, she supported him at every available opportunity. She came over on a ship called the Australia in 1951, and she brought two children with her; one was aged four and the other was aged one. One can imagine the trials and tribulations of someone who came to this country at the age of 21 with two children, and it took a month to get here.

When she arrived, she went to north Queensland where she became the person who took the tea to the gangers out in the cane fields. Her husband then decided to go into market gardening and of course she followed, working hard looking after the fields, tilling the soil and generally being a great support for her husband. At the same time, she looked after the children and, although they were in very poor circumstances, she did the best she possibly could.

Later her husband decided that he would get involved in the hotel trade, so she trudged all around Queensland, running around hotels, cleaning the toilets and cleaning the ground, to the point where she ended up with bad knees from all the cleaning work that she did. She worked in paid employmentâand when I say `paid employment' I mean helping her husbandâuntil she was about 55 or 60. She worked in hotels, and then, to supplement the family income when things went bad at the farm, she worked at cafes in Brisbane and as a cleaner in state government buildings. She generally did what all migrant women of that time did, and I guess they still do.

One can only imagine the hardships and the suffering that they would have gone through, bringing up a family in a strange country and doing, if you like, everything that the husband wanted. In those days, if the Italian husband said, `You have to do this,' there was none of this equal opportunity stuff. They had to do it.

talk.start.para: âThe Irish were the same.

âThe Irish were probably the same, as the minister says. I can say to you that this lady was an absolutely wonderful lady, and somebody who I think should be remembered somewhere. There are so many of these people who live and then pass on, and no-one ever really tells their storyâand it is a little difficult for me, in five minutes in an adjournment debate, to do so.

speech.para: I say this because this lady was my mother. She passed away on 20 November last yearâonly a couple of months ago. She died suddenly. She went into hospital for elective surgery to fix up her knees, which she had ruined as a result of all the work she had done. Unfortunately, they must have given her too much anaesthetic or something because 12 hours after the operation she died.

As you can imagine, we miss her terribly. I mention her not because of my personal part in her story but because it is women like her whose names never go down anywhere. They are just expected to do what they do. They are fantastic people. My mother was one of a kind. I guess we all love our mothers, but I just want to say to herâwherever she is nowâthat we have not forgotten her. If nothing else, she will be forever in the annals, in the Hansard, of this place. I am very, very proud to have had her as my mum.

talk.start.para: âI thank the member for Bowman. There are many of us, in areas where there have been horticultural labourers, who could identify with the story he has just told.

âLike most rational Australians, I was appalled by last night's decision by the Senate to overturn the government's small business exemption in the unfair dismissal laws. This short-sighted decision by the ALP and the Democrats was a conspiracy against small business, a conspiracy against the unemployed and a conspiracy against battlers in electorates such as my electorate of Macquarie.

speech.para: Late last year, just a couple of days after the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business announced the decision to exempt small business from these unfair dismissal laws, I had a small businessman in my electorate office talking about a totally different issue. At the end of that interview, as he got up to leave, he said to me, `Next time you see Peter Reith congratulate him on this decision regarding the unfair dismissal laws. I'm now going to go out and put on an apprentice.' That was totally unsolicited. That is what the small businessman said to me. I wonder how he feels now. I wonder how dudded he feels having taken that risk in good faith knowing that the government had done the right thing by small business. Knowing that the government had done the right thing by the unemployed, he went out and gave a young person a job. How dudded he must feel now that the Senate, the ALP and Democrats have overthrown this rational, sensible and fair decision.
Mr Laurie Ferguson interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI am not sure what the situation will be but I am sure that this particular small businessman, like many thousands throughout the country, would be reluctant to take the risk again. How many other members have heard their constituents say, `I'd like to give a young person a job but I'm not willing to take the risk because of Labor's unfair dismissal laws. I'd like to help out the unemployed but it's too big a risk to take'?

speech.para: I could tell many stories of small business people in my electorate, but I will just mention a couple. The first case involved a small car repair business. This business had an employee who failed repeatedly to follow instructions to the extent that it cost this business a lot of money because of mechanical repairs that were not done properly. After several warnings they dismissed this employee, who then took them to court in an unfair dismissal case. The employer found out not long afterwards that this was the second unfair dismissal case and followed one the same employee had taken against a former employer. This business had to waste considerable energy, considerable time, and considerable money in fighting a case that they should not have been forced to take, all because of a vexatious claim by an employee.

The second case involved a small manufacturer in my electorate who used flammable liquids. This employer gave a very clear warning to employees before they were taken on that there was to be no smoking on the job because of the danger to the business and other employees from the flammable liquids. Two employees were caught smoking and were dismissed. Again, an unfair dismissal case ensued. Again, there was considerable cost and considerable time wasted. There was also considerable inconvenience for this employer who was trying to do the right thing by his employees.

The third case involved another small manufacturer in my electorate. This manufacturer was approached one day by a difficult employee, who said, `I quit. I don't want to work here anymore. I quit.' Because he had been somewhat difficult, the employer said, `Okay, your resignation's accepted. I accept your termination.' They parted on good terms. Two days later the employee came back, presumably after some consultation with and persuasion by the union, and said, `Sorry, I don't want to quit any more. I want my job back.' The employer, quite rightly, said, `I'm sorry. You resigned. I accepted your resignation. That's the end of the story.' This employer was also threatened with an unfair dismissal case. He had to settle out of court in a case that cost him several thousand dollars. These are three examples of the unfairness of the current legislation that the Labor Party and the Democrats refuse to allow to be changed. This legislation is costing jobs and it is hurting small business. In today's Financial Review Mr Siekmann, representative of the Small Business Association of Australia, said `the Senate had failed to understand the problems faced by small businesses in defending dismissal claims'. The Senate fails to understand small business, the Senate fails to understand the unemployed and, what is worse, the Senate fails to care for small business and the unemployed. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Home and Community Care Program: People Who Care Inc.

talk.start.para: âTonight I am speaking about the stress and difficulty being experienced by 3,500 people in my electorate as a result of the loss of a community transport and gardening maintenance service provided by People Who Care Inc. to the residents of a local council area in the city of Stirling.

speech.para: In November, People Who Care Inc. rang me to say they would be withdrawing the service from the city of Stirling area at Christmas time due to financial problems they had experienced for the past four months in trying to stretch their service to cover a number of council areas in Perth. The failure of state and federal governments to increase funding to HACC services was the ultimate cause of their financial problems.

People Who Care Inc. have been providing two needed services in the council areaâa community transport service and a gardening maintenance service. They have been providing services to people with disabilities and frail aged people for a very long timeâalmost 25 years. They are a not-for-profit organisation and raise the money to provide these services in a number of ways: funding from the federal and state Home and Community Care Program, fundraising, proceeds from op-shops, donations, project funds from such bodies as the Lotteries Commission of WA and small contributions from clients for services provided. Their services were very dependent on volunteer labour and they had very few staffâapproximately 15 but over 200 volunteers. It was a valued, needed and integrated community service.

It was valued for its work by many people and groups, including the clients, their families, groups, council, GPs, other community services who relied on them to bring the clients to them and hospitals and health services, to name just a few. Often the gardening service was the reason people could be independent, live in their homes and not be prematurely or inappropriately admitted to a nursing home.

There is another HACC funded service in the areaâContact Sâwhich also does a fine job. They also receive Home and Community Care funding. However, they have never been able to meet all the needs for services and People Who Care picked up the shortfallâ3,500 clients is an awful lot of shortfall.

People Who Care went to their funding body, the Home and Community Care Program, both at the state and federal level for additional funds, advising that they would have to withdraw their service; they had no choice. They also tried other funding programs, but there are very few where they can get additional money.

One of my constituents, Mrs Norma Wallis-Houston, brought to my attention her problem in getting community transport in Stirling when she suffered an eye problem. She is an elderly lady and a widow. She has one child deceased and two children living interstate, and she has very little, as an elderly lady, in the way of local peer groups or networks who could assist her. These are the people that lack of funding and failure of the Home and Community Care Program to be able to increase funding to local services are causing problems for. I draw it to the attention of the House, and I do hope that in the budget appropriations and over the next budget term the government will look at the issue of Home and Community Care funding.

talk.start.para: âMr Speaker, I require that the debate be extended.
âThe debate may continue until 8.10 p.m.

âEarlier in the adjournment debate the honourable member for Cook raised an issue relating to the Olympics and Sydney's successful bid for the 2000 Games. I wish to respond to some of those comments made and to add some comments that may clarify some of the matters raised by the honourable member.

speech.para: All of us are aware that in recent months events surrounding the administration and operation of the International Olympic Committee have caused consternation and concern to many people around the world. The Olympic Games is no longer a simple sporting event drawing together all nations. It is a massive business operation, and Australians and others expect corporate governance for the Olympic movement incorporating the principles of transparency, accountability and integrity. I hope the Olympic movement implements necessary reforms to restore world confidence in the Olympic ideals.

The interaction of the Olympic Games administration and Sydney's successful bid has been the subject of much comment in recent times, particularly in New South Wales. The honourable member for Cook made some comments in respect of that. As president of Sydney's bid and chairman of the board of the bid company leading up to the decision, I believe it is in the public interest that certain facts be placed on the record.

John Coates, a director of the bid company and President of the Australian Olympic Committee, recently disclosed that a commitment was made the night before Sydney was awarded the Games to representatives of the national Olympic committees of Uganda and Kenya which involved subsidising athletes and sporting events in those countries. These commitments were made without the authority or knowledge of bid company directors. On my recollection, he subsequently informed the board some weeks after the 2000 Games decision that these commitments flowed from discussions that occurred during a visit to various African countries by John Coates and Gough Whitlam several weeks before the 2000 Games decision and that this was an extension of the AOC's Oceania Athlete Development Program.
