I point outâand I am glad that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs is here at the table, as he usually is when he can beâthat what has happened in Brisbane is going to be replicated all around the country. Whether they are refugees or not, these people are still human beings. I would not have thought that this country was one which would allow this sort of thing to happen. These people are here and, as far as I am concerned, previously they were able to apply for these work permitsâwhich were not easily got; they were pretty hard to obtain. The department still had to work out that there was financial hardship, et cetera. I would like to think, to give the benefit of the doubt to the minister, that the government would not have envisaged that this sort of thing could have occurred.

I do not think that Australia is the sort of country where human beings are forced, because they cannot get money out of charities, onto the streets. This case in Brisbane involves six children, two to 18 years old. They are children and they are human beings. Sometimes I wonder how mean-spirited this federal government has become. I think that in Australia we all believe that we should have a fair go, but that should involve everybody who happens to live in this country, particularly if they are waiting for refugee status.

I noticed that yesterday the minister put out a press release and answered a question in the House with respect to the number of illegals that had been caught working illegally. If I remember correctly, the press release made a big deal about how many more people have been caught this year than last year. I think it is 16 per cent more than in January last year. I wonder how that figure is being inflated by people like this, who are now not able to obtain work permits simply to live, who have had to go out there and probably be driven underground, in trying to find some way to sustain themselves and their children.

I put out a press release a couple of weeks ago on an aspect of this which concerns me. It did not get much of a run, I guess because, in the end, it is one of those things that do not. I wonder what sort of signals it sends overseas regarding our reputationâparticularly with the Olympic Games coming up in the year 2000, only next yearâwhen we allow such a situation as appears to be occurring in Brisbane, where refugees who are here legitimately, in the sense that they are awaiting a decision, are not even able to work at odd jobs or whatever it is just to get a few dollars so they can live.

I ask the minister to look at that again. I know the minister has been heavily involved in these issues relating to refugees over many years. I do not think he would have expected this to happen. It is happening and it is going to happen more and more throughout this country, not only in Brisbane. Apart from that, the bill is not a problem and we support it. I will leave it at that.

talk.start.para: âThe Migration (Visa Application) Charge Amendment Bill 1998 before us today is very simple and straightforward. It concerns some minor housekeeping matters to finetune our excellent visa system. The bill makes some minor technical changes to the Migration (Visa Application) Charge Act of 1997 which imposes and sets charge limits. I think this debate over the technical amendments opens an opportunity to speak more widely on the matter of visas.

speech.para: I would like to address two matters: the ETAs and an issue that stems from the previous address by the opposition member. While I have some sympathy with the member's point of view, I have seen the other side of the misuse of these visas as recently as last week.

I would like to rebut those who would call on us to do away with the visitor visa system and charges for visas. Members opposite have railed against the concept of charging people for visitor visas just as there was a predictable outcry when on 1 July the $50 fee was applied to all visitor visas for the first time. However, that coincided with the full scale expansion of the ETA system, the electronic travel authority. This government has led the world with the introduction of the ETA visa system, a move which makes it very easy for touristsâfrom our major source countriesâand business people in general to come to Australia. Undoubtedly, tourism remains the largest provider of jobs in this country of ours. There are some 650,000 people in direct tourism jobs and 350,000 indirectly affected by the fortunes of tourism.

Tourism is also the second largest provider of foreign exchange earnings in the country: it generates about $16 billion a year based on 1997 figures. It was second only to mining and provided larger amounts of income than sugar, wheat, wool or beef. The introduction last year of charges for visitor visas, unfortunately, coincided with the Asian economic downturn. I do not think that would have stopped anyone from coming to this country. To try to extrapolate the fact that we had a $50â

talk.start.para: âTry talking to the tourist industry!

âThat always amazes me about you guys. Nearly every country in the world imposes charges on tourismâGST and VAT; charges to enter and to obtain visas; and charges to leave, but the second we put on a charge, the world is going to fall in. Do you think anyone who seriously wants to come to this country, to enjoy our magnificent tourist attractions or to do business, is going to run away because of $50? Lift your vision a little.

speech.para: However, free ETAs were available to tourists from our major source countries. Only Hong Kong and Taiwan did not have the ETA system and that will be rectified on 1 July this year. The ETA is a new concept in international travel. It is a world first. It is an invisible, electronically stored authority for travel to Australia for short-term tourists and those people here for business purposes.

As we all know, everyone except Australian and New Zealand passport holders is required to have a visa to enter Australia. This generally involves completing an application form and submitting it, with a passport, to an overseas government, high commission, embassy or consulate office. If the application is approved, a visa label is inserted in the passport and it is returned to the potential traveller. However, the ETA does away with the need for the application form and the visa label.

The ETA system is the most advanced and streamlined travel authorisation system in the world. ETAs are issued within 10 seconds after the applicant's personal details have been entered into the computerised system. Once issued, they can be electronically verified at airline check-in counters and at Customs officials' desks in airports, on wharves et cetera. The result is that passengers with ETAs are processed more quickly. In a survey, 96 per cent of passengers were happy with our visa arrangement, two per cent higher than in 1995 before the ETAs were introduced.

There is nothing more infuriating when you are coming into a country than to have to line up in endless queues and then, in some European countries, dribble through with torturous slowness. If we are gearing up for the year 2000 Olympics and the like, we need to be at the forefront of this modern technology. I compliment the minister for his work on this system; I think it is quite outstanding. I really think that the opposition denigrate Australia when they nitpick on something like a $50 entry charge.

The ETA system is as accessible and easy as obtaining an airline ticket because it uses existing travel industry booking terminals and telecommunications networks. The ETA sets world standards for travellers, and it is good to think that Australia is at the forefront of those standards. It provides a seamless, fast process for obtaining pre-clearance at places where airline tickets can be obtained. The ETA uses state-of-the-art technology to deliver a user-friendly product: no more having to find an embassy or a consulate, no more form filling out, no more queues, as I said beforeâjust 10 seconds of electronic transaction after the passport data is keyed in by the agent. The whole process is completed while you wait in a travel agency or, indeed, even over a phone.

The ETA system means travel agents can be a one-stop shop providing instant and total client services. It allows all your arrangements to be put together on one site, and I think that is good too. It is always stressful enough going overseas, so taking that initial phase out of your pre-arrangements is a good thing for all Australians and for all people visiting this country. Airport check-in staff can electronically confirm the authority to travel to Australia.

There are three types of ETA. The tourist ETA is free and allows stays of up to three months for each visit within a 12-month period. The long validity business ETA has the fee of $50 I referred to and is valid for up to three months at a time. And US, Canadian, French and Spanish passport holders travelling on business may apply for a short validity business ETA.

While the ETA is currently available to certain nationalities only, that list is being expanded and currently stands at 29, including our biggest tourist markets. I think that is the important point. ETAs are now generally available world wide. Travel agents and airlines had to modify their reservations and departure control systems, both to issue ETAs and to identify ETA holders. ETAs are now available from travel agents world wide; and, as at July 1998, 53 international airlines had ETAs functioning within their systems.

By the end of December, nearly 3.75 million ETAs will have been issued world wide since inception which occurred in September 1996. More than 2.1 million of these have been issued in the last 12 months. The percentage of tourists on short-term visas issued under the ETA system from January to December 1998 was 75.7 per cent, an extraordinarily high figure, as I am sure you agree, Madam Deputy Chairman. In December, 92 per cent of tourist and short-term business visas were issued as ETAs in countries whose nationals are eligible for ETAs. What a saving that must be in terms of convenience for the tourist and the elimination of bureaucracy.

Like all countries, Australia reserves the right to decide who should be allowed to enter and stay in our country. Since 1995, this authority has taken the form of a visa. Australia's visa system is universal and non-discriminatory. Visitors from anywhere in the world can apply for the same visa, subject to these arrangements having been made, as I said before.

To discriminate between countries would not be fair and could be detrimental to our long-term tourism and business interests. Visa free travellers will be disadvantaged compared with travellers who obtained a visa in advance, as they would need to be processed on their arrival in Australia. As I said before, quick processing is one of the important features of this system. They would experience time delays at migration clearance while their passport details were recorded and the purpose for their visit and proposed length of stay in Australia were determined. In addition, they would not have the certainty of entry which pre-visa visitors enjoy.

The current visa system also provides the Australian tourism industry with statistical information which enables it to plan for the rise and fall in the number of arrivals and in the current economic crisis, especially that in Asian countries, that is an added weapon to our arsenal. It is clear that the coalition has made tremendous strides in getting this system up and running. It provides great advantages for tourism but also protects our national borders.

The second matter I would like to deal with just briefly on this matter of visas is that there has been a lot of rorting of visas over recent years, and, sadly, a lot of the One Nation phenomenon arose out of a misplaced zeal to have Australia's borders secure. I do not agree with their policy but I can understand. I come from a small crop-growing area. I know people who are out there fruit-picking who were flouting Australia's visa laws. I actually knew of an occasion, which I brought to the attention of the department, where people with legitimate visas were being asked to sign two forms. I suspect that the second form was kept under the counter so that, when someone turned up without a visa, the work documents for that person to go onto a farm were readily accessible. I could never prove that, unfortunately, but I know a bit of that went on.

I think that anything we do to secure our borders, in the first instance, or to protect the jobs of Australians is worth while. I have no objection to people with legitimate work visas participating in our work force and I can see some merit in what the shadow minister said in terms of, perhaps, providing arrangements when people are here for elongated periods of waiting while refugee status is being determined.

But the case I saw recently, as recently as this week, was a case from the Philippines. It is a tribute to the vigilance of our authorities that in just a random check of some luggage they found letters to two Asian gentlemen who were coming to Australia, ostensibly to visit relatives. In this spot check it was found that a letter addressed to one of them told him what job arrangements could be made for him in Australiaâand bear in mind they were on visitors visas only.

The other one was a letter from the wife or female associate in the home country instructing the Australian contact to send half the pay home to the mother country. Sadly, I happen to know some of the relatives, not the immediate relatives but some distant relatives of this particular family. Those people gambled, they played roulette, with our visa arrangements, and they got caught.

I think it is important that we do police our visa arrangements strictly. If there are weaknesses, as the shadow minister appeared to identify, we should address those rather than say, `Let's turn a blind eye to all the visa arrangements,' because the moment you turn a blind eye to one of them you will put all the others at risk. I just wanted to touch on that briefly.

I think too that when there is a will expressed by the government, hopefully supported by the opposition, and enforced by a focused bureaucracy, the sort of nonsense that was talked about at the time of the rise of One Nation will fade to insignificance. I say that because it will be known that we have good immigration laws, it will be known that we police our visa laws strictly, and that should remove a lot of the anxiety on which these right-wing parties breed so easily.

talk.start.para: âCall them what they are: fascists.

âI am not so much interested in the personalities as in trying to find an outcome to this problem. I think that, if the government and the opposition, backed by a focused bureaucracy, get those sorts of things right, then the breeding grounds for discontent, the breeding grounds for racial comments, and the uncertainty that worries some Australian workers when they think their jobs are at risk from people holding shonky papers or shonky passports, will be removed, and the integrity of our border and the integrity of the jobs of Australians will be protected.

âThe situation with this bill, the Migration (Visa Application) Charge Amendment Bill 1998 , is uncontroversial, as the shadow minister mentioned, but it does provide the opportunity to discuss the issue of the operation of the visa system. Other speakers have spoken on that and so will I.

speech.para: Let me say that the honourable member for Hinkler's approach, that everything is gung-ho and wonderful, shows he does not know what he is talking about. I know what I am talking about because I speak as a person who was chairman of the immigration committee for four years, chairman of the caucus immigration committee for nine years, and parliamentary secretary responsible for multicultural affairs.

I can tell you that the administration of the system of visitors visas in this country is a disgrace. I do not blame the minister; the issue is not the policy. The member for Hinkler said that we are opposing the policy. No, the problem is not the policy. The problem is the way the policy is being administered, and there are very, very serious problems there.

talk.start.para: âYou had 13 years to get it right when you were chairman of those committees. What did you do about it?

âLet me say in reply to your point that the system was put in place not by your government but by our government. But it was never the intention, in putting the system in place, that the system would be misused in the way in which it is at the moment because of the very thing that you said, One Nation. Because of what has happened with the One Nation Party, the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has become the department of anti-immigration. The Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has become the department of stopping people rather than the department of dealing with people on a fair basis.
âRubbish.

âAll right; you call rubbish. You will have your turn to reply. You can go and defend the indefensible, if you wish, because what I am going to present here today is incontrovertible evidence. The member for Hinkler talked about the wonderful ETA system. He talked about how we have this system where you can go to an agent and within seconds get a visa. There is only one problem with that. The problem is that it happens in only a limited number of countries.
âIt is 29 countries and rising.

âIn 29 countries. And what about the rest of the countries, including a major number of our neighbours in Asia? What happens there? I will tell you what happens. On the one hand, we have this automatic system in which Immigration is not involved. On the other hand, we have the immigration department involved in the scrutiny of the others. What is happening in the scrutiny of the others? I will tell you what is happening, because the data was supplied to us before a parliamentary committee only a week ago.

speech.para: In certain countries, up to 46 per cent of the applicants are rejected. In the case of the Lebanon, 46 per cent of people applying for visitors visas are rejected. Is this department suggesting that 46 per cent of the people from the Lebanon are trying to deceive the Australian government and society? Of course they are not. If we talk just about the Lebanonânot the other countries that I will mention in a momentâare the department suggesting that 46 per cent of those people are trying to mislead? No. What is happening is that the department has been grabbed by excessive zeal.

You may think it is non-discriminatory to have a situation in which people from some countries, no matter who they are, can go and get a visa just like that from a travel agentâno checking of who they are, what they are and nothing about their relativesâwhen in countries like Lebanon, China, Vietnam or Turkey people are subjected to huge scrutiny and, in some cases, more than two hours of interrogation by an officer of the department. And for what?

talk.start.para: âIs that all?

âIs that all? You may think it funny that somebody from Turkey or Lebanon who has a relative here in Australia and wants to visitânot come here to reside permanently but to visit their familyâis subjected to a two-hour investigation into every aspect of their life. You may think that is fair, sir, but I will leave you to live with your own conscience, because it is certainly not fair.

speech.para: Let me give an example from Turkey. A woman here in Australia, an Australian citizen, had an accident at work. She had an operation on her back. She applied to the department for her sister to come over on a visitors visa. I supported that application. I gave my own personal assurance that this person would not be rigging the system. What happened? Firstly, the department dealt with the matter in Istanbul. The person was rejected. Then we put in a second application. I explained to the department the compassionate circumstances in this case. The person from Istanbul sent it to the chief migration officer in Ankara who then, without even the courtesy of ringing me, or making any further investigation, rejected this person. If this is what you think is a fair and a non-discriminatory system, that is an absurdity.

It is all very well to talk in theory about non-discrimination but, as with everything else in human rights, it is the practice that counts, not the theory. Even the biggest dictators of the world talk about theories of human rights. The question is the practice. I put it to you that this department is now carrying out the exercise of the visitors visa program in a disgraceful fashion. What is the justification for this kind of grilling of people? The answer that is usually given is, `They fall into particular kinds of descriptionsâthey're single, or divorced with a child, or they don't have a proper job,' notwithstanding, I might say, that in the case that I mentioned the person has a job, has a house, and is in a situation where they would not want to stay in Australia. If this is not the exercise of excessive zeal, I do not know what is.

Ever since the department of immigration has started directing its energies primarily and conclusively towards the control issues without looking at the fairness issues, we have had a lot of complaints. Let me tell you that there are people from the business community, there are people from the ethnic communities and there are people from the community generally that have protested to the department about the use of the visitors visa program. For example, the Tourist Commission itself and the tourist bodies have said that the way we exercise the visitors visa program from Asian countries is actually affecting our tourism. It is actually affecting tourism to Australia because we are subjecting them to such an intense investigation for a visitors visa that in the end people say, `To the hell with it. We will go somewhere else.' No other country subjects its visitors to this sort of scrutiny.

Okay, we introduced the two categories: the ones that come in automatically and the ones that are in the separate category and need examination. Examination is one thing. But we should not subject people to this intense scrutiny when they are coming on a visitors visa or they are coming on a temporary business visa. The interesting thing about temporary business visas from countries like China is that we have had so much trouble with them that the situation has got out of control. For example, there are now many people waiting in the queue to have their temporary business visas, especially the three-year 457 visa, considered by the government. Surely you would think, given that these people bring millions of dollars here, that the government and the department might give priority to this matter in processing the 457 visas. Oh, no! They are held up. Why are they held up? Because they happen to be from China; that is why. The situation is totally unacceptable. I say that the department is responsible for this and the department, firstly, should go and tell the minister what is really happening in relation to this matter and, secondly, should get its act together.

I know, and I have been told by the minister and others, that in fact the officers of the department are given training about sensitivity to people in relation to the visitors visas. I tell you what: if sensitivity is what they are at at the moment in terms of the experiences that are coming to my attention, the training program needs to be reconsidered from the ground up. The fact is that, when we introduced these two categories, we said that those who did not fall within the automatic category were to be considered by the department of immigration in a sensitive way. And they are not. We have people who cannot even come to visit their relatives for two or three monthsâor even a month in some casesâbecause some immigration officer makes a subjective judgment that they do not like the look of the person or that they are not convinced about the case being put before themâthat sort of thing.

I am not going to go into individual cases; I have brought some to the attention of the minister. I brought the Turkish case up because I have not taken that matter to the minister directly. I am appalled by what is happening in relation to these visitors visas. If we are going to maintain this program where we on the one hand give the travel agents in 29 countries the right to give somebody a visa in 10 seconds, but then subject people from the rest of the world, and especially our Asian neighbours, to a situation in which people are grilled and stopped from coming to Australia even for a short-term visit, it is a very serious situation.

It is true that some people choose to try to misuse their visas. Yes, we have always had that as a problem. But this is like saying, `Okay, we have got a problem with a few people, so we are going to punish all people. We have got a problem with a few people who might bring their relatives in and try to get their relatives to stay, so we are going to punish all people who want to bring their relatives in for a visit.' Visiting even for a wedding or a baptism has been refused. It is not good enough. We have to do something about this matter, because it is a critical issue in relation to the application.

Is it true that the department has been given instructions by senior officers in these embassies to reject the overwhelming majority of applications? Has that order been given? Are immigration officers under this instruction? If they are not, what is the explanation for figures such as the 46 per cent that I mentioned for the Lebanon, or the 36 per cent or whatever it is from Turkey? What is the explanation? Are we to assume that one out of three Turkish people who want to visit their relatives or who want to come to Australia for a visit is to be considered suspectâand not only considered suspect but actually ruled out, not even given the opportunity, in many cases, of appeal? We do not have appeal for visitors visas except for relatives.

It might be said, as in the Turkish case, that the person can appeal. Here she is, sick in bed. She can make an appeal, which will mean that it will be heard in a few months timeâwhen she needs her sister nowâbut the situation really is that in addition people have to pay $500. That is all very well for some rich people, but it is not all very well in the case of this person, who is on workers compensation because she had an accident at work and she had to have an operation.

This kind of thing illustrates the dilemma we are in: the department has gone from one point of view to the complete opposite. It is time for the department to re-evaluate its thinking in this matter. I call on the departmentâthe secretary to the department and the senior officersâto deal with this issue before we get attacked by the governments of the Lebanon, Turkey, China and Vietnam for discriminatory behaviour.
What would you think if 46 per cent of your people that were applying to visit Australia were told, `No, we think you are in some kind of category thatâ

talk.start.para: âThat is their right.
âI remind the member for Moreton that he will have his right in the debate. The member for Calwell should address his questions through the chair.
âYou're being very provocative, mate. Keep your values to yourselfâall right?
âThe member for Calwell should address his remarks through the chair. The honourable member for Moreton will be brought in.

âThe honourable member for Moreton ought to be ashamed of himself for his comments if he thinks this is a fair situation. The fact of the matter is that we have these problems and we have gone too far in response to the Hanson phenomenon, in trying to please people who will never be pleased about our immigration program.

speech.para: That leads me to some concluding comments about what is happening with our immigration program. As the member for Hinkler mentioned, we have respondedâunfortunately, too muchâto the Hanson phenomenon. We now have a situation in which we have cut immigration to the lowest levels for many years and there are people in the community, including the major business and industry groups, saying that we have cut immigration far too much. These industry groups are saying that we are affecting the economic wellbeing as well as the social fabric of the country.

There are also many groups in the community, not just the ethnic communities but others, who are saying that the reductions in the immigration program that have gone so far are now so serious that they are endangering the continuation of our multicultural programs. Multiculturalism in Australia has always relied on a consistent level of immigration but we have now reduced immigration to very desperate levels, at which it is almost impossible for certain categories of people to come here, no matter how worthy they are.

Under those circumstances, as a parliamentâand I am not talking about Labor, Liberal or National; I am talking about the responsibility we have to the national interestâwe must consider the possibility of expanding our immigration program because it has become so small in net terms that we are being criticised by key sectors, such as the business sector and others, about what has happened.

We also have to face up to the fact that we have an ageing population and our ageing population cannot continue in this way. We will be continuing the ageing population problem unless we do something in the area of immigration. For years we have had an immigration program orientated towards the young; these young people helped us in terms of the ageing of the population. Now we have reduced the immigration program and we have a very big problem in relation to the ageing of the population. That has to be addressed, and immigration is one way of addressing it.

We have a number of things that we have to take into consideration. We should have an open debate on this issue. I am not afraidânor are most membersâof a debate about the importance of immigration. Let us have this debate. Let us talk about why we need a bigger immigration program that is important for the future of this country and necessary to sustain our social fabric, multicultural identity and economic development.

talk.start.para: âThe member for Calwell is a passionate observer of Australian life and I welcome the opportunity to follow him in this debate. In fact, these days, the Australian Labor Party, in supporting migration from a broad cross-section of the worldâas do the Liberal and National partiesâprovide a willing contrast to the namesake of the seat of the member for Calwell, who was the architect of the White Australia Policy of the Labor Party governments of the 1940sâa policy which all sides of politics now reject.

speech.para: The member for Calwell, though, is the failed parliamentary secretary of the failed Keating government in the area of immigration and multicultural affairsâthere certainly were a lot of failures. The Keating government left Australians with absolutely no faith in the migration system in this country. They believed that multiculturalism was living in separation. As a government they practised divideâ

talk.start.para: âRubbish!
âOrder!
âand rule in multicultural communities right across this country.
âOrder! The member for Calwell has had his right in the debate. The member for Moreton has the floor.

âOne of the great contrasts of the Howard government in its short time in office, amongst multicultural groups and the broader community, has been the bringing together. In my own community, I have a very large multicultural community and I can speak with a reasonable amount of authority and daily practice in this area. The Chinese community say to me they had never met a representative from the Eritrean community, as people from former Yugoslavia say they had never had interaction with people from other countries in the world. There was this `divide and conquer': we will give you this but do not tell the other groups in multicultural Queensland or multicultural Australia that you have got it. That was the divide and rule approach of the Keating government.

speech.para: This government believes very strongly, as one of its programs suggests, that living in harmony, living together as Australians, with a fair and equal share in this country and its future is what it is all about.

In another area the Keating government left an absolute mess as far as migration was concerned: the high level of illegal immigrants in this country. In my own community, newly arrived, or even longer established, people from Asian and Chinese nations were sometimes talked about by others, their hands across their mouths, as being `illegals'â`You know; he is probably an illegal immigrant or something.' They were the sorts of damaging effects that a lot of people in my electorate felt as a result of the member for Calwell's contribution to the immigration policy in this country, during his confessed nine years of involvement in the immigration committee of the Keating government.

I think everybody in this nationâwhether they were born here, whether they have migrated here in recent years or whether they are the descendants of migrants, as I am myself, of 150 years agoâshould have faith in the integrity of the system. I know that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Philip Ruddock, is held in the highest possible regard because it is his daily activity to ensure absolute faith in the system.

talk.start.para: âI raise a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker. Nothing in what I said reflected on the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. What I was critical of was the department. I think the member should at least be honest enough to reflect that.

âIt is not a point of order. The debate was wide ranging. I allowed the member for Calwell to have a wide-ranging debate on the visa applications and the honourable member for Moreton I think is well aware of what was said in the debate. I give the honourable member for Moreton the floor.

âMadam Deputy Speaker, as you would recall and Hansard will reflect, I certainly did not suggest the member for Calwell reflected on the minister. We all know this is the very best minister and the very best person in this place qualified to be the minister in this particular portfolio area. He is doing a great job.

speech.para: The fact of the matter is that, perhaps like the member for Calwell, I know for sure that I have to deal with these sorts of visa issues on a daily basisâvisa issues raised by people who live in my electorate. I am very honoured to have the role of representing these people in this place and I have learnt so much from these people during my time here. I look after people who come from many of the world's trouble spots who are refugees and people who aspire to be great Australians, whether they have come from trouble spots or whether they have come from quite well-established nations and democracies and so forth. So I deal with these matters every day.

One thing I know for sure: the migration system, exemplified through provisions contained in this bill, is all about taking the very best the world has to offer and ensuring that all Australians understand that all migrants to this nation should be afforded the respect of being the very best potential contributors to this nation. So we are all about trying to give migrants the very best of starts in the eyes of all Australians. I think this government is doing a great job in that regard.

Visitors as well must also find that they are subjected to a few penalties and a few pressures in order to maintain the integrity of the system, because, in all too many cases, we have seen people come to this country under the guise of visitor and stay. All that does is damage the integrity of the system, damage the standing of those good Australian citizens who have come from other nations, damage the social fabric of our nation and give rise to the sort of mess and mayhem that we saw from the former member for Oxley in this place.

All citizens must be confident in the system. All citizens in Australia should be proud of the immigration system. As far as numbers of people coming to this country, those matters are always reviewed from time to time, and reviewed in the very best interest of Australia. As I interjectedâquite unparliamentary, Madam Deputy Speaker, I concedeâon the member for Calwell's contribution before, it is the right of each sovereign nation, particularly a democratic nation where all citizens are afforded the opportunity to comment on government policy through the ballot box and through their representatives, to set the standards, including the numbers, for migrant intakes. It is vital to this nation and its social fabric that we do.

All citizens of Australia should be confident that visitors, permanent residents and refugees are all afforded health checks and character checks. I submit that in fact those people are subjected to greater health and character checks and asked to commit themselves to Australia in a way that people born here are not. So all Australian citizens should be confident about that.

We all know there are high risk areas. There are areas around the world where people have used all sorts of desperate measures in order to come to this nationâa promised land for so many people. I can list a couple. We are all, as members of this place, very used to dealing with desperate people, perhaps from the Indian subcontinent, the Asian region in general, and Fiji is another difficult spot, who have come here under the guise of a visitor visa and stayed. The former Yugoslavia, Bosnia and Eastern Europe are also other troubled areas. Our Belgrade embassy is of course one of those posts where they are facing all sorts of difficulties.

I would also like to submit for the record that one of the things that has concerned me in recent times is that elements of the ethnic basis of the unrest that has taken place in those countries are perhaps seeping into some of the considerations of those applying for migration to this country. It is a matter I have raised with the minister, where an Albanian family have been subjected to the many difficulties of getting a visitor visa to this country. They allege it has got something to do with their ethnicity or religion, based on who they are dealing with in the Australian Embassy. That is a matter that is being looked at. I think it is important to state on the record that at least there are mechanisms within this country to go and review those sorts of matters.

Of course, Nairobi, which handles the Horn of Africa, is one of the most constant postsâin fact, it is on the fast dial of the fax machine in my electorate office. I wish them well in the high commission in Nairobi, but, at the end of the day, handling areas such as Somalia, Sudan, Eritrea, EthiopiaâI have residents in my electorate who have come from all of those countriesâis a very demanding job.

I firmly believe that the constituents in my electorate know that very well. Yes, you get an occasional complaint, but when you explain to them that it is all about the integrity of the system and that they themselves should feel very proud that they have come through the hoops and roundabouts that are demanded by this country in order to gain access to it they feel better about themselves. They do not feel that the tough penalties that may apply to those who breach the laws, the tough processes that are put in place to make sure we get the very best, apply to those in this country who are well intentioned, and they do not see that they are really penalties that should be fully complained about at the end of the day.

I would like to turn to some of the contributions of migrants that have come to this country. We have in this nation of migrants people from so many interesting places. I have mentioned Eritrea and Ethiopia, Sudan and Somaliaâthose sorts of places. People in my electorate and all of those other people try to make great contributions to this country and are doing so, but are having some difficultiesâalways moving from one country to another is difficultâand should be supported well by this government and by this parliament in general.

But I would like to also mention on this day, the first day of the Year of the Rabbit, the role of the Chinese community in this country. It is a marvellous contribution that so many people from Asian nations are making on a contemporary basis to Australia. As you would know, the first Chinese migrant, if you like, arrived here with the Second Fleet, and since then the role of the Chinese community in Australia has been building and growing. It has never really reached the point that it has until now, and the Chinese community need to be congratulated on their determination over the last couple of years, in particular, to play a positive role in the national debate on immigration and multiculturalism. The temptation to protestâto be loud, long and offensiveâin the face of those who are loud, long and offensive was never taken up by the Chinese community. They have shown themselves to be very dignified and very self-assured as Australians of Chinese extraction.

I think it is a marvellous thing that my daughter of nine, Jessica, is learning Mandarin in year 4 at Macgregor Primary. I think that will only help to strengthen the sort of bond that exists already in my local community where we have children of nine learning someone else's language. She can understand some of the basic Chinese script. At this important time of year, the spring festival, the Chinese New Year in the Year of the Rabbit, she understands well that Gong Xi Fa Cai means `may you have a prosperous New Year'. She understands well the values of the Chinese community with regard to the family and to industry, and promoting good business and conduct especially towards the older members of the family. They are all values that, I think, we, as Australians, in general seek to uphold.

The Year of the Rabbit promises to be a productive year. Each of these different Chinese lunar years takes on the identity of the animal for which it is named. The year before last, the Year of the Ox, was about slow but steady progress. When I think back to sentiments I offered in this place about that year at that time, I recall that the Chinese community took up the challenge of beating off the last remnants of the recession we had to have and actually progressed the economy and made their contribution to the progress of the economy over that particular year. But the Year of the Rabbit is a year of productive and frenetic activity, and I think we will see some great results from those who have come from Chinese heritage.

It is also worth noting that this is the 50th anniversary of citizenship in this nation. This year we should all feel very justified and equal and we should be living in harmony. Australia has the very best people that come through our migration system, and at the heart of our migration system is the integrity of the visa system which is facilitated by matters contained within this bill.

It is important that we emphasise what brings us together as a nation and as subcommunities within it, not what divides us. It is important that we uphold the integrity of our visa system. And, whilst I understand the passion and the frustration of the member for Calwell, a man who is well regarded in this place for his stand on human rights issues, he must understand, as all members must understand, that human rights are upheld very well by this country.

We have the highest per capita intake of refugees. No-one can dispute our commitment to looking after people from world trouble spots, but at the end of the day the fabric of our society and the integrity of the migration system are interlinked. It is very important that we do not try to cause divisions, to chip off groups in our community to have them doubt the intention of the government in these matters. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: âIt gives me great pleasure to rise to speak in relation to the Migration (Visa Application) Charge Amendment Bill 1998 . In doing so I say at the outset that Australia is a nation of immigrants. I suppose, Madam Deputy Speaker, you and I know that more than anyone. We might represent seats in different states but we both grew up in the same area and we grew up in a multicultural society that was based on tolerance and a sense of goodwill.

speech.para: On that basis I want to pick up an issue raised in passing by the member for Moreton. I will not speak today about who is the best minister. I would suggest that the minister for immigration has one of the toughest jobs in government. It is fair to say that over the last decade or so we have had a series of good ministers with people like Robert Ray, Gerry Hand, and the current minister, Philip Ruddock.

The problem is that this portfolio is a tough portfolio. The job of the minister for immigration, irrespective of who sits in that chair, is made more difficult by the freeloaders in the legal fraternity and the migration agents who seek to undermine the integrity of the migration system in Australia.

I would suggest to the House today that perhaps the time has come to acknowledge, across both sides of the House, that, irrespective of which party occupies the government benches, the job of the minister more often than not, as has been the case since the change of government in March 1996, is to seek to work in a cooperative way to maintain the integrity of the system. That is the approach I have adopted as the shadow minister, and I would hope that it is the approach that will continue to be adopted by the new opposition, when a change of government occurs, and, importantly, by whoever occupies the position of shadow minister for immigration.

Having said that, I very clearly say at the outset today that, if we are to maintain support for immigration, if we are to maintain our pride in our immigration roots, we must maintain the integrity of the immigration program.

Already Australia is one of the few migrant receiving nations in the world, and it has one of the most open and liberal attitudes to immigration regulation and citizenship. It has a system that acknowledges the responsibility of a nation such as Australia to have a humanitarian program, but also to develop a non-humanitarian program which must be based on what is in the best interests of Australia.

I understand why a host of people from a variety of areas of the world want to come and settle in Australia. Why wouldn't they want to settle in this great nation? That is what the debate on immigration has to be about: a program that is in the best interests of Australia as a nation both economically and socially, a program that acknowledges our responsibility internationally from a humanitarian point of view, but more importantly, a program that is based on integrity.

When it comes to a question of ensuring that there is a program based on integrity, that is when I believe there has to be a sense of goodwill and cooperation between the government and the opposition benches. I say that because I believe that support for these open attitudes can only be maintained if our own people have trust in the institutions that monitor and manage these regulations. That is what the real debate is about.

We will have a debate about the size of the program. I have an alternative view to the government about the size of the program. I will outline that today and we will have that debate. When we conclude the debate about the size of the program, the real debate then is about how we maintain the integrity of the program. Unless there is integrity in the program, the whole program will be pulled down Australia-wide.

It is not a question of scoring political points on either side of the House today, because the finger was pointed at all the major political parties. It has to be fair. In the minds of some in the community it has slipped in recent times. It is because of the doubt in the integrity of the system that the Hansonites, whom we largely all cooperated to turn back, were able in recent times to make a mark on our political dialogue. Hopefully, with the recent election outcome, and the fact that they are falling apart in Queensland and that they hopefully will make no electoral progress in New South Wales in the weeks to come, we are now about to see what might be labelled as the post-Hanson era as the One Nation mob implodes.

We must be careful, I also say, not to label all the supporters of the One Nation mob as crazies. They are Australian citizens who had doubts in their minds. Some of those doubts were pursued for political reasons. The perpetrators of those doubts have now been pushed back. Our responsibility as a community now is to bring some of those people who supported One Nationâincorrectly, I might sayâback into the mainstream political debate in Australia.

I, therefore, venture to suggest that many of those supporters had legitimate concerns about immigration and the perceived rorting of the system. Irrespective of who is in government, because of Australia being such a great place, there will be some in the community and beyond Australia who will seek to rort the system. I suppose in their minds that will be for the right reason. They want to get into Australia and have the same opportunity that we have as Australians. I can understand the desperate measures, although I will never support them, that some of those people will resort to in order to try and get into Australia.

We have to take those concerns into account. They were not just concerns of people who voted One Nation. The concerns were also more widespread. We have to build back trust into the institutions which monitor and manage our migration programâtrust that the system works in a just manner for all Australians. That is why the Labor Party backs the amendments before the House today. They are a small part of the trust building process. This is also part of the cooperation that often exists between opposition and government when it comes to the difficult process of handling the portfolio of Immigration.

I would also suggest to the House today that, if we are to increase our immigration intake, we must work hard to build community approval of the migration program. The support for the migration program must be rebuilt from the bottom up. The fact that this is the 50th anniversary of what I am pleased to say was Labor's Citizenship Act gives us a wonderful opportunity to rebuild support and to start a new debate about migration as we move into the 21st century. I hope the community people who, like me, want to see a vibrant immigration program which builds and strengthens our nation will go out and use the celebration of this important anniversary for that very point.

I stress the need to build and rebuild community support from the bottom up for our tradition as a nation of migrants. Elite support for immigration from business leaders, union leaders, politicians, ethnic leaders and religious leaders, et cetera, is just not good enough. In the anniversary year we need the members of service clubs, country women's associations, farmers groups, local church and other religious group members, school communities, work places, local government and ethnic communities themselves. We want them to come out, discuss and wholeheartedly support our national traditions of acceptance of diversity and a fair go for all our people, including new migrants.

We should use this anniversary year not only to celebrate what we have achieved but to review the successes and the failures, to review them in a non-political way and to learn from this review. In my view it is important that the celebration of this anniversary should be a success, creating a platform from which we rebuild and move on. In many traditions the jubilee yearâthe 50th anniversaryâis taken as the year to reassess long held values and to resolve to improve those values. It is a good traditionâa wonderful traditionâwhich we should tease out in our discussions about immigration and citizenship. It also includes considering that difficult issue, which has been shelved all too long by both sides of the House, of dual citizenship.

These discussions should also try to help to inform a lot of the debate now going on about the current annual review of our migration intake. I think we can and shouldâand I say this very clearlyâmove to a higher intake, but the nature of that intake needs to have general agreement right across the Australian community. Australians need to feel confident about the integrity of the immigration program.

Fifty years agoâand this goes to assessing what went on in the pastâour immigration program was different from what the immigration program needs to be today. It was a different world; it was a different Australia. It was different for a variety of reasons which included, for example, the nature of the times, the post-war reconstruction difficulties that confronted Australia at the time and the wonderful leadership initially offered by a person such as Ben Chifley. It was different because of the people who wanted urgently to come to Australia. They were seeking a new chance in life. It was different because of the needs of the nation at the end of the war and, most importantly, because of the question of nation building that confronted Australia at that moment. A hell of a lot of work had to be done by a nation that was, in essence, tiredâtired from a contribution that Australia made as a nation to the Second World War effort, a contribution beyond what could normally have been expected of a nation the size of Australia.

There were opportunities for employment in the way the jobs were organised in the immediate post-war era that were different from the challenges that now confront Australia on the jobs front. They are just some of the many factors. Everyone in the House could suggest a few other factors, but in talking about the immigration intake today, we really need also to recognise that the jobs revolution has changed the face of Australia from an employment point of view, and that has occurred largely over the last 50 years.

Fifty years ago we could almost guarantee jobs for anyone who came to Australia from any part of the world. Unskilled migrant workers were able to fill the expanding positions in our growing resource, manufacturing and infrastructure industries. Many of these people are now proud Australian citizens and one should not underestimate how much they valued the opportunity to take out citizenship in Australia. That is also the case with the newer wave of immigrants, for instance from Asia and elsewhere, as one sees in a very proud way at the various citizenship ceremonies that we attend on a regular basis.

Unfortunately, those people are finding that those jobs which they wanted to hold for life are disappearing from underneath them. Their lack of skills relevant to the areas of jobs growth in Australia, especially literacy, is cutting them out of the new job opportunities. I believe we have an obligation to help our people, many of whom arrived in the last 50 years, to adapt to the new jobs, train for the new jobs and add to their skill base so that they can compete for these jobs on an equal footing. If you admit to that obligation as a nation then automatically it must change your view as to the nature of our immigration program at the end of the 20th century.

We must now accept, as a nation, an immigration program which is different in composition from that which we commenced 50 years ago. Whether some in the community like it or not, the immigration program is always going to be based on what is in the best interests of Australia as a nation. Australia today is entirely different from the Australia of 50 years ago. That therefore throws up the sound suggestion that our immigration program in the future is more than ever going to be based on skills and thus we will encourage a program which providesâ

para.inline: A division having been called in the House of Representativesâ
Sitting suspended from 12.40 p.m. to 12.52 p.m.

talk.start.para: âBefore the suspension, I was dealing with the basis on which I believe the Australian immigration program should be proceeding. I referred in passing to the sharper focus on skills. I also believe that central to the program is a focus on business migration that provides opportunities to create new industries, new exports and new jobs for those already in Australia.

speech.para: In considering business migration, I also believe that we now have to seriously investigate as a nation how we should try to attract some of that business investment to the depressed areas of regional Australia. That is a challenge to all of us for a constructive debate over the next 12 to 18 months. That goes back to the thrust of the issue I raised at the outset today: migration has to be a program for all Australians and that delivers benefits to all Australians.

In that context, I also understand the serious questions raised by the Premier of New South Wales at the moment with respect to future development difficulties in Sydney. He is right to raise those issues; he is not anti-immigration. He is looking at it from a state point of view. The fact is that perhaps too many people, both from within and beyond Australia, are settling in Sydney, whereas, from a New South Wales and a national perspective, potentially we have to try to create incentives to get them out of Sydney.

In raising these issues, I also acknowledge the importance of the family stream. People should never expect the immigration program to Australia to be based on the family stream. The family stream flows from the other aspects of the immigration program. They are important but one should never determine one's intake, be it annual or of a five- or a 10-year duration, based purely on consideration of family issues.

In suggesting that, I also argue strongly that embracing such an approach to immigration is not discriminatory. It does not discriminate between one nation and another. It is based on anyone from any nation around the world seeking to apply to come to Australia based on the criteria that we establish as the basis of an immigration program that is in the best interests of those who currently live in Australia and those who want to come and make a contribution to nation building in Australia in the future. It is not discriminatory. It is about Australia as a nation deciding what is in the best interests of Australia.

A program based on these principles will also provide real hope and opportunities for the many people who would happily and willingly join us and become part of our great nation. It would be a program of integrity and one that has community support because it will deliver higher standards of living for all Australians as well as having a viable economically and ecologically sound population base.

In conclusion, I will discuss for a short while the rewriting of the preamble to our constitution and how it can play an important role in this jubilee yearâthe 50th anniversary of citizenship. I note from this morning's media that the Prime Minister has taken upon himselfânot as a process to bring in all Australian citizensâto write a preamble for our constitution in the referendum later this year.

Well, for the life of me, Mr Deputy Speaker, whatever can be said about the Prime Minister, he has never seemed to me to be a person who can be best described as a poetic soul, let alone one having the imagination needed to write the visionary prose in a preambleâwords that will sing down the generations, create a sense of adventure and commitment to the future of Australia. That is what our contribution ought to be about.

But, if the Prime Minister has taken on this task, I would like to provide a little advice to him today, as he sits down with the quill, in the new $10,000 chair that he has bought for the Prime Minister's suite. The advice I offer is that he should take into account this important jubilee. The preamble should also note that we are a nation of immigrants and reinforce the integrity of our migration traditions of citizenship and respect for diversity.

talk.start.para: âI am delighted to see you are being relevant to the bill. I had my doubts.

âThank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am also more relevant to the debate about the constitution and the referendum because I do not think any single person in this country has the wisdom to take upon themselves to draft what we should vote on at a referendum. It is an issue that should be considered and debated by all Australians. No person is the fount of all wisdom, and especially the Prime Minister of Australia.

speech.para: A new preamble can and should talk about the obligations and responsibilities of our nation, which are firmly based on our history and tradition to peacefully integrate and provide opportunities for all who come to our shores. Of course, in turn, we need to mention our obligations to each other in the nation we create, by working together as a community, as one people. Mr Howard, put pen to paper, but acknowledge that you are not the fount of all wisdom. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI would have thought, Mr Deputy Speaker, that if we are going to rewrite the preamble to the constitution, we should have got you to do it, because you are such an eloquent person.
âI thank the honourable member.

âI can get five minutes now, can't I? The opposition generally does not have any disagreement with the Migration (Visa Application) Charge Amendment Bill 1998 before us today. I think members on both sides have significant concerns about the visa entry to this country, particularly members representing an electorate like mine which has a very large numberâbordering on 40-odd per centâof constituents who were not born in Australia, and who have relations wishing to come here as visitors or as permanent residents, with friends in the same position.

speech.para: So the question of entry into Australia and the issuing of visas, be they permanent resident visas or temporary entry visas, is a very large part of the work that my electorate office does. And I have to say that we have quite considerable concerns with the way many of these visas are issued, the amount of time it takes to have visas issued and, indeed, the criteria that are often applied by posts to issuing those visas. It is not just electorates with a high number of people born overseas who have that problem, but members from across the board. Even rural electorates like yours, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, would have the same problem.

The really significant problem that we find in my officeâand knowing a little of your electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker, I think you would find the sameâis for people who wish to come on visitors visas to see family, to come to weddings, to come to christenings, to come and see a cousin they have not seen for a long while. The difficulty those people often have in having relations come to Australia is a significant concern. It is a concern that tends to militate against those who are people from non-English speaking backgrounds: if you have a relation from the UK or Ireland, you have a lot less trouble having them come for a visit than if you have a relation who wants to come from India or the Middle East or Africa. Whether there are good reasonsâand I know the minister can tell us about the profiles the department has that show that certain groups of people tend to be overstayers while others do notâit does not matter how good those reasons sound, the people themselves believe in their hearts that there is discrimination against them.

Often, as I am sure members find, you get some people who come in and you know that they have got friends or relations who have overstayed or will overstay. But we must apply our minds and the government must apply their mind to finding some way to deal with the decent people. An example I hadâI will not give the name but I think this was one I wrote to the minister about; and I am not criticising the minister here because all immigration ministers have this problemâwas a family where the couple have lived in Australia for 30-odd years. They have never been on any benefit of any sort. They are good, hard working Australians who came to this country from the Middle East. They have never sponsored anybody to come here. They have never been in any trouble. They wanted a friend to come for a holiday and, despite the entreaties that my office made to the post, they were unable to get the person issued with a visa just because a whole lot of other people from the area that that post dealt with tended to overstay.

If you are a young or single person from the Middle East, you just will not get a visa. I think that is terribly unfair to a lot of the really good people who can show that they have done everything right in this country, that they have been good, upstanding citizens. Sure, they accept that there are other people from their homeland who may have overstayed, but they should not be put in the same boat.

We have really got to the stage where maybe both sides of the parliament have to apply their minds to the question of finding a way to deal with those decent people. If we do not, we are going to find that those people will really feel a backlash and think that their value to this country accounts for less than someone from your background or mine. If we really want to do something to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Citizenship Act, we should find some way to satisfy the genuine desire of those citizens who have complied with every law and regulation that we have. If they want to invite a friend or a family member out, they should be able to.

It also often causes those people considerable embarrassment because they have been travelling back and forth to their homeland over the years, they have enjoyed the hospitality of relations and they feel that they are not able to do the right thing by their relations. They will go back to Lebanon, Syria, India or Bangladesh and stay with a friend or a relation, but they cannot reciprocate. I really think we need to do something about that.

The second issue I will touch on, and I will try to be brief, is the question of the very lengthy delays now experienced at some posts for the issuing of visas to spouses. I know that governments over a period of time have had problems with marriages of convenienceâalthough I think there are fewer of those now than in the past and people are taking a much more mature approachâbut we still have long waiting lists for spouses to be reunited. I really do not think the government should get in the way of the marital relations of Australian citizens and their spouses.

While governments may not believe in true love, I do find it rather disgraceful that someone can fall in love with a person here in Australia and marry them next week, if they want to, but if they fall in love and marry someone who does not live in this country they can find thatâas my office has foundâit can take up to two years to be reunited with their spouse. I had a woman come to my office who went through the trauma of having to have her child on her own, with her husband not allowed to come to the country because he was on this visa queue. They were married overseas, she was an Australian citizen and they could not be reunited. Both sides of politics should accept that there are fewer marriages of convenience and agree that the great number of Australian citizens who marry people from overseas should not be at a greater disadvantage than those who marry people who live in this country.

I think those two things should be addressed. I know the minister will say that they are not easyâand they are notâbut there have been a number of things that governments have addressed in changes to the migration program over the years which have overcome some of these issues. We could find some way to have a bond or some other form of enforceable penalty for people who ask someone to come as a visitor who then overstays. It is surely not beyond our wit to work something like that out.

I am sure we could do the processing for spouses of Australian citizens onshore. These are Australian citizens. They are not people who have come here for a holiday and decided they want to marry someone else who has come here for a holiday. These are often people who have been born in this country, have gone on an overseas holiday and have decided they have found someone they want to marry. Why should they have to wait and wait? It does not happen here. If you want to get married here, usually the only people who get in your way are your parents. But when people wish to marry someone from abroad, the people who get in the way are the state.

Once again, the perception isâwhether it is right or wrongâthat the state gets in the way of one group of people far more than it gets in the way of another group of people. If one of my kids went back to Ireland, where my grandparents came from, and got married, I am sure they would not be waiting 12 months for their spouse to arrive here in Australia. If my nephew, who is of Lebanese descent, went back to Lebanon and got married, he would be waiting longer than his cousin.

I do not see how we can say to people that we are not treating one group differently from others, and I really think that we ought to try to address that. I have a lot of differences with the minister over many things, but the minister is a good hearted person. I have said many bad things about the minister from time to time, but I have never said that he was not a good hearted person. I really think that these are two issues that we should try to address.

I think there is a danger for us if we do not resolve these two issues in that there will be a large group of people who live in this country, who are citizens of this country in the same way that you and I and the minister are citizens of this country, who genuinely feel that they are being treated differently. That is not fair and it is something that we should try to overcome. While the opposition does not disagree with the legislation before the House, I think that many members on both sides of the House would have quite sincere concerns with those two issues that I have just raised in this debate.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr RUDDOCK
talker.role: Immigration and Multicultural Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: âin replyâI will try to contain myself in terms of the breadth of the issues I canvass, but I do want to thank the shadow minister and the members for Calwell, Batman, Moreton, Hinkler and Watson for their comments. I will pick up some of the comments of the member for Watson since he is kind enough to remain here. He is the only person who has spoken in this debate who is here and I think, on that basis, he deserves a response to the particular matters he has raised, more so because he was so generous in a personal way.

speech.para: Your comments, coupled with those of your shadow minister, reveal the conundrum that we face. On the one hand, you were expressing the anxiety of families here who want to have family visitors and who are seeking to sponsor. On the other hand you are saying that I, as the minister, in relation to those people who have come and who seek to remain here and use every opportunity to remain here, ought also to give them work rights and provide additional incentives for someâand let me make the position clear, we are only ever talking about someâpeople who have ulterior motives.

When people live in countries with a relatively low standard of livingâwith much lower incomes than we have and few employment opportunitiesâone ought not be surprised if there are family members here, with relatives abroad, who might be desirous of family members being able to come here and even engage in employment for a time. One ought not be surprised; it happens.

So the conundrum is: how do we get the right balance? I do not want to discourage family migration. I do not wish to discourage people who are in bona fide relationships from being with their partners. I do not want to stop people who have settled in Australia and made Australia their home having their relatives and friends here for all their important occasions.

In relation to the member for Watson's comments, let me just say, dealing first with spouses, that there has been an effective reduction in the extent of manipulation. We have seen a fall off in application rates of something in the order of between 30 per cent and 40 per cent, and I suspect that that is a reflection of the fact that those people who were entering into non bona fide relationships are now not applying. I think that is the case.

It has meant that the extra staff we have put in to overseas posts to process spouse applications and to deal with enhanced bona fides are having an impact, and I am told that the delay for spouses has, on average, come down. It was nine months in 1997-98, and it was down to six months in the last half of last year.

talk.start.para: âThat does not take account of those cases where it is 12 to 18 months.

âIt certainly does not take into account the fact that in high risk areas there might be, in some cases, longer delays. I am alarmed when you tell me that somebody has experienced a two-year delay. She must have had a child for over one year, unless she travelled backwards and forwards to get pregnant. But if she was pregnant when she left him and then came back here and sponsored him, I assume the child would have been one year andâ
âI said that some people have waited for two years. This woman had a baby while she was waiting. She was not the two-year one.

âOkay, I was a bit troubled about that. I would be very concerned if there were two-year delays. There can be reasons for delay in particular cases. If there are no children involved, or if the party is not an Australian citizen and you have a big caseload, delay could occur. Sometimes it may be to do with health. For example, there may be some scars on the lungs when you do the X-rays and you have to look for tuberculosis. There are a whole lot of factors that can lead to delays. However, if you have major problems of that sort I would hope that you would continue to come to me because I am sure we could sort them out.

speech.para: I want to spend a bit more time dealing with the entry of visitors. These matters are not new and they were the subject of a very comprehensive analysis by the Joint Committee on Migration. Your colleague Senator Jim McKiernan was the chair of that committee when it looked at the procedures that we put in place.

You must understand that my officers are working in an environment where they have to make lawful decisions. We have an act, we have regulations, and they have to apply those. My officers are very much aware that every decision is appealable. The way in which we function as a department today is extremely onerous for departmental officials, in terms of the comprehensiveness of the training and in the way in which they have to deal with these sorts of issues.

If people are making a family visit they are able to appeal those decisions. I know some people believe the fees are too high, but the fees are fixed on a cost recovery basis and the appeals can be taken. Butâ
Mr Leo McLeay interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThat may be the case too, sometimes, but I will come to what I am going to offer in relation to that matter in a moment because the member for Calwell raised much the same issue when he spoke. He raised a concern about similar countriesâLebanon, China, Turkey and Vietnam. Essentially, if you look at the statistics that are available, these are all what we call high risk posts.

speech.para: When the joint committee, which came to its task with an objective approach, was asked to look at this, it said in its conclusions at 7.69 and 7.70:

The Committee is of the view that it is essential to guard against abuses of the visitor program. To that end, the Committee supports the principle that where objective data demonstrates that certain classes of entrant present a higher overstay risk, such evidence should be used by DIEA in its decision making. In the Committee's view, it is appropriate that visitor applicants who exhibit high risk characteristics be requested, where appropriate, to produce cogent evidence to demonstrate that their intentions in visiting Australia are genuine.

In this context, the Committee supports the principle of the risk factor profile. The profile is a management device constructed from objective data which simply allows decision makers to highlight those visitor applicants who must show appropriate evidence of their intention to return home. The risk profile does not mandate refusal of the visa. While the visitor visa refusal rates from posts in certain risk factor countries are high, large numbers of visitor applicants at such posts are approved.

That is still the case. I would simply say to the honourable member, and he knows this, that I instruct my overseas posts to have regard to the points that are made by members of the community who have good reputations, by members of parliament who have important reputations and who are prepared to make the point that they are putting their credibility on the line when they say these people are most unlikely to breach visa requirements.

I do not want people to do it lightly. I want them to make some judgments in relation to these matters. We do undertake intelligence work to look at whose undertakings, when they have been given, have been found to be accepted and honoured, and those whose undertakings have been accepted and not honoured. They are factors that my officers have to undertake because I do recognise that if people have a good record, if they have been able to travel in and out of Australia and exhibit that, they ought to be able to demonstrate that. And, for those who have not been able to do it, we ought to establish circumstances where they can.

This is against the background of the major problems that we have had here in Australia with people who have given undertakings. I have had people offering undertakings when they themselves had come here as a visitor, overstayed, and eventually sought permanent residence, saying, `Believe me.' These are matters of concern.

The shadow minister has come in and I am glad to see him here. There have been some very useful contributions in this debate today. I think this is an area in which it is important that we are able to work constructively, and I want to reiterate that. I am willing to work constructively with the shadow minister, as I have with his predecessors, to sort out areas in which there can be disagreement from time to time.
